DOC.HEAD: House Passes Civil Rights Bill As Congress Heads Toward Recess
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS graf 7: ``The legislative,'' with 3 grafs bgng: ``Late Friday,'' with SDI and campaign finance developments. The House is still in session and further updates are possible
DOC.TEXT: The House passed landmark civil rights legislation despite President Bush's veto threat Friday as Congress juggled a host of bills in the race toward summer recess. Attempting to meet a self-imposed deadline of finishing business by week's end, the House pushed the Civil Rights Act of 1990 closer to final passage, approving the measure by a 272-154 vote. ``Stand up for what you know is right, stand up for America's values,'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., told his colleagues shortly before the vote. The bill now goes to a House-Senate conference committee where prospects for compromise seemed bright. The Senate approved its own version two weeks ago. The bill would overturn the effects of five Supreme Court decisions in recent years, which reined in affirmative action programs. Bush argued that the measure would go too far and would led to hiring quotas. But he also promised to sign what he called ``a sound, practical compromise.'' Across the Capitol, the Senate labored over a $289 billion defense authorization bill. The debate was laced with repeated references to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait as staunchly pro-defense senators argued against steep Pentagon cuts. Senators agreed to vote Saturday on five amendments dealing with Star Wars. Late Friday, the House passed a highly contentious bill overhauling the campaign finance laws, but only after Democratic leaders eased spending limits in the bill under pressure from members concerned about their chances for re-election. The partisan 255-155 vote came after the spending ceiling in the bill was raised from $550,000 to $715,000 and members rejected a Republican alternative that would have banned ``Leadership PACs,'' political action committees run by powerful congressional figures to give funds to other members. The Senate, by a largely party-line, 59-40 vote Wednesday night, approved a Democratic bill that would limit Senate candidates' campaign spending at $2 million to $10 million, depending on their states' population. Work on those and other bills has kept the both chambers in marathon sessions deep into the summer nights. Bush argued in a letter to House Republican Leader Bob Michel of Illinois that the civil rights bill fashioned by the House and Senate would ``have the effect of forcing businesses to adopt quotas in hiring and promotion.'' ``It will also foster divisiveness and litigation rather than conciliation and do more to promote legal fees than civil rights,'' Bush said. Nevertheless, Democrats voted 240-12 for the bill. Thirty-two Republicans joined the Democratic majority Bush while 142 supported Bush's position. On the roll call for passage, the bill fell 12 votes short of what would be needed to override a presidential veto. Major provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to barriers against reopening court-approved fair-hiring agreements. The major clashes, however, came over provisions making it easier to use statistics to win discrimination suits against employers and for punitive damages for women and other discrimination victims. The Democratic-controlled House rejected 238-188 the Bush-backed alternative. Civil rights forces said that version would dilute protections against discrimination. ``It would rip the heart out of it,'' said Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas. Lawmakers said there was fierce, last-minute lobbying on the alternative, championed by Rep. John LaFalce, D-N.Y. ``The pressures have been enormous, the intimidation has belied the vision and hope of civil rights, but in the end it is my face in that mirror,'' said Rep. Nancy Johnson, R-Conn. The LaFalce alternative would have tempered language designed to make it easier to win job bias suits against employers based on statistics. It also would have capped at $100,000 punitive damages for intentional discrimination that courts could award to women, religious minorities and the disabled. The bill limits those damages to $150,000 or the amount of compensatory damages, whichever is higher. In its deliberations on the defense authorization bill for the new fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, the Senate turned back an attempt to cut nearly four times as many U.S. troops in Europe as Bush had proposed. Despite the argument that the Cold War has ended and the United States faces severe fiscal problems, the Senate rejected an amendment to cut 130,000 troops, including 80,000 in Europe. The vote was 59-40. In proposing a $307 billion defense bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, Bush called for a troop reduction of about 40,000. The Senate Armed Services Committee adopted a $289 billion military budget last month that would cut overall troop strength by 100,000.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Hits Two-Year High in July, Renews Recession Fears
DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate shot up to 5.5 percent last month, its highest level in two years, the government said Friday in a report that renewed fears that the economy may be toppling into a recession. ``The economy appears to be caving in to a full-fledged recession. The jump in the unemployment rate is the telling sign,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. On Wall Street, the stock market sold off sharply amid the new recession fears and Middle East oil concerns. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down more than 120 points at its midsession low, closed with a 54.95-point loss at 2,809.65. The Labor Department's unemployment report showed widespread weakness in the job market as payrolls fell by 219,000 jobs. That number was bloated by the 160,000 temporary census workers the government laid off, but other sectors of the economy posted job losses, too. Construction and manufacturing continued their slide and even the nation's service sector, which had been carrying the economy, suffered in July. ``It's one more nail in the coffin of the economic boom. When you have 219,000 people out there without jobs, even if many of them were census workers, you've got a lot of people without buying power. It's pretty clear evidence the economy is in big trouble,'' said Irwin Kellner, chief economist of Manufacturers Hanover Trust. The Bush administration interpreted the numbers differently. Spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the report ``does reinforce our concern for getting the deficit under control'' but said the economy is still growing. ``We don't see a recession,'' he said. But Richard Rahn, chief economist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said the U.S. economy ``is not going to hang on much longer. It is headed directly into a recession.'' Analysts were also alarmed about how America's already struggling economy might react to oil price shock from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``We're close to the edge. It wouldn't take much of a breeze to push us over ... What's going on in the Middle East may be the breeze to do it,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. Friday's statistics were the latest in a string of lackluster government reports on economic activity that showed: _The U.S. economy grew by just 1.2 percent in the second quarter of 1990, a rate far below the pace analysts believe is needed to generate new jobs. _Orders to factories for manufactured goods fell in June for the third time this year, a 1.5 percent decline which was likely to trigger further production cutbacks and layoffs in U.S. industry. _Construction spending was unchanged in June after falling for two consecutive months. _The government's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, which has been flashing weak signals for most of the year, showed no strength at all in June. The index is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance. Last month's 0.3 percentage point rise in the civilian jobless rate, which was up from the June rate of 5.2 percent, put the American unemployment rate at its highest level since it hit 5.6 percent in August 1988, the Labor Department said. Analysts had been expecting the jobless rate to jump eventually to reflect the nation's slow economic growth. So far this year, America's private industries have been producing an average of just 96,000 new jobs a month, far below the 177,000 generated monthly in 1989, the Labor Department said. Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, blamed July's weak jobs report on the deterioration of the service sector that had been ``the major engine of job growth during the current economic expansion. But that engine seems to have sputtered in July.'' The service sector suffered a 160,000-jobs decline last month. That number included temporary census workers as well as jobs in wholesale trade and business services. Retail trade added 20,000 jobs. the government said. Construction payrolls fell by 50,000 jobs, after seasonal adjustment, the fifth consecutive decline and a reflection of continued weakness in the housing market. Construction jobs are more than 100,000 below the level of last fall, the government said. The nation's manufacturing slump also continued in July, as factory payrolls fell by 7,000 jobs. It was the 15th time in 16 months that manufacturing jobs declined. Since reaching a post-recession peak in March 1989, nearly 350,000 factory jobs have been lost. Health services, which had added an average of 50,000 jobs each month in the first half of this year, expanded by only half that amount in July, adding 25,000 new jobs. Labor costs continued to increase. Average hourly earnings posted a 0.6 percent rise in July to $10.09, up from the $10.03 the average worker earned per hour in June. Overall, total civilian employment was about 118 million in July, down from the 118.4 million employed in June. The jobless numbered 6.8 million, up from 6.4 million unemployed in June. Last month's big jump in unemployment was a major departure from the steady nature of the jobless rate over the past two years. Before July, the jobless rate had fluctuated within a tenth of a percentage point of 5.3 percent since September 1988. The only exception was March of last year, when it hit a 15-year low of 5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Feds May Exhume Body of Delinquent Taxpayer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service will go to almost any lengths to retrieve back taxes. In a case against an Iranian immigrant, federal officials are considering following the man into the grave. The U.S. attorney's office says it might ask to exhume the body of Ehsanolla Motaghed just to make sure he's dead. Motaghed apparently died June 9 without paying $156,000 in back taxes. ``They're just mad because he had the audacity to die without settling his account,'' said James Martin Davis, the attorney for Motaghed's estate. Motaghed, 66, who ran an optical lens importing business, was indicted April 25 for allegedly offering a $4,000 cash bribe to an IRS agent. He pleaded innocent and was free on bail. According to both Davis and local death records, Motaghed died June 9 in his Omaha apartment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease. He was buried June 12. The U.S. attorney's office has said it is considering seeking a Douglas County Court order to have the body exhumed. Assistant U.S. Attorney Bob Kokrda has refused to say why officials suspect Motaghed isn't dead. ``This is about as grotesque a thing as I've ever dealt with,'' said Davis, who has asked the court to dismiss the charges. ``It's an identification problem,'' Kokrda said in an interview Tuesday. ``It was four days after he was put in the ground that we read in the paper that he died. We're just trying to satisfy ourselves'' that the man died. Kokrda said his office hasn't decided whether to ask for exhumation. ``If we can do it (make an identification) any other way, we will,'' he said. The IRS on Monday filed liens against Motaghed's estate, claiming he owes $156,000 in back taxes. The filing was the result of a review of Motaghed's 1985 through 1987 tax returns, said Omaha IRS spokesman Ed Daemon. Motaghed's daughter, Afsaneh McGahey of San Diego, said she was questioned two weeks ago by IRS officials about her father's death. ``I was horrified,'' said Mrs. McGahey, who is a lawyer. ``I don't know why they are doing this.'' Mrs. McGahey said she's satisfied the man in the grave at Omaha's Evergreen Memorial Park Cemetery is her father. The death certificate on file with the county identifies the body as that of Motaghed, said Douglas County Attorney Ron Staskiewicz. The certificate lists amyotrophic lateral sclerosis as the cause of death. Motaghed came to the United States 12 years ago after being expelled from Iran by the government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The indictment alleged that during a tax investigation, Motaghed offered a bribe to an IRS agent. ``He was told he owed the IRS money, and the agent said he had to pay, and so he gave the agent $4,000,'' Davis said. The Inspection-Internal Security Division, which investigates alleged bribery of IRS agents, doesn't buy that version. ``Do you think the U.S. attorney's office would take the case if it was like that?'' said Marti Hosimer, a spokeswoman in the division's Chicago office. When Motaghed was arraigned, Kokrda said his assets were between $750,000 and $1 million. Davis said Motaghed invested his money in U.S. Treasury bills and lived off the income. Davis said it would have been difficult to hide that money from the IRS. Motaghed posted his $110,000 bail in Treasury bills. Davis said Nebraska law stipulates that the only legal reason for exhuming a body is for dissection to determine a cause of death. ``They would have to dig him up for the purpose of dissection,'' Davis said. ``I've heard the IRS does that to people while they're still alive, but not when they're dead.''

DOC.HEAD: National Yiddish Book Center Makes Soviet Trip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: After years of collecting the remnants of Yiddish literature, which was virtually wiped out by the Holocaust, Aaron Lansky is taking the culture back to its roots. Lansky, founder of the National Yiddish Book Center, recently returned from a mission of remembrance: taking Yiddish books to Jews in the Baltic republics of the Soviet Union. ``These are Jews that have been cut off from their own past,'' Lansky said Friday. ``Unless they can connect now, I think they'll simply lose it.'' Lansky and his associates packed up 6,000 volumes in a rented van and drove for 12 days through the Baltic states, handing out copies of a written tradition that has nearly vanished in two generations. He recalled in particular a trip to a town in Lithuania that had been predominantly Jewish before World War II. ``There was just no trace of Jewish life at all,'' Lansky said. ``Had we been in that town 49 years before, most of the people on the street would have been speaking Yiddish to us. Here was a town that was virtually unchanged, yet the Jews had vanished.'' Lansky, 35, began ``rescuing'' Yiddish 10 years ago, when he founded the National Yiddish Book Center in western Massachusetts, running newspaper ads for unwanted Yiddish books languishing in attics and cellars. At that time, it was estimated that 75,000 books existed written in the language that had been spoken by Eastern European Jews for hundreds of years. Instead, about a million books have poured into the non-profit center, the largest repository of Yiddish works in the nation, which now has a staff of about two dozen and runs such educational programs as the Yiddish Library Development Program. Lansky got the idea to take books into the Soviet Union after receiving letters from Jews in the Baltic states who had heard of the center and hoped that the new openness would mean Yiddish could be resuscitated. The books were sent to Finland and then to Estonia, where a non-Jewish group, the Estonia Cultural Foundation, had agreed to accept them. Lansky, an associate and a photographer flew to Stockholm, rented a van and then drove to Estonia. ``We were there exactly 50 years to the day of the Soviet occupation of the Baltic states, so it was an historic time,'' Lansky said. Many of the books in the van were reprints of works that had been originally published in the Baltic states during the 100 or so years that Yiddish literature flourished, starting about 1870. Lansky said although many of the Jews he spoke to hope to leave the Soviet Union now that immigration has relaxed somewhat, they still want to keep in touch with their old traditions. ``Their grandparents were Yiddish-speaking Jews. They're not Russians, they're not Latvians, it says right in the passport that they're a Jew ... but they haven't the slightest idea what that means,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Duck Season, Turtle Season
DOC.TEXT: Snapping turtles are feeding off ducks at a town pond, but duck lovers are getting even by feasting on the turtles. The strong-jawed turtles in Douglas Pond have been latching onto ducks by the feet, dragging them under water and eating them, said Crowley Fralick, who works at a nearby sporting goods store in Bluefield. ``It is their way of survival. I understand that,'' Fralick said Friday. ``Still, it got to be a little much during the spring when the young ducklings started disappearing,'' he said. ``The little ones are easy for the turtles to catch.'' Fralick and his co-workers have responded by trapping the turtles in the one-acre pond and turning them into soup. In three years, they've caught and eaten 72 snappers. ``Last year was the first time I tried one. It was pretty good. Really, it was delicious,'' Fralick said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Leader Known Throughout Arab World by First Name
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein, to his own apparent pleasure, is known throughout Iraq and the Arab world by his first name, which means ``one who confronts.'' With his latest exploit, facing worldwide condemnation and sanctions after invading Kuwait and ousting its royal family, he seems to be living up to his name. Even little children in Iraq know their leader by his first name. Schoolgirls sing a little jingle: ``Saddam, Saddam, we will give our blood for you.'' Headlines in Iraqi and other Arab papers use Saddam to refer to the Iraqi leader. Stories might say President Saddam Hussein. But though Hussein was the first name of his father, who died before Saddam was born, he is never referred to in the press as President Hussein. He is called Saddam. Saddam was born in the close-knit town of Takrit north of Baghdad and like many other residents, bore the surname Al-Takriti. Later he abolished regional surnames. A wide interpretation of the law was that Saddam wanted to obscure the number of members of his inner circle who were relatives from Takrit.

DOC.HEAD: President-Elect Gaviria Is Small Man With Tough Ideas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The next president of Colombia is a soft-spoken economist who was catapulted to his nation's highest office less through charisma than by violent events. Cesar Gaviria of the Liberal Party _ the former campaign manager for a candidate who was killed by drug traffickers _ will become Colombia's next leader on Tuesday. He is a small man with a thin voice and a childlike face. But as a congressman and Cabinet minister, he gained a reputation for being a tough negotiator and political manipulator. ``He's a 21st-century type, smart, practical and pragmatic,'' said Jorge Orlando Melo, director of Bogota's Institute of Political Studies. One year ago, Gaviria was campaign manager for Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, an anti-drug crusader who was slain at a rally by drug traffickers. Galan's death signified the start of a bloody war against drug lords. It also marked the political rise of Gaviria, who vowed to carry on Galan's crusade against drug criminals who were endangering Colombian democracy. ``In many ways, Colombians were voting for a dead man when they chose Gaviria,'' said political scientist Camilo Castellanos. Colombians, devastated by a seemingly endless nightmare of bombings and murders, now look to Gaviria to defend their country's dignity. He takes office at a time when drug lords have declared a cease-fire, several leftist guerrilla groups are talking peace with the government and political leaders have agreed to call a national assembly to reform Colombia's 104-year-old constitution. But the atmosphere of hope is muted by the continued violence. Assassinations of political leaders, judges and policemen continue. Guerrillas still fight the army in the countryside. Earlier this week, police said they thwarted a plan by terrorists to disrupt next week's inaugural ceremonies. Security forces found three Uzi machine guns that they said were to be used to carry out terrorist attacks during the inauguration. Officials say tough security measures will protect the five heads of state and 81 foreign delegations visiting Colombia for the inauguration. But recent terrorist attacks underscore the fact that no one is truly safe in Colombia as long as so many violent elements run free. Gaviria has promised to continue the tough stance against drug traffickers taken by the current administration of President Virgilio Barco. Observers say that one of Barco's greatest achievements as president was getting the world to admit that the drug war was not just Colombia's problem. ``During Barco's tenure, Colombia went from being the criminal to the victim in the world's eyes,'' Melo said. But if Barco's biggest feat was getting the world to admit the problem, Gaviria's biggest challenge is getting it to act. Critics charge that Barco's diplomatic successes were not supported by enough foreign aid to help Colombia fight the drug war. Last year, the United States sent $65 million in logistical aid, such as helicopters and bulletproof vests. However, the economic assistance Colombia had hoped for, such as preferential treatment for its exports, never materialized. ``Compared to Barco, Gaviria is going to insist much more on the economic part, getting commercial aid, international credits, etc.,'' Melo said. Some observers say Gaviria represents a new breed of Colombian political leaders who shun the closed, old-boy network of the past. He has promised to open up the political system to under-represented groups. But not everyone agrees Gaviria represents a change. ``In order for anyone to get to where Gaviria is, you'd have to play by the rules, and those rules aren't available to everyone,'' human rights activist Clara Lopez said in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Text of U.S.-Soviet Joint Condemnation of Iraq Invasion of Kuwait
With PM-Soviet-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the joint U.S.-Soviet statement on the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, as read by Secretary of State James A. Baker III at a new conference in Moscow.

The Soviet Union and the United States, as members of the U.N. Security Council, consider it important that the council promptly and decisively condemned the brutal and illegal invasion of Kuwait by Iraqi military forces. The United States and the Soviet Union believe that now it is essential that the council resolution be fully and immediately implemented. By its action, Iraq has shown its contempt for the most fundamental principles for the United Nations charter and international law. In response to this blatant transgression of the basic norms of civilized conduct, the United States and the Soviet Union have each taken a number of actions, including the Soviet suspension of arms deliveries and the American freezing of assets. The Soviet Union and the United States reiterate our call for unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. The sovereignty, national independence, legitimate authorities and territorial integrity of the state of Kuwait must be completely restored and safeguarded. The United States and the Soviet Union believe the international community must not only condemn this action, but also take practical steps in response to it. We take the unusual step of jointly calling upon the rest of the international community to join with us in an international cutoff of all arms supplies to Iraq. The Soviet Union and the United States call on regional organizations, especially the League of Arab States, all Arab governments, as well as the non-aligned movement and the Islamic Conference, to take all possible steps to ensure that the United Nations Security Council resolution is carried out. Governments that engage in blatent aggression must know that the international community cannot, and will not, acquiesce in, nor facilitate aggression.

DOC.HEAD: With Cold War Over, Superpowers Join To Halt Gulf Conflict
With PM-Soviet-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Air Force jets have screamed low over Western canyonlands for years, practicing bombing runs for a potential war against the Soviet Union in the volatile Middle East. Now the Persian Gulf is aflame with gunfire _ but the superpowers are on the same side, trying to halt the violence from Day One. Friday's historic joint statement condemning Iraq, made in Moscow by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, is the first time the superpowers coordinated specific sanctions to stop a war. They condemned the ``brutal and illegal invasion of Kuwait by Iraqi military forces'' and agreed to seek a worldwide cutoff of arms shipments to the aggressor. They asked the entire international community to join in taking all possible steps to restore Kuwait's independence. ``These steps that we have outlined are a lot more than simply rhetoric. These are specific and concrete actions,'' Baker told a news conference. The Soviet Union, Iraq's largest weapons supplier, had already announced it was suspending arms shipments because of the invasion. The United States, which sells no military equipment to Iraq, froze Iraq's bank accounts and banned imports of its oil. The superpowers have cooperated in the past in the United Nations on such fruitless endeavors as seeking peace for Lebanon, but Friday's action is the first time they have tried to strangle a war by cutting off the aggressor's resources. It was a stark example of the radical change in Soviet foreign policy over five years of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's rule. He has been saying for years that conflicts must be decided peacefully. But the arms embargo backed words with action, at the cost of angering a long-time ally. Friday's meeting also brought dramatic evidence that the Cold War is truly over. This time, there is no fear that someone else's temper would turn an icy superpower confrontation into a conflagration that could destroy the Earth. Iraqi soldiers overran Kuwait and on Friday gathered on the border with Saudi Arabia in spite of a clear warning that the United States may enter the war if Saudi Arabia is attacked. For years the United States feared that a threat to Saudi Arabia would lead directly to a war between the superpowers. But Shevardnadze made it clear the Soviet Union has no intention of sending its own troops to the Persian Gulf. ``There are no such plans,'' he said. Shevardnadze also said he still believes Iraq ``will have the political wisdom'' to end its occupation of Kuwait. He said, one day after the Soviet Union cut off arms to Iraq, that Baghdad had assured Soviet diplomats its troops would begin withdrawing soon. Shevardnadze also warned of ``very, very severe consequences'' if any of the thousands of Soviet citizens in Kuwait and Iraq are hurt. Shortly after Shevardnadze's announcement, Baghdad Radio said Iraqi troops would begin leaving Sunday, because the provisional government set up during the invasion could stand on its own. Western diplomats called the new Kuwaiti government a puppet regime under the control of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Shevardnadze admitted that when he and Baker _ meeting in Irkutsk on Wednesday _ first discussed the Iraqi troops massing on the Kuwaiti border, ``I did not expect the Iraqis would resort to such an overt invasion, an undistinguished aggression against a defenseless, peace-loving country, which did not and does not threaten anyone.'' Shevardnadze said that if Iraq does not withdraw, the superpowers would continue to work together to that end and the Soviet Union would consider further steps of its own beyond the arms embargo. President Bush said the United States might blockade Iraq's oil-shipping routes. Richard Grimmett of the U.S. Congressional Research Service said a worldwide arms cutoff would have no immediate effect on Iraq because it has imported $43 billion worth of weapons in the past eight years. But if the Soviets, the French, the Germans and the British all refused to sell arms to Iraq, and kept up the embargo for four or five years, ``there is nobody out there who could take their place, except possibly China.'' That would eventually force Saddam to stop his military aggression, Grimmett said. Bush hailed the transformation in American-Soviet relations that allowed Friday's events. ``All the issues are on the table. We don't dodge the tough ones, and that's been the secret to our success so far,'' Bush told reporters in Aspen, Colo., on Thursday. A commentator for the Novosti news agency, Vladimir Alexeyev, said Friday that the sudden danger of war in the Persian Gulf, just as European tensions are disappearing, shows world peace is like a patchwork quilt. ``As soon as a tear is mended in one place, another appears somewhere else,'' he wrote. ``Under these circumstances, what is need are concentrated efforts on the part of all nations, on all continents, to work out a codex of international behavior that would effectively preclude the possibility of new local wars and local armed conflicts, which pose a threat to peace and have the potential of turning into major conflagrations.'' Alexeyev said the Baker-Shevardnadze meeting marked a new phase in superpower relations, ``where egocentric ambitions are being set aside and the two nations are beginning to work together for the benefit of all mankind.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Ann Imse, based in Moscow, has been covering the Soviet Union for The Associated Press for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Squid Wash Up on SoCal Beaches
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of squid have washed ashore on a three-mile stretch of a Southern California beach, apparently stranded as they chased after prey, officials said. ``Most important to state is the squid are not ill and are not casualties of a marine pollutant,'' said Herb Frey, a marine biologist with the state Department of Fish and Game. The giant squid, each measuring up to 3 feet in length and weighing about 20 pounds, formed a 18-inch-deep ``slick'' along the shore, officials said. The squid were probably chasing small fish when they began landing on the south Orange County shoreline between Dana Point and Monarch Bay late Thursday and early Friday, Frey said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says Troops to Begin Leaving Sunday; Troops Approach Saudi Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Japanese, other reax, Iraqi meeting with Saudi king. Pickup 12th, `U.S. officials...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON1,6, BAG1,2
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said Friday it will begin withdrawing troops from Kuwait in two days, but the U.S. State Department said some Iraqi soliders had pushed their advance to within a few miles of the Saudi border. An Iraqi government spokesman said all troops in Kuwait will be withdrawn according to a timetable, beginning Sunday, according to an official radio broadcast. No time was specified for complete withdrawal. The government spokesman said the Iraqi troops might stay longer if ``something cropped up that threatens Kuwait and Iraq.'' Iraq said it invaded Kuwait on Thursday to provide security for a provisional government that had overthrown Kuwait's rulers. The international community dismissed that claim. In Washington, President Bush warned Iraq not to threaten U.S. ``vital interests,'' or try to add oil-rich Saudi Arabia to its conquest of Kuwait. He said the United States was willing ``to help in any way we possibly can'' to stop Iraqi aggression. Bush has refused to rule out the use of military force. A NATO source said the United States had ``contingency plans'' in case Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, advanced his forces further through the strategic region. In related developments: _The Soviet Union and United States issued a rare joint statement demanding that all countries stop arms supplies to Iraq and that Iraq pull out of Kuwait immediately. The Soviet Union, Iraq's main weapons supplier, cut off shipments Thursday. Italy, Poland and France have also cut arms deliveries to Iraq. The United States and France have frozen Iraqi assets, while both countries and Britain also blocked Kuwaiti assets. _The United States proposed that the U.N. Security Council adopt sweeping military, trade and economic sanctions against Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait. _Japan said Friday it would go along with any economic sanctions against Iraq that the United Nations might vote to impose. _Egypt broke the silence among major Arab nations and harshly condemned the invasion. The Arab League, meeting in Cairo, also denounced the invasion and called for Iraq to withdraw immediately. The Gulf Cooperation Council, which includes Saudi Arabia, similarly criticized the Iraqi attack in a statement issued in Cairo. _Jordan's King Hussein met with Saddam in Baghdad, then announced that Arab leaders would gather for a summit Sunday to discuss the crisis. He also urged the United States not to intervene militarily. _Saudi sources said there was a good chance Saddam would meet with the ousted Kuwaiti ruler, Sheik Jaber Al-Ahmed Al-Sabah, at the summit. _Izzat Ibrahim of the Iraqi Revolutionary Command Council met in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. He made no statement. _U.S. officials sought information on 14 Americans, mostly oil workers, missing in Kuwait who apparently were seized by Iraqi forces. There are about 3,000 Americans in Kuwait. _Driven by fears of a production drop, oil prices continued to climb. North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude, rose $2 a barrel Thursday and 86 cents more on Friday to close at $23.25. Last month, oil prices were as low as $16 a barrel. Iraq's invasion followed two weeks of threats and accusations against its small Persian Gulf neighbor. On July 17 Saddam accused it of stealing oil from a field that includes land both sides claim. He also blamed Kuwait for a fall in oil prices, saying it contributed to the oil glut by cheating on its OPEC production quotas. Iraq quickly overran Kuwait on Thursday and announced that it would begin leaving when the situation stabilized. In Amman, Jordan, a senior Iraqi diplomat said Friday: ``We believe that the national government in Kuwait can take over all the responsibilities now and they are capable of defending their national security.'' Not a single member of the provisional government has been named publicly. The Iraqi government was unable to find leading Kuwaitis willing to cooperate with it in joining a government, said Gulf sources outside Iraq. An Iraqi radio broadcast, which was also carried by a station calling itself the Provisional Government of Kuwait Radio, said the al-Sabah royal family that ruled Kuwait for almost 250 years will never return to power. ``The bygone regime is finished forever and will never come back,'' the spokesman said. In his statement, the Iraqi government spokesman said that if anyone took action against Iraqi forces, Iraq would ``chop off his arm from the shoulder.'' The statement also indicated the decision to withdraw was not made to satisfy international demands. ``We refuse to respond to empty chatter, here and there, by malicious people to whom we give no weight,'' the statement said. Baghdad radio also carried a government statement denying reports it was massing troops inside Kuwait along the Saudi border. But State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Iraqi troops were between five and 10 miles from the Saudi border. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Iraqi troops were massing along the Saudi border. And residents of the Saudi border city of Khafji, reached by telephone from Bahrain, said Iraqi troops early Friday evening had laid down a checkpoint less than a mile from the border. One man, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that earlier, ``Iraqi troops almost touched the Saudi territory but went back quite politely when the Saudi border patrols instantly alerted them.'' The opposite Saudi checkpoint had registered about 50,000 foreign families fleeing Kuwait since the invasion began, Saudi border authorities said. An American couple living in Kuwait who fled to Saudi Arabia after the invasion said they saw armored Iraqi personnel carriers, howitzers, missile launchers and tanks heading toward the Kuwait-Saudi border. Elizabeth Thames, 36, of Glenrock, Pa. said however, the gathering arsenal stopped well before the frontier. Communication with Kuwait gradually died Friday, with telephone and telex lines cut and radio broadcasts extremely fuzzy. The Iraqi army faced pockets of resistance early in the day, according to residents and diplomats. Explosions and gunfire were reported at the country's main military barracks in the capital and along the coast 15 miles away. Diplomatic sources in Saudi Arabia said an Iraqi missile exploded early Friday on Saudi territory area near the Kuwait, Saudi, and Iraqi borders. It was not known if the missile was deliberately fired into Saudi Arabia, but Saudi security forces said in Saudi Arabia that an Iraqi jet had apparently misfired the missile. There were no reports of injuries or damage in the sparsely populated area. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters: ``We are extremely concerned about the possibility of Iraq broadening its invasions plans to any other country. ... They are close enough to the Saudi border to indicate cause for concern. But we don't know what their intentions or motives are.'' Saudi Arabia has the most oil reserves of any country in the world and provides the bulk of U.S. oil imports. Its troops would likely be no match against Iraqi forces. Iraq has been engaged in a major defense buildup since Saddam came to power in 1979. Its combined military forces are estimated at 1 million. The Saudis' total armed forces number 65,700. Oil is Iraq's most important revenue source, and Saddam nearly doubled his supply when he sent his army into Kuwait early Thursday and forced the ruling family to flee to Saudi Arabia. France said it was sending a second warship to patrol the gulf, joining eight U.S. Navy ships there. In addition, the USS Independence backed by six ships was heading toward the region from the Arabian Sea but was said to be several days away.

DOC.HEAD: First-Person Report on Americans' Flight From Kuwait
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Elizabeth Thames, 36, is an American from Glenrock, Pa. who worked for The Associated Press in Kuwait. She and her husband, an oil company employee, fled the Iraqi invasion to neighboring Saudi Arabia on Friday morning.

There was no way out. Rumor had it the Saudi Arabian border and roads leading to it were closed. The airport runway was laced with cluster bombs. Americans aren't used to having no options. I'm no exception. This northern Gulf state was invaded by Iraqi troops early Thursday and my first impulse was to get out. I heard shelling in the distance. I've never heard the sounds of war. I didn't know how close the invading troops were. It was the not knowing that frayed the nerves. Some said it was over, others said the worst was yet to come. I'd never known this kind of fear. The whole bizarre drama began for me at 6 a.m. Thursday. An American friend phoned telling me the news. He said there were casualties. I packed. It's funny what you think of in times of crisis. I'd just bought a new pair of shoes the day before and I wanted to be sure and pack them. I was leaving nearly all of my worldly possessions behind but I had my shoes. Others fled immediately. Our Iranian friends packed the car and drove their families to the south fast. I didn't even get to say goodbye. A tiny shop in our apartment complex was filled with nervous customers. A woman waiting in the checkout line said: ``I'm staying put. I have my birds upstairs. I can't abandon my birds.'' We took a short drive to see if I could get photographs. I saw a communications tower that had been bombed. There were long, long lines at gas stations, at banks, at the bakeries. People were wondering what would happen next. I kept asking myself if my husband and I still had jobs. We worked for the Kuwaiti government. But was there a Kuwaiti government? A friend working at the American Embassy said the shelling and gunfire were close to her home. She had two small children who were my 5-year-old son's playmates. We tried to joke about the situation but it wasn't easy. People in downtown hotels were injured by flying glass. Within hours, the rumors really began to fly: The British Embassy was fired on, the American Embassy overrun. News reports via satellite told us that the Emir fled to Saudi Arabia. Both of the Emir's palaces were under Iraqi control. Iraqi troops occupied ministries as well as the state-run radio and television stations. For a few hours in the afternoon we set about organizing a trip to Saudi Arabia and safety. But the U.S. Embassy told us to stay put. They said the roads were blocked. My husband worked in the oil fields. Three of the oil rigs he worked on were under Iraqi control. There was a rumor that Americans on the rigs were captured by Iraqi troops. Charles Cumming, a drilling foreman on one of the rigs said he saw 10 Soviet MiGs flying low over the rig. ``They were pretty loaded up,'' he said. ``I heard this massive explosion,'' . There were rumors of casualties but no one knew how many died. The shelling got louder, or seemed to. The panic grew. We decided to ignore the American Embassy and try to get out. It seemed worth the risk to get away from the fighting and we made it. My hands are still shaking. We drove about 60 miles from Ahmadi in southern Kuwait to the Saudi border. For the first 24 miles of our tense trip we saw thousands of confident, smiling Iraqi troops. Many waved us on our way. At least 100 tanks were parked not far from an Ahmadi administration building. Some young soldiers were making themselves at home by looting a small neighborhood store. As we ventured further south, we saw armored personnel carriers, howitzers, missile launchers and tanks. They were heading south, the direction of the Kuwait-Saudi border. The gathering arsenal stopped well before the actual frontier. Anyone with identification documents was waived across the border. Within minutes after leaving Kuwait we were greeted with hugs and tears by other joyous Americans and Britons. We saw about 100 who had managed to escape. We traded war stories during the hours it took to get Saudi visas and clear customs.

DOC.HEAD: `Night Music' Goes Operatic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: Stephen Sondheim's ``A Little Night Music,'' cast with actors who sang or stabbed at singing on Broadway in 1973, has entered the repertory of the New York City Opera in a classy production, with singers who act very well. Presented for the first time Friday night at the New York State Theater, it's probably the best of the hybrids the company has attempted. The voices all were good but never ``too operatic.'' Sally Ann Howes, the second Eliza in ``My Fair Lady'' on Broadway, played the actress Desiree who gets to sing the show's best-known song, ``Send in the Clowns.'' She did it with poignant musing, the way it fits into the plot. Regina Resnik, from 1944 through '83 at the Metropolitan Opera and since then on Broadway in ``Cabaret,'' played her mother, Madame Armfeldt. She has the best lines to speak and her timing and delivery were perfection. She did full justice to ``Liaisons,'' her reminiscenses of affairs. Most importantly, Miss Resnik was never vulgar. The production is elaborate and highly effective, with many scene changes. People dressed as maids and butlers swiftly carried and slid furniture in and out. A mansion front arrived from above. Much of the time blue sky with white clouds on the backdrop was reflected on the floor, setting mood. The plot, based on Ingmar Bergman's film ``Smiles of a Summer Night,'' has many facets. Fredrik Egerman (George Lee Andrews) has a young wife (Beverly Lambert) and a son (Kevin Anderson) who loves the young wife. His former mistress, Desiree, now is the mistress of Count Malcolm (Michael Maguire), whose wife (Maureen Moore) makes the most of the second best set of lines. There's a lusty maid (Susan Terry) who gets to sing ``For I Will Marry the Miller's Son.'' And there's Desiree's daughter, looking like Alice in Wonderland and played with winning solemnity by Danielle Ferland. It was an amusing idea to cast a count not only younger but a great deal taller than Fredrik Egerman. We enjoyed this ``A Little Night Music'' more than its Broadway presentation. Because it has so many different couples and entanglements and different ages and levels of experience, it is easily compared with ``Aspects of Love,'' now on Broadway. ``A Little Night Music'' seems real and wise and ``Aspects of Love'' seems more than ever to have been charted on graph paper. Scott Ellis directed. Paul Gemignani conducted a large orchestra. Michael Anania designed the set, with a raked stage at the back. Lindsay W. Davis designed costlumes and Dawn Chiang designed lighting. ``A Little Night Music'' has been scheduled for five performances in August and six in October.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Says United States May Lift Sanctions on Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher indicated the United States may soon lift the trade embargo against Vietnam. He made his remarks Friday before U.S. businessmen, who urged him to renew the trade ties that were cut when the Communists won the Vietnam War in 1975. Mosbacher said lifting of the embargo was ``still over the horizon but, depending on the talks, it could appear shortly.'' In a letter addressed to him, the American Chamber of Commerce in Thailand said U.S. companies are ``losing out on the potential Vietnam offers on many economic fronts.'' Washington has said a settlement of the Cambodian war must be reached before relations are normalized with Vietnam, which backs Cambodia's Communist government. However, the United States reversed a longstanding policy last month, announcing it would enter into direct negotiations with Vietnam on Cambodia.

DOC.HEAD: Another Philippines Coup Officer Falls
DOC.TEXT: The military says it has captured another rebel officer said to be involved in the failed December coup against President Corazon Aquino. The officer, 1st Lt. Paul Pompeyo Dario, 30, was arrested Thursday at his mountain hideout in Maria Aurora in Aurora province about 90 miles northeast of Manila, said Maj. Gen. Rodolfo Biazon, the armed forces vice chief of staff. Dario was found on a tip from a civilian informant, Biazon said. Troops seized a .45 caliber pistol, but Dario offered no resistance. Biazon said 89 officers involved in the attempt are still at large; about 21 are undergoing trial, and 60 other officers are under investigation. The mutiny left at least 113 people dead and more than 600 wounded, he said.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Caribbean Trade Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House early Saturday gave final congressional approval to legislation making permanent the duty-free status on imports from 24 Caribbean and Central American nations, including Nicaragua and Panama. By a voice vote, the House passed a trade bill extending permanently the duty-free status of $4 billion a year in imports under former President Reagan's 1983 Caribbean Basin Initiative. But the House refused to expand it to cover imports of textiles, shoes, sugar and ethanol that might threaten U.S. farmers and jobs. The Senate approved the bill earlier this week after lawmakers had spent nearly two months hammering out differences between its and the House's version. The bill now goes to the White House for President Bush's signature. In addition to the CBI, the bill also makes permanent what had been a year-to-year ban on the export of raw logs from federal land and also from state lands in California, Oregon and Alaska. Exports from state-owned land in Washington would be reduced but not halted. The log measure is intended to preserve the Pacific Northwest's dwindling timber supply for domestic mills along with enough old-growth stands to save the northern spotted owl from extinction. Exports of logs from privately owned lands would still be allowed but the timber industry generally would be prohibited from substituting them for logs from federal lands as a way to escape the ban. The Caribbean Basin Initiative was intended to lift the region's depressed economy through a combination of direct aid and an elimination of tariffs and other trade barriers to encourage the development of export-oriented businesses. Excluded from duty-free importation, however, were textiles, clothing, dinnerware, luggage, shoes and other ``sensitive'' goods that compete with U.S.-made products. Import quotas also were kept on sugar. Critics say the initiative has failed to large degree because the direct government-to-government aid fell victim to U.S. budget deficits and drastically reduced imports of oil, petroleum products and sugar from the region. In 1983, when the initiative began, Caribbean and Central American exports to the United States totaled nearly $8.8 billion. By 1988 they had dropped to $6 billion. To protect domestic sugar growers, for example, annual import quotas have been reduced from 3.2 million tons to 1.2 million over the past seven years.

DOC.HEAD: Education Department to Cover Defaulted Loans
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos, with the academic year approaching, is quickening efforts to make sure banks continue to grant student loans. Cavazos said Friday a deal will be announced within a few weeks to cover the defaulted loans guaranteed by the financially troubled Higher Education Assistance Foundation, or HEAF, of Overland Park, Kan., one of the nation's largest insurers of those loans. ``We are intensively involved in sensitive discussions with other organizations that have an interest in and capacity for assuming all of HEAF's guarantee functions,'' Cavazos told the Senate Labor and Human Resources education subcommittee. ``We are committed to putting in place a solution that will ensure that new loans are made and insured without interruption, and that the existing HEAF portfolio is properly serviced, collected, insured and reinsured,'' he said. He told the panel the arrangement would be in place ``within a few weeks.'' Education Department spokeswoman Etta Fielek said it is unlikely HEAF will survive the restructuring. The financially threatened foundation guarantees student loans in Minnesota, West Virginia, Kansas, Nebraska, Wyoming and the District of Columbia, and insures loans in other states as well. HEAF, one of 47 guarantors nationwide, told the Education Department four weeks ago it was having serious financial problems because of a high default rate. The foundation blamed the problem on overlending to students who attend private trade and technical schools, students from largely low-income backgrounds who either drop out or earn too little after graduation to repay the loans. Cavazos, who has already tightened regulations on loans for students at private trade schools, said he will seek further restrictions on their accreditation and licensing next year. He also said regulations will be published next week aimed at barring false information from the schools. Under the student loan program, banks make the student loans and groups such as HEAF guarantee that they will be repaid and take over collection. The federal Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, provides money to lenders by selling packages of loans to investors. The Education Department is the backup insurer to the guarantors. The taxpayers must make up the difference between the default liability and what the department takes in through loan fees and collections. The department said last week that the taxpayer costs for the troubled foundation would not surpass $100 million. Several alternatives have been suggested for the bailout: a takeover by Sallie Mae; a takeover by Indianapolis-based United Student Aid Funds, another large guarantor; and a spreading out of the bad loans over a number of agencies.
