Soviet Students May Be Drafted To Help with Harvest
DOC.TEXT: College students may be ordered to help bring in a bumper Soviet harvest and delay the opening of their fall terms by one month, according to Vladilen Nikitin, director of the state food commission. Nikitin said Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov signed an order Friday drafting at least 15 percent of the nation's civilian trucks to help with the harvest. The officials Tass news agency reported Thursday that tens of thousands of soldiers and even KGB personnel are harvesting a grain crop estimated at a record 260 million tons. ``We have to consider it reasonable to draft students for a month, to permit deans to postpone studies for a month,'' Nikitin told the ``Vremya'' TV news program Friday. The Soviets are already losing 2 million tons a day because they cannot harvest and store the grain fast enough. Soviet news media blamed shortages of fuel, trucks and storage space, as well as the centrally planned economy's inability to adjust to the demand. The government has already sent 70 army battalions with 35,000 trucks to help with the harvest, and Tass said another 20 battalions with 10,000 trucks will be added.

DOC.HEAD: Executive Says S&L Deal Saved Taxpayers $100 Million
DOC.TEXT: An insurance executive whose acquisition of 15 failed savings and loans has been labeled a sweetheart deal says the transaction saved taxpayers more than $100 million. James M. Fail of Phoenix said the collection of Texas thrifts that he now operates under the name of Bluebonnet Savings Bank of Dallas ``is part of the solution to the savings and loan crisis, not part of the problem.'' ``Bluebonnet already has saved the American taxpayer over $100 million as compared with continuing the operations of the 15 insolvent thrifts,'' Fail said in testimony scheduled for delivery Monday to the Senate Judiciary antitrust subcommittee. The remarks were distributed to reporters Friday. Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, the subcommittee chairman, has sharply criticized the deal between Fail and the now-defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board. He said Fail acquired the thrifts and was awarded government subsidies valued at $1.8 billion after investing only $1,000 of his own money. Fail borrowed the rest of his initial $70 million investment, half of it from an insurance company he controls, Metzenbaum said. But in his statement, Fail said ``substantially all'' of the government assistance ``ultimately will go to depositors and creditors of the 15 failed thrifts, paying for mistakes made long before I ever heard of any of those thrifts.'' He said Bluebonnet's profits ``do not depend solely on government largesse _ they depend on managing the institution well,'' he said. Fail said the suggestion that he acquired Bluebonnet for $1,000 was ``ridiculous.'' He said he was committed eventually to invest a total of $120 million, has invested $95 million so far and had ``pledged substantially all of my business holdings as collateral for personal loans'' in the deal. Further, he said, Bluebonnet has distributed no earnings to its shareholders and as chairman of the institution he receives only an $18,000 annual retainer and a $1,000 fee per meeting. A $35 million loan for the acquisition from an insurance company he controls has been a good deal for the company's policyholders, he said, noting that the loan has paid $6.4 million in interest. Metzenbaum has questioned why the bank board did not disqualify Fail as an acquirer because a company he controlled had pleaded guilty to fraud in 1976 in Alabama. But Fail said he had repeatedly disclosed his legal problems.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Protesters Demand Greater Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Anti-government protesters who have put up 14 tent cities across the country say they have 250,000 supporters and will fight for more democracy despite the election of an opposition intellectual as president. Protest leaders expressed confidence that Zhelyu Zhelev, the philosopher chosen Bulgaria's first non-Communist president in decades, and his deputy Atanas Semerdzhiev, a reformed Communist, will bring more democracy to Bulgaria. ``The conservative Communist forces are giving in, although slowly,'' said a declaration read at a news conference Friday. But the protesters swore to continue their struggle for more democracy, especially in towns and regions outside the capital of Sofia. The parliamentary opposition, the 16-party Union of Democratic Forces alliance, meanwhile elected Petar Beron, a biologist and zoologist, to replace Zhelev, who led the alliance in June's free elections and became president Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Diagnosis Of Disease in Human Egg Called Important Advance
DOC.TEXT: A new technique that allows diagnosis of inherited diseases in an unfertilized human egg before conception is being described as an important step toward the prevention of genetic diseases. On Friday, researchers reported that they had diagnosed cystic fibrosis in a human egg before conception. They said the technique could be used with many other inherited ailments, including muscular dystrophy, hemophilia and sickle cell anemia. The technique could satisfy some abortion opponents' objections to fetal diagnosis, said Yury Verlinsky, director of the Reproductive Genetics Institute at Illinois Masonic Medical Center in Chicago. These diseases can now be diagnosed in the fetus before birth. But such diagnosis often leaves the parents with no option but to terminate the pregnancy if the fetus carries the disease. The new technique of pre-conception diagnosis makes abortion unnecessary, Verlinsky said in a telephone interview. ``I feel it's going to be the technique of choice for the families who are carriers for genetic diseases,'' he said. ``It's better to avoid abortion and to have this technique to conceive only a normal child. ``I get letters from right-to-life people who say this is good research,'' Verlinsky said. Dr. Norbert Gleicher, director of the Center for Human Reproduction at Mount Sinai Hospital in Chicago, called it ``a very, very important advance. In practical terms, this is a very important step and a very smart concept.'' An important limitation of the technique is that it can be used only in conjunction with in-vitro fertilization or IVF, the ``test-tube baby'' technique in which an egg is fertilized in a laboratory dish and the resulting embryo is implanted in the mother's womb. ``IVF, which is what you're involved in, has a limited success rate,'' said Dr. Laird Jackson, director of the division of medical genetics at Thomas Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia. In other words, many eggs judged to be free of disease using pre-conception diagnosis will fail to result in births because of the difficulties of in-vitro fertilization. Nevertheless, technical advances in the future could change that, Jackson said. And pre-conception diagnosis was clearly of value for parents who are opposed to abortion, he said. Last November, Verlinsky reported the development of the new technique at a meeting of the American Society of Human Genetics. His report of the pre-conception diagnosis of cystic fibrosis appears in today's issue of The Lancet, a British medical journal. The technique makes use of a cell called a polar body that is discarded by an egg as it matures, Verlinsky said. An immature egg contains a pair of each of the 23 human chromosomes. As the egg matures, it discards one set of chromosomes in the polar body and retains one set. The sperm that later fertilizes the egg imports a set of the father's chromosomes, so the fertilized egg is back to full strength with a pair of each chromosome. Verlinsky analyzes the genes in the polar body to determine whether the remaining genes in the egg carry the cystic fibrosis defect. On Thursday, Dr. Alan Handyside and colleagues at Hammersmith Hospital in London reported the first birth of children who were examined for genetic diseases by screening test-tube embryos before the embryos were implanted in their mothers. In that technique, an egg fertilized in a test tube is allowed to divide until it forms an embryo of eight cells. One cell is removed and analyzed for genetic defects. If the embryo is healthy, it is implanted in the mother's womb. Verlinsky, who has also experimented with that technique, said it could be used in conjunction with the pre-conception screening in circumstances in which the pre-conception screening alone was not enough to assure that the fetus did not carry a genetic disease. The research team at Hammersmith Hospital also is experimenting with pre-conception diagnosis, Jackson said. The pre-conception diagnosis of cystic fibrosis currently is limited to children of the 70 percent of cystic-fibrosis carriers with the most common of the many genetic mutations that can cause the disease, Verlinsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Roseanne Barr is hearing some cheers again. About 100 fans showed up to support the star of the popular television comedy series ``Roseanne'' on her arrival Friday at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. Supporters held up signs such as ``Barr None Roseanne. You're No. 1. Keep singing those Barrs'' and ``Welcome Roseanne. Have a spit'n good time in the Twin Cities.'' Barr has been under fire since singing a shrill rendition of ``The Star Spangled Banner'' at a San Diego Padres game last week. Barr, loudly booed by the crowd, capped the performance by grabbing her crotch and spitting on the ground in what she said was a parody of a baseball pitcher. The rally was organized by Lori Peterson, a recent University of Minnesota Law School graduate who told Barr she was the victim of sexism. ``We believe it's not so much what she did, but rather who did it,'' Peterson said. Barr said she doesn't know if people would have been as upset had the performance come from a male comedian. Barr, also a standup comic, is scheduled to perform tonight in St. Paul, Minn.

Actor Timothy Busfield, who allegedly threatened to boycott ``thirtysomething'' unless he got a hefty raise, is returning to work after settling a dispute with the makers of the acclaimed ABC series. Busfield plays the advertising executive whose wife's battle with ovarian cancer is expected to be a key part of the show's coming season. He was nominated Thursday for an Emmy award. David Gerber, chairman of the MGM-UA Television Production Group, said Friday the studio had settled a dispute with the actor. On Wednesday, the studio filed a lawsuit that alleged breach of contract and said Busfield had threatened to boycott the show. Busfield wanted $36,375 an episode, while MGM-UA had offered him $28,750 per episode, the lawsuit said. MGM-UA spokeswoman Lori Gerson wouldn't say if the lawsuit has been dropped. Production of the series' fourth season began Friday in Los Angeles.

Oscar-winning actor Karl Malden has been elected to a second term as president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Malden, 77, will serve a one-year term on the academy board. He has served on the Academy Board of Governors for seven years. He won the Academy Award for best supporting actor in 1951 for ``A Streetcar Named Desire'' and also earned an Oscar nomination for supporting actor in 1954's ``On the Waterfront.'' Both films starred Marlon Brando. Malden went on to star with Michael Douglas in television's ``Streets of San Francisco'' and appeared most recently with Barbra Streisand in the 1987 film, ``Nuts.''

John Hall, executive director of a broadcast artists' union whose members include entertainers David Letterman and Roseanne Barr and anchormen Dan Rather and Peter Jennings, is resigning for health reasons. Hall said Friday he is stepping down Nov. 1 when his contract expires as executive director of the 77,000-member American Federation of Radio and Television Artists. A federation spokeswoman said Hall is suffering from a heart ailment, but gave no details. The union represents both entertainers and news staffers in local and network broadcasts. Hall, who has headed the federation since 1985, will be succeeded by Bruce York, now the union's assistant national executive director. Hall will continue with the federation as a consultant for two years.

DOC.HEAD: House Boosts Federal Borrowing Limit by $72 Billion
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Senate vote on debt limit; picks up 4th graf pvs bgng Last Tuesday.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate early Saturday voted to let the government sink $72 billion deeper into debt over the next two months, a cash infusion designed to avert an unprecedented federal default. The Senate passed the bill by voice vote after the House on Friday cleared the bill by a vote of 247-172. The bill, requested by President Bush, would provide enough money to keep federal coffers full through Oct. 2. Last Tuesday, the House approved a longer-term extension of the debt limit providing $322 billion in borrowing authority. But that measure, the target of possible amendments in the Senate, is not expected to move toward enactment until after Congress' August recess. The Treasury has warned that the government will run out of money by Aug. 15 unless its authority to borrow money is extended. With Congress poised to begin its month-long August recess at the close of business Friday, lawmakers had to approve the measure before leaving the capital. By Aug. 15, the government is expected to deplete its cash-on-hand. In doing so, the total federal debt will hit a record $3.12 trillion. The government has never defaulted on its payments. If it did so, economists say interest rates would skyrocket and financial markets could be badly shaken. ``Failure to enact the bill would result in disastrous economic, political and financial consequences,'' said House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. Because debt limit extensions are must-pass legislation, they consistently attract unrelated amendments that would have little chance of passage on their own. Oct. 2 is the second day of fiscal 1991. It is a date by which Bush administration and congressional budget negotiators would like to complete their work on a deficit-reduction deal. Because any budget-cutting pact would contain unpopular tax increases and spending cuts, budget bargainers would like to attach their package to the next extension of the debt limit.

DOC.HEAD: TV Coverage of Iraqi Invasion a ``Dark Spot''
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait was filled with the tanks and soldiers of the invading Iraqi army, but for a second day, the U.S. networks were unable to get pictures of the combat from the scene. Network news made do Friday with arrow-filled maps; phone interviews with reporters, business executives and others inside Kuwait's capital city; file footage taken before the invasion, and related reports from around the world. But with Kuwait's airport closed and outsiders barred, network correspondents in the area _ including CBS anchorman Dan Rather _ and their camera crews had to do their reporting from neighboring Persian Gulf countries. Rather was vacationing in Europe when the invasion began. He rushed to the Middle East to join CBS correspondents there, officials at CBS said. Correspondents were not allowed into Kuwait or Iraq, said officials at CBS, NBC, ABC and Cable News Network. In one Gulf state that let correspondents file taped reports via satellite, jittery officials, fearful of angering Iraq, asked them not to mention the country from which they were reporting, network executives said. It resulted in correspondents ending their stories by simply saying they were reporting ``from the Gulf.'' Network producers in the Middle East remained tuned to telecasts from Baghdad, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia for news footage from Kuwait. But it was in vain, executives said Friday. In a major story like this, some sort of footage from the scene usually turns up, ``but this one has just been a dark spot,'' said Ed Turner, CNN's vice president for news gathering. It was particularly frustrating for ABC News, which had videotape taken Thursday inside Kuwait. ``We have pictures in Kuwait, but we haven't been able to get them out,'' said Robert Murphy, ABC's vice president for news coverage. He said he didn't know what shots were on the videotape.

DOC.HEAD: Stark to Sullivan: ``I Blew It''
DOC.TEXT: Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan says he is frustrated that he cannot express his own political beliefs without suffering ``race-based criticism.'' Sullivan, in a speech in Los Angeles Friday night to the National Association of Black Journalists, was referring to a remark by Rep. Fortney ``Pete'' Stark, D-Calif., that Sullivan was a ``disgrace to his race and his profession'' because of administration policy on health care for the poor. ``I guess I should feel ashamed because Congressman Stark thinks I am not a `good Negro,''' Sullivan said. ``As a Cabinet member who has spent almost four decades of my life dedicated to healing, ... (I) am unable to express my own views without being subject to race-based criticism by those who are not ready to accept independent thinking by a black man.'' Sullivan called the remarks by Stark, a chairman of a House health subcommittee, ``incomprehensibly offensive.'' Both Sullivan and the administration had demanded an apology after the Thursday remarks. Friday on the House floor, Stark, who is white, conceded that ``I blew it'' by injecting race into his criticism of a black cabinet member for backing Bush administration policies. But Stark told the House he stood by his main point _ that administration policies are harming blacks and the poor _ and regretted that race had obscured his complaint. ``To the secretary, I have to say I blew it,'' Stark told the House. ``I should not have brought into the discussion his race, because it obscures the fact he is carrying on a bankrupt policy ...'' Sullivan spokesman Bob Schmermund said Stark's latest comments were not the apology Sullivan was looking for. ``He was right about one thing: he blew it. Other than that, we certainly don't view what he said on the House floor as anything close to an apology,'' he said. The White House called Stark's remrks a ``bigoted assault.'' Before Stark spoke, House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., led a series of Republican critics on the House floor. He charged that Stark had brought ``discredit on this institution,'' demanded an apology and called Stark's attack ``as bizarre as it is deplorable.'' ``No matter how heated our debate may be, no one has a right to bring into question a man's race or religion or national origin,'' Michel said. Stark rose moments later and said Michel ``is absolutely right. To bring in race or religion ... into a policy debate is wrong.'' But he repeated his complaints that Sullivan was going along with Bush administration policies that hurt the poor and minorities. He said the policies were denying them decent medical care, job training, extended unemployment benefits, and denying abortions for poor women. Democratic National Chairman Ron Brown, who is black, said in a prepared statement that he was glad Stark had ``clarified his original intent.'' ``I do not believe that Mr. Sullivan is a disgrace to his race,'' Brown said. ``However, I do think that many of the Bush administration's policies, like Reagan's policies before him, are disgraceful. I believe that is the point that Congressman Stark was trying to make.'' The Republican National Committee then entered the argument, saying Stark's ``unfair, unwarranted and shameless'' attack warranted strong language from Brown. ``Since Stark only half concedes he was wrong, Chairman Brown needs to step up and condemn him,'' GOP consultant Charles Black said in the RNC statement. Black is filling it for the ailing GOP Chairman Lee Atwater. Rep. Craig Washington, D-Texas, who is black, rose in Stark's defense. He told the House that if Republicans were sincere in denouncing the racial remarks, he hoped they would vote for the civil rights bill before the House. Stark made his initial remarks Thursday in response to questions at a news conference on another subject. He refused to apologize at a second news conference later that day. Stark accused Sullivan of switching to an anti-abortion position at the urging of administration officials and opposing expanded federal health coverage to the uninsured for the same reason. The two differ on those issues and also over federally sponsored national health insurance, which Stark is pushing and Sullivan said last month he opposes.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Advisers Vote to Delete Artists' Anti-Obscenity Pledge
DOC.TEXT: The advisory body of the National Endowment for the Arts is pushing for the elimination of an anti-obscenity pledge that artists and arts institutions must sign before they can receive federal grants. After an emotional debate, the National Council on the Arts urged endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer on Friday to stop requiring grant recipients to agree in writing to comply with a congressional ban on using federal funds for works that might be deemed obscene. The 17-2 vote by the presidentially appointed council is not binding on Frohnmayer. ``I'm going to consider it and take my action in due course,'' said Frohnmayer. The motion to remove the anti-obscenity pledge was sponsored by council member Roy Goodman, a New York state senator and arts patron, who called it ``a loyalty oath reminiscent of the McCarthy era'' of anti-communist witch hunts led by Sen. Joseph McCarthy, R-Wis., in the 1950s. Goodman said the pledge insulted and alienated the arts community and worsened the furor surrounding the endowment. ``The artist knows what the law is,'' he said. ``We don't have to rub his nose in it.'' Frohnmayer instituted the pledge after conservative lawyers led by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., persuaded Congress last October to amend the arts endowment's current $171 million budget to include a prohibition against federal support for obscene art. The ban, prompted by protests over an NEA-supported exhibition of works by the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, includes ``depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts.'' Frohnmayer placed the text of the anti-obscenity ban in the regulations that govern the award of endowment grants. Of the 2,000 NEA grants approved by early July, a dozen recipients have signed the pledge under protest, a half-dozen have refused to sign and forfeited their grants, and two have challenged the requirement in federal court. At Frohnmayer's urging, the council amended Goodman's motion to make clear that it did not relieve NEA grant recipients of the need to comply with anti-obscenity law. Without such a qualification, Frohnmayer said, ``the signal might be that the endowment is thumbing its nose at the law.'' The council was beginning a three-day meeting devoted mostly to reviewing grant applications approved by the endowment's panels of outside experts in dance, theater, music and other arts disciplines. Council member Lloyd Richards, dean of the Yale School of Drama, said the controversy over obscene art had injected fear into the arts community and threatened to transform the NEA into a ``National Endowment for the Agreeable.'' Another member, Phyllis Berney, an arts patron and former member of the Wisconsin Arts Board, said the endowment had lost public confidence because of the Mapplethorpe exhibit and other ``offensive art.'' ``First Amendment rights are an issue for lawyers,'' she said, saying the real issue is ``a handful of individuals who want to shock, and do it with public funds.'' Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., chairman of a House subcommittee that oversees the arts endowment, warned there is ``no chance'' that Congress will authorize an extension of the NEA this year without some form of restrictions on obscenity. Williams won loud applause from council members and spectators who crowded into the hearing room when, in a reference to Mapplethorpe, he denounced the ``howling mob of people hurling epithets at a dead, gay male artist'' and other artists whose works are controversial.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Mideast Forces to Be Bolstered With Third Carrier
LaserPhoto WX6
With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States is sending a third aircraft carrier and 15,000 sailors and Marines toward the Middle East early next week to bolster its naval armada in the Persian Gulf crisis, Pentagon officials say. As military strategists and lawmakers debated the dangers of committing U.S. combat troops to a protracted desert war against Iraqi tanks, it was clear that the immediate U.S. response to Iraq's seizure of oil-rich Kuwait was to focus on a show of naval strength. Officials said 15 naval vessels led by the carrier Saratoga and including a Marine amphibious assault unit will leave East Coast ports on Monday and Tuesday for the Mediterranean. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams refused to link the latest ship movements with the gulf crisis, saying they had been planned for months. Although the Saratoga had been scheduled to relieve the USS Eisenhower, he said, the two carriers might remain together on duty in the Mediterranean for a while. The Eisenhower was deployed in the region in March. Its Marine amphibious unit has been stationed off the coast of strife-torn Liberia for several weeks. The carrier Independence already is steaming toward waters outside the Persian Gulf from the Indian Ocean to back up the U.S. Navy's task force of eight warships already stationed inside the gulf. While the United States is focusing for the time being on naval maneuvers, concerns were expressed at the Pentagon and on Capitol Hill about the implications of sending American troops into battle against Iraq's 5,500 tanks and million-man army. Even though billions of dollars in U.S. arms have been sold to Saudi Arabia over the years, its 65,000-man army is largely untested on the battlefield. Just last month, the Saudis signed an agreement to buy $3 billion of the U.S. Army's most advance tanks, the M-1A2s, but they aren't scheduled for delivery until the mid-1990s. Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told NBC the United States could ``dominate the gulf from a naval standpoint (and) we can dominate them in the air,'' but that landing U.S. combat troops ``would be a major problem.'' Military observers note that most Mideast nations friendly to the United States have refused to allow U.S. bases on their territory. The closest major ground forces available to the United States are based in Western Europe or on the island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean, a week to 10 days away from the Persian Gulf region by sea. ``We were impotent 10 years ago in the hostage crisis and we're impotent now,'' said one military analyst, who spoke only on condition that he not be identified. ``We have no infrastructure there to accept any kind of land forces. No way to get water, food, fuel _ let alone tanks and trucks _ to support a land war,'' he said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met with Bush at the White House on Friday and then reviewed Iraqi military moves and U.S. options with Gen. Colin Powell and other members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The possibility of an Iraqi thrust into Saudi Arabia worried members of Congress. Lawmakers who attended secret briefings on the crisis said the 120,000 Iraqi troops massed along their southern border could easily attack the Saudis next. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said such a development would raise ``the most serious security questions'' for the United States and ``would call for a direct military response by the United States, Western Europe, maybe even the Soviet Union.'' Added Foley: ``This would be an action that could not be ignored.'' The Saratoga will be accompanied by the guided missile cruiser Philippine Sea, the destroyer Spruance, guided missile destroyer Sampson and frigate Elm R. Montgomery, all based in Mayport, Fla. Departing Norfolk, Va., will be the battleship Wisconsin, guided missile cruiser Biddle, frigate Thomas C. Hart and destroyer tender Yellowstone. The fast combat support ship Detroit, based in Earle, N.J., will also join the battle group, the Pentagon said. Those nine ships are scheduled to leave on Tuesday. They will be preceded on Monday by five ships that make up the Marine amphibious ready group. Those are the amphibious assault ship Inchon and the amphibious transport dock Nashville, both based in Norfolk, and the dock landing ship Whidbey Island and tank landing ships Newport and Fairfax County, based in Little Creek, Va. Carriers are normally outfitted with a wide array of missiles and firepower, including FA-18 jet fighters, F-4 attack aircraft and A-6E bombers. Currently, there are 18 U.S. Navy ships in the Mediterranean with about 10,000 personnel aboard, Pentagon sources said. Inside the gulf, the U.S. military presence is represented by eight warships of the Joint Task Force Middle East, led by the command ship USS LaSalle and including a cruiser, destroyer and frigates.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Justice Marshall Hospitalized After Fall
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall is recovering in a hospital after a fall earlier in the week in Chicago, a court spokeswoman said. Marshall, 82, was admitted to the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., where he was listed in stable condition, said Toni House. She said Marshall, who was in Chicago to speak at the annual convention of the American Bar Association, stumbled in the lobby of his hotel Thursday evening. He flew back to Washington Friday ``because he prefers consulting with physicians he knows,'' said House, adding it did not appear he had broken any bones in the fall. She said Marshall does not plan to return to Chicago, where he was scheduled to address a dinner of the ABA's Judicial Administration Division Monday night. Marshall, a staunch liberal on the court, has had several health problems in recent years. He had a heart attack in 1976 and has suffered bouts of pneumonia and bronchitis. He was treated at the National Naval Medical Center in 1987 for a blood clot in his right foot.
DOC.HEAD: Bad Testing And Faked Records Cloud Some Communities' Drinking
DOC.TEXT: Water

Drinking water in many small communities falls below federal health requirements and in some cases violations are being hidden by improper tests or falsified records, a congressional study says. The General Accounting Office said in a report released Friday that an investigation of compliance to drinking water standards at 75 community water systems in six states showed many local authorities are not complying with the federal requirements. The study also said that efforts by the Environmental Protection Agency to uncover violations and take enforcement actions against the local water officials frequently are ineffective. ``We found that many water systems, particularly smaller systems, are violating requirements for monitoring water quality and meeting drinking water standards,'' Richard Hembra, the GAO's director for environmental issues, told a House Government Operations subcommittee. The Environmental Protection Agency acknowledged problems with getting small community water systems to comply with federal clean water requirements. She also acknowledged that some violations of federal drinking water standards go unreported because of erroneous information from local officials or inadequate monitoring by states. Nevertheless, Ms. Wilcher maintained that said the most serious violations have been resolved and in that available reports showed that 73 percent of the community water systems, serving 183 million people, were complying with federal health standards for drinking water in 1989. According to the GAO report, however, those statistics may overstate compliance nationwide.
DOC.HEAD: One Clean Air Issue Disposed of By Conference Committee
DOC.TEXT: Senate and House negotiators on clean air legislation reached agreement on a schedule for ending, by the close of the decade, use of chemicals that damage the ozone layer. But leaders acknowledged Friday the most difficult issues of the legislation have yet to be discussed. Among other provisions, the negotiators agreed to forbid states and local governments from restricting or banning the chemicals for two years. The conference committee is not scheduled to meet again until after the August congressional recess. House and Senate staffers were directed to work through the month to draft possible compromises on various parts of the two bills. Negotiators said they hoped the agreement on ozone-destroying chemicals would help break the deadlock. That agreement calls for phasing out such chemicals, including chlorofluorocarbons, halons and carbon tetrachloride, widely used as coolants, solvents and foam blowing agents, by the end of the decade. Some substitute chemicals that are less harmful to the environment such as HCFCs _ chlorofluorocarbons that contain one or more hydrogen atoms _ would be phased out over the next 40 years. The measure also calls for recylcing of these chemicals by 1992, and the installation of precautions to prevent routine release into the air.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors File Bankruptcy Petition Against Stotler Group
DOC.TEXT: An involuntary bankruptcy petition has been filed against Stotler Group Inc., a brokerage company formerly headed by the newly resigned chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade. Stotler Group said in a statement Friday night that the petition originated with ``three parties claiming to be creditors'' holding more than $1 million in unpaid obligations. Money troubles plaguing Stotler Group resulted in the recent announcement that its principal subsidiary, Stotler and Co., was getting out of the futures trading business. That announcement led to the resignation Wednesday of Karsten Mahlmann as chairman of the company and chairman of the world's largest futures market. Thomas M. Egan, president and chief executive officer of Stotler Group, said the company had been in negotiations with the creditors in efforts to reach a solution. ``Our intention and desire was to avert a filing in bankruptcy by developing a workable plan to cooperate with and maximize the return to creditors,'' Egan said. ``However, it appears unlikely that any return to shareholders of Stotler Group will be possible under the current circumstances,'' he said. The petition names only Stotler Group Inc., and does not affect Stotler and Co. or its other holdings. Stotler and Co. was one of the largest brokerage firms before it announced its plan to liquidate its futures business. Stotler Group identified the petitioners as Advanced Portfolio Management, which holds a $1 million unpaid note of the Stotler Group, and two parties that received part of $4.15 million in defaulted commercial paper held by Compass Futures. Advanced Portfolio Management and Compass Futures are pooled investment funds operated by Stotler Funds Inc., another Stotler Group subsidiary. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission earlier this week accused Stotler Funds of improperly talking money from APM and Compass to help bolster its parent company. The funds were supposed to be used only for investment in commodity markets. Mahlmann has denied any involvement in Stotler's recent financial decisions, saying he had spent almost all his time running the Board of Trade.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Extends Bush's Authority to Tap Strategic Petroleum Reserve
DOC.TEXT: Congress early today extended for an extra month President Bush's authority to tap the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve should Iraq's invasion of Kuwait disrupt the world oil market. On a voice vote with no dissent, the House approved an emergency temporary extension of the Energy Policy Conservation Act that established the rainy-day stockpile in the event of another oil disruption. Without the extension, Bush's authority to pump crude oil from the stockpile to relieve shortages would expire Aug. 15 while Congress is on vacation. The Senate passed the same bill Thursday. ``Given the events in the Middle East with respect to Kuwait, it would be unwise to leave town without extending the current law,'' Rep. Norman Lent, R-N.Y., said. The stockpile, stored in salt caverns along the Louisiana-Texas coast and accumulated at a cost of more than $20 billion over the past decade, now has 580 million barrels, enough to replace imports from abroad for 50 days at current import levels. Congress and the administration have been battling the past 18 months over whether to increase the reserve to 1 billion barrels in view of growing U.S. dependency on foreign oil. Bush has opposed increasing the reserve beyond 750 million barrels.

DOC.HEAD: Report: 120 Iraqi Officers Executed for Refusing to Fight Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: A leading Egyptian newspaper reported today that Iraq executed 120 of its military officers who refused to fight against Kuwait. The government-owned Al-Ahram said in a Baghdad-dated front-page report that the executions occurred Friday, a day after Iraq invaded Kuwait in a dispute over land and oil. The report did not cite any source, raising the possibility that it was an Egyptian intelligence leak. It said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein approved the death sentences handed down by a military court. ``The officers had refused to obey orders issued to them to participate in the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait because this represented an unjustified aggression on a sister Arab state,'' the paper said. The paper did not give the names or ranks of the executed officers. It did not say how the officers were put to death, but executions for military crimes in the Arab world normally are carried out by firing squad.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Major Oil Spill Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House passed and sent to President Bush early today a bill triggered by the wreck of the Exxon Valdez that would strengthen federal oil spill liability laws. The House approved 360-0 the compromise worked out by a House-Senate conference committee as one of its last actions before recessing for the summer. It passed despite strong objections by some lawmakers to a one-year moratorium on drilling off the North Carolina coast. The Senate voted 99-0 Thursday to approve the legislation, more than 16 months after the Exxon Valdez tanker ran aground in Prince William Sound, dumping 11 million gallons of crude oil into the pristine Alaska waterway. ``The oil spill bill says safe transportation of oil is going to be part of the cost of doing business,'' said Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., the chairman of the House Interior subcommittee on offshore energy resources. He called the bill ``the first environmental salvo of the decade.'' ``It's not as strong as many of us would like to see it, but it's landmark legislation,'' said Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries subcommittee on the environment. Stephen Hart, deputy press secretary at the White House, said Bush has some reservations about the bill, but no veto recommendations. ``We have reservations because the protocols are not in the bill, and that the conference added the moratorium on North Carolina,'' said Hart. The protocols are a reference to an international treaty, not yet ratified by the United States, that would lessen liability. The bill puts a one-year moratorium on drilling off the coast of North Carolina until a study of possible effects can be completed. Miller and other lawmakers pushing for tougher liability laws said they hoped to pin more responsibility for spills on oil companies, instead of just the shippers. Miller was satisfied, however, that companies using irresponsible shippers would eventually have to pay, said a Miller aide. The bill also allows states to enact tougher laws. Lawmakers who have been trying for years to get a federal liability bill through Congress consider the legislation a major breakthrough that seemed to need a tragedy as devastating as the March 24, 1989, oil spill to become reality. ``Many of us are glad not to have to work on it again in another Congress,'' said Studds, whose efforts to strengthen oil spill laws go back to 1975. The Exxon Valdez spill, the worst in U.S. history, prompted demands for tougher federal requirements. Following the spill, the House and Senate each passed differing bills that took lengthy conference negotiations to reconcile. Major provisions in the legislation going to Bush include: _Liability by shippers for up to $1,200 per gross ton of the tanker, instead of the current ceiling of $150 per gross ton. _Creation of a $1 billion oil spill response and cleanup fund, with the money coming from a 5-cent-a-barrel fee on domestic and imported oil. _A requirement that all new tankers have double hulls and that most of the existing tankers be retrofitted with double hulls or taken out of service over the next 20 years. A small number of tankers will be given until 2015 to have double hulls. _Formation of regional response teams within the Coast Guard to deal with oil spills and a national response center where computers will hold lists of personnel and equipment that can be called upon after a major spill. _Increased research on oil pollution control. _A requirement that the government check driving records for alcohol-related offenses before issuing licenses to operate an oil tanker.

DOC.BYLINE: Will Late-July Sales Pace Continue? ^By FREDERICK STANDISH
DOC.TEXT: An unexpectedly strong late-July sales pace, especially for General Motors Corp. cars and trucks, may not be a true indication of the U.S. vehicle market, an economist says. The 10 major U.S. auto makers said Friday that sales of their cars and trucks rose 9.5 percent during the July 21-31 period this year compared with the same period last year. GM's sales rose a strong 15.8 percent over last year. ``This was a pleasant surprise, but I doubt it will last,'' said Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va. ``GM's sales increase is against a very weak year-ago period. The companies said their vehicles sold at an average daily rate of 43,978 compared with a rate of 40,147 over the same period in July 1989. Car sales rose 8.4 percent and truck sales increased 11.4 percent. GM was the only one of the Big Three automakers whose sales rose in late July. Ford Motor Co.'s sales fell 4.1 percent and Chrysler Corp.'s dropped 7.4 percent. ``Sales at Ford and Chrysler are more indicative of the market's direction,'' Webb said. Combined Big Three car sales rose a slim 0.6 percent while sales of Japanese-nameplate cars built in the United States rose 59.1 percent. For the entire month of July, with imported cars and trucks figured in, sales were running 6.2 percent below last year's rate, with car sales down 8.3 percent and trucks off 1.8 percent. Late last July, automakers were preparing to boost incentives to help dealers clear out inventories of new vehicles to get ready for the new model year cars and trucks. Despite the increase in late-July figures, car and truck sales this year continue to lag behind last year's pace. Through the first seven months of the year, domestic and overseas manufacturers reported a selling rate 4.1 percent behind last year. Car sales were down 4.6 percent and truck sales were off 3.1 percent. GM's combined sales of North American-built cars and trucks rose 15.8 percent during the period with strong showings in both categories. Car sales increased 14.8 percent and truck sales rose 17.7 percent. For the first seven months of the year, GM's cars and trucks sold at a pace 2.7 percent slower than last year. Ford said its late-July car and truck sales were down 4.1 percent. An 11.7-percent rise in truck sales, fueled by the new Explorer four-door sport-utility vehicle, was diluted by a 14.4-percent decline in car sales. Through the first seven months of this year, Ford's vehicle sales were 7.8 percent behind last year's pace. At Chrysler, an 11.5-percent drop in car sales combined with a 3.7-percent decline in truck sales for a 7.4-percent decrease overall. Through July this year, Chrysler's car and truck sales were 13.1 percent behind last year's pace.

DOC.HEAD: Superpowers Join to Stop Iraqi Invasion
DOC.TEXT: In the superpowers' first joint sanctions against a war, the United States and Soviet Union have urged a world embargo of weapons sales to Iraq and demanded that the Baghdad government pull its troops out of Kuwait. ``We have been assured that very soon the Iraqis will pull out their troops,'' Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze told a Friday news conference with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III at his side. He said the Soviets received the assurances through contacts in Baghdad. Later Friday an Iraqi government spokesman said Iraqi troops will begin withdrawing from Kuwait on Sunday, Baghdad Radio announced. Iraq claimed the decision was not because of international pressure. It was a historic case of the superpowers acting together to try to end hostilities. They worked together in seeking peace for Lebanon, but Friday's action is the first time they have tried together to strangle a war by cutting off trade with an attacker. They also cooperated during World War II, but before attaining superpower status. Both countries separately condemned the Iraqi invasion. But Baker noted superpower cooperation had made a joint stand ``natural.'' ``In earlier days, we might have been viewing this very tragic action through an East-West prism,'' Baker said. Shevardnadze spoke slowly and softly to reporters as he reviewed his country's decision to cut off arms shipments to its ally after the invasion began Thursday. The Kremlin and Baghdad have had a friendship treaty since 1972, and the Soviet Union is Iraq's major arms supplier. ``It wasn't easy to adopt such documents and make a joint statement because of our well-known good relations with Iraq which have been evolving for decades,'' Shevardnadze said. France said it already had suspended arms shipments to Iraq, citing payment problems with that Middle East nation. Italy and Poland have also cut arms deliveries to Iraq, and West Germany is discussing such a move. Neither Baker nor Shevardnadze said specifically what their nations might do if Iraq continues what their statement called ``brutal and illegal invasion'' and ``blatant transgression of the basic norms of civilized conduct.'' They spoke of continued concerted action in the U.N. Security Council. Shevardnadze said neither side was considering military intervention. But Baker, when asked about further actions against Iraq, said, ``I don't think that prudently you should rule out anything.'' China is also a major arms supplier to Iraq. Shevardnadze said the Soviets planned to urge the Chinese to stop supplies. Later, a senior State Department official speaking on Baker's flight from Moscow said the United States would do the same. Baker cut short a visit to neighboring Mongolia to fly to Moscow to meet with Shevardadze for the second time in a week and to make the joint statement. Baker then flew to Washington, winding up a four-nation Asian tour. Shevardnadze acknowledged that Baker earlier in the week had asked the Soviets to act to stave off the possibility of an invasion. ``I really did not think at that time that the Iraqis would so openly engage in aggression against such a defenseless country, a country that is a threat to no one,'' Shevardnadze said. He said the Soviet leadership sent a ``special'' message to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq on Thursday, but did not reveal the contents. Shevardnadze, referring to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's foreign policy, said the invasion ``contradicts the principles of new political thinking and the principles of civilized relations between nations.'' He warned Iraq about the safety of the 900 Soviets in Kuwait and the 7,000 to 8,000 in Iraq. ``We expect the security of Soviet citizens there to be safeguarded, otherwise there might be very, very severe consequences,'' he told reporters. Baker said similar consequences would result if any of the 3,000 Americans in Kuwait or an undetermined number of Americans in Iraq are endangered. Speaking on Baker's Air Force plane, the State Department official said the United States had privately warned Iraq before the invasion not to attack Kuwait. ``There was a general warning ... at several different levels, including very high levels,'' the official said on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Backs Voting-District Remapping to Redress LA County Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: A plan to remedy discrimination against Hispanics won the backing of a federal judge who has ordered local lawmakers to redraw the political map in the nation's most populous county. U.S. District Judge David V. Kenyon, ruling in a historic voting rights lawsuit Friday, supported a redistricting plan that creates a Hispanic majority district for the Board of Supervisors, the county's top elected officials. ``For the first time, the Hispanic community is going to be a meaningful part of the electorate in Los Angeles County,'' said attorney Mark Rosenbaum, who represented the American Civil Liberties Union in the suit. ``This means we can take down the `Hispanic Need Not Apply' sign.'' Kenyon ruled June 4 that the Board of Supervisors discriminated against Hispanics when redrawing district boundaries after the 1980 Census. Kenyon found the supervisors violated the federal Voting Rights Act and ordered the board to submit a new plan that would help a Hispanic win a seat. An estimated 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million residents are Hispanic, but the board has not had an elected Hispanic member in 115 years. Jose Roberto Juarez, an attorney for the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said Kenyon's decision sends a strong signal nationally to governments that will be redrawing voting boundaries on the basis of the 1990 Census results. ``The most important outcome of this lawsuit is the recognition that we are prepared to do battle for voting rights regardless of the size of the opponent,'' he said. Under the new plan, a supervisorial district held by a retiring conservative supervisor would be redrawn to give it a Hispanic majority. The other four districts would undergo minor adjustments that generally preserve voter bases of two liberal and two conservative supervisors. Kenyon's ruling came in the form of a request to the plaintiffs to draw a plan to his liking. The plaintiffs' plans already submitted generally conform to what the judge has asked for. Kenyon still must issue a formal order to implement the new plan. The ruling could change a decade-long 3-2 conservative majority with possible sweeping effects on such matters as health and social services funding. The decision also voids a June primary election and sets a special election for Nov. 6 for the new Hispanic majority district. That district had been held by conservative Supervisor Pete Schabarum, who is retiring. ``The board obviously disagrees with Judge Kenyon's ruling and our attorneys will file an appeal by Monday morning, seeking to stay his demand for a special primary election in the new 1st District,'' conservative Supervisor Deane Dana said in a statement. ``We expect the appeals court to rule on our request for a stay by Tuesday.'' With new district lines, Dana and fellow Supervisor Mike Antonovich face losing their conservative lock on the board. MALDEF, the ACLU and the U.S. Justice Department argued successfully that supervisors drew boundaries to protect their incumbencies. The county supervisors denied purposefully discriminating against Hispanics and said they did the best the could with the available census data. The board majority approved a redistricting proposal that this week was rejected by Kenyon as ``nonsensical'' and ``insensitive'' to Hispanic and black residents.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices Climbing After Iraqi Invasion, Price Gouging Alleged
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait already is costing U.S. motorists more at the gas pump. Some elected officials, service-station owners and motorists are accusing oil companies of price gouging. A survey of 1,400 retail gasoline stations nationwide showed self-serve unleaded gasoline prices increased 4 cents in two days, to an average of $1.11 a gallon, the American Automobile Association said Friday. Spot checks by AAA clubs in Florida, Michigan, Missouri, North Carolina, South Carolina and the Washington, D.C., area Friday showed retail prices shot up 4 to 14 cents a gallon, the association said. In Wisconsin, ``prices are just jumping up like crazy,'' sometimes increasing every 12 hours, said Robert Park, director of trade practices in the Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection. Increases as high as 10 cents a gallon were reported and further hikes were expected today, he said. Major oil companies increased wholesale prices, blaming surging energy markets. Prices for crude oil, gasoline and home heating oil futures rose for a second day Friday because of uncertainty about future Mideast supplies. Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., urged a federal investigation of the U.S. oil industry. ``There is absolutely no reason consumers should already be paying more for oil and gas,'' he said. ``It's either panic or profiteering. Either way it must be stopped.'' Dan Loepp, executive director of the Service Station Dealers Association of Michigan, agreed. ``The public has a right to know why these prices are rising so rapidly when the oil at the terminals was purchased weeks ago,'' he said. Motorists' reactions were varied. ``I really don't care, not when it comes to my car,'' said Casey Brittain, 28, of Shreveport, La. ``You've got to have it.'' ``Five cents isn't so bad,'' said Steven Binson, a teacher from Miami Beach, Fla. ``But 50 cents would be a cause for war.'' ``It's absolutely illegitimate,'' said Art Warsaw of East Peoria, Ill., who was filling up at a diesel pump. ``That stuff (higher-priced OPEC oil) hasn't hit the pipeline yet.'' Texaco raised prices as much as 7 cents a gallon; Chevron Corp. hiked its price 5 cents; BP America Inc. had a 4-cent to 5-cent increase; and Mobil Oil Corp. raised its prices an average of 3.5 cents a gallon. Other firms also had increases. Ed O'Brien, owner of two gasoline stations in Superior, Wis., said his price for unleaded gasoline rose from $1.14 a gallon to $1.23 per gallon Friday, and said an increase of another 6 cents per gallon was likely today. ``This is a big jump, probably the biggest I've seen,'' O'Brien said. Gas station operators said they were forced to pass higher costs on to consumers. ``We can't eat these kinds of increases. We'd be in terrible shape,'' said W. Terry Dennis, general manager at Woodfin Oil Co., which operates 20 service stations in Virginia. Oil is Iraq's most important revenue source, and Iraqi President Saddam nearly doubled his country's reserves by invading Kuwait early Thursday and taking control of that country's oil. Today, there was concern that Iraq might invade Saudi Arabia, which has the world's largest oil reserves and provides 15 percent of U.S. oil imports. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, climbed $1.38 to $24.49 a 42-gallon barrel Friday after rising $1.57 on Thursday. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for September delivery soared 4 cents to 72 cents a gallon, compounding a nearly 4-cent rise Thursday. The September contract for home heating oil picked up nearly 2 cents to close at 66 cents a gallon after a 3{-cent gain Thursday. Natural gas for September delivery rose to $1.51 per 1,000 cubic feet from Thursday's $1.43. Prices for other fuels also were up. In Reno, Nev., wholesale diesel prices have increased more than 10 cents a gallon since July 28, from 57 cents to nearly 68 cents Friday. Heating oil prices also rose. Tom Warren, owner of Warren Oil and Heating Co. in Chicago, said prices rose 18 cents a gallon since Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Injured, 500 Houses Destroyed In Kazakhstan Quake
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake has shaken eastern Soviet Kazakhstan, injuring eight people and destroying 500 homes, the official Tass news agency reported today. The earthquake struck at 1:15 p.m. (5:15 a.m.) Friday and was centered in the village of Akkol, 12 miles east of Lake Zaisan, Tass said. It registered six to seven on the Soviet 12-point scale. Tass did not give a Richter scale reading and the Soviet scale does not convert to the Richter scale. The earthquake was also felt in Alma Ata, the capital of Kazakhstan, the second largest Soviet republic geographically.

DOC.HEAD: University Zoologist: Depleted Ozone May be Killing Frogs
DOC.TEXT: Increased ultraviolet light streaming through the earth's depleted atmospheric ozone layer may be causing the mysterious deaths of toads, frogs and other amphibians reported in widely scattered areas of the world, an Oregon State University zoologist said. Cautioning that evidence remains circumstantial, Andrew Blaustein said Friday that ultraviolet radiation could explain the recent mass die-offs in two Cascade Range lakes in Oregon, and other declines in amphibian populations in the western United States, Costa Rica and Australia. He said tadpoles taken from the stricken Oregon lakes before the die-offs and reared away from direct sunlight in his laboratory developed normally, prompting the theory that UV light was to blame. ``If this is the problem, humans will be directly affected,'' Blaustein said in a telephone interview. ``They will also be greatly indirectly affected if it is starting to kill animal life. Amphibians are not the only ones to go.'' Blaustein, a professor of biology at the university in Corvallis, said the theory would be one of the main topics Tuesday at a meeting in New Orleans of scientists studying the recent declines in amphibian populations around the world. ``I am getting somewhat alarmed,'' Blaustein said, adding that many possible causes for the mass deaths had been ruled out. ``I would say people studying amphibians are somewhat alarmed by the possibility it could be increased UV.'' Scientists have blamed releases of chlorofluorocarbon gases, used as a coolant in refrigerators and air conditioners and as a propellant in aerosol cans, for widespread thinning of the ozone layer, which screens ultraviolet light from the sun. In the spring, Blaustein and other scientists discovered all the Western toad eggs had died in Lost Lake near Santiam Pass in the Cascade Range and all the frog tadpoles had disappeared from an unnamed lake nearby. Blaustein said research done at Oregon State University in 1975 by Robert Worrest showed toad eggs and tadpoles were very susceptible to increases in mid-range ultraviolet radiation. Jack Hardy, associate professor of environmental studies at Western Washington University in Bellingham, has found increased ultraviolet light reduced ocean plankton's ability to perform photosynthesis, the vital oxygen producing-process of plants. So-called middle range ultraviolet light, between 290 nanometers and 420 nanometers, reduces photosynthesis, causes genetic damage and skin cancer and could affect the growth of food crops and forests, Hardy said. ``I would not be surprised if it affects frog egg hatches,'' Hardy said. Research in Antarctica indicates that ultraviolet light is strongest in the springtime, when amphibians would be in their larval stage and most susceptible to damage from sunlight, he added. In the Northwest, scientists have noted the western spotted frog is no longer found in western Oregon and western Washington and breeding populations of the red-legged frog have disappeared from Oregon's Willamette Valley, Blaustein said. Up to 40 species of amphibians in Costa Rica are now endangered, and the golden toad has disappeared from a national park there. The red-legged frog, once the most common frog in California, has disappeared from the Central Valley and is declining elsewhere. The gastric-brooding frog can no longer be found in Australia.

DOC.HEAD: Borough Head Halts Development of Malcolm X Assassination Site
DOC.TEXT: Manhattan's borough president wielded obscure veto powers to halt development on the site where Malcolm X was assassinated, a Harlem ballroom she fought to preserve as a historical landmark. Ruth Messinger led the battle to save the Audubon Ballroom, but said her veto Friday of an $8.1 million allocation for the proposed $34 million medical research laboratory project was purely a business decision. The project already was $9 million over budget, Messinger said in a letter to the Port Authority, which was to have provided the $8.1 million she challenged with the little used-veto power afforded her office by state law. The deal to build the biomedical research lab also was too speculative and only promised 300 new jobs initially, she said. The city, state and Columbia University planned to share construction costs. Messinger left the door open for a compromise to save the lab project and preserve the ballroom where the famed black Muslim leader was shot in 1965. ``Nothing bars a new submission from the mayor's office,'' she wrote in the letter. Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch said the veto effectively halted the project. Messinger is a longtime ally of Mayor David Dinkins but crossed swords with him over the Audubon Ballroom. The mayor recently agreed to a compromise plan that would have preserved 40 percent of the ballroom, which has a distinctive terra cotta facade. But Messinger and other preservationists favored a plan backed by the Municipal Art Society to keep the ballroom intact and build the lab on a different corner of the block. City officials say that plan would push the project back into the approval process.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``When you look at vital interests of the United States, the relationship with Saudi Arabia and its independence and its freedom come under the heading of very, very important.'' _ President Bush on whether he is committed to defending the Saudis.

``Baseball is the American pastime ... It's pretty fun to play. I just couldn't believe anybody had to act like that to play baseball.'' _ Catcher John Hills, 15, son of a coach whose nose and several ribs were broken after he was pummeled with a bat during an all-star game by a rival coach.

``There is absolutely no reason consumers should already be paying more for oil and gas ... It's either panic or profiteering. Either way it must be stopped.'' _ Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., urging a federal investigation of the U.S. oil industry after two days of steep hikes in gasoline prices at the pump in the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Police Chief Relieved of Duty
DOC.TEXT: Dallas Police Chief Mack Vines and his deputy have been relieved from duty while prosecutors examine allegations of witness tampering and perjury during an investigation into a police officer's firing. City Manager Jan Hart said Friday that Vines and Assistant Chief Greg Holliday were placed on indefinite leave. The Dallas County district attorney's office was looking into the allegations, she said. Vines has been police chief since Billy Prince retired in April 1988 amid a controversy over police-minority relations. Ms. Hart said a panel reviewing the case of former Officer Patrick LeMaire, fired after fatally shooting an unarmed Mexican, found ``potential witness tampering and perjury'' by Vines and Holliday. The panel's findings were reportedly related to an alleged conversation Vines had with Holliday before Holliday testified in front of the panel this week. The panel apparently believes that Vines tried to get Holliday to change his testimony. ``This is a very serious matter,'' Ms. Hart said. ``It involves the integrity of the department and public confidence in the department.'' Assistant Chief Willard Rollins will run the department in their absence, she said. The Dallas Police Association, which represents 2,000 of the department's 2,400 members, called for Vines' immediate resignation. A report by the panel made public Friday said it believed ``there was a deliberate attempt by one or more individuals to subvert'' its findings. ``This conduct we believe was blatantly unethical and resulted in possible perjury testimony,'' the report said. The actions of Vines, Holliday and other top police officials have been under scrutiny since LeMaire was fired a year ago. LeMaire shot the Mexican while searching for car theft suspects and was fired for failing to find alternatives to using deadly force. When questioned about the conversation, Vines allegedly told the panel that it had been misinterpreted. Vines has denied any wrongdoing, saying he reserves the right to request more information, redirect investigators or set aside procedures in any inquiry.

DOC.HEAD: Replicas Begin Spanish Tour Before Retracing Columbus' Route
DOC.TEXT: Replicas of the ships that accompanied Christopher Columbus on his Atlantic crossing have set sail, but this time in search of tourist dollars instead of precious metals and spices. The Nina, Pinta and Santa Maria on Friday began their six-month voyage to a dozen Spanish ports to prepare for a 1992 re-enactment of Columbus' trip to the New World. The ships have a total of 90 crew members and all but the commander, a Spanish navy captain, will sleep outdoors, as Columbus' crew did on the voyage to America. Like Columbus, Capt. Santiago Bolivar will lead from the deck of the Santa Maria, the flagship. ``The objective of the 1992 voyage will be to study in action the navigation methods of the 15th century and the effectiveness of Columbus' sailing methods,'' Bolivar, 40, told reporters. The 15th century Spanish royalty bankrolled Columbus. Today's government spent $2 million to build the three replica ships from Galician pine and oak from the Pyrenees. They sailed from this southern port _ 310 miles southwest of Madrid _ 498 years to the day of Columbus' first voyage to the New World. The head of the government company planning the 1992 celebrations, Luis Yanez, saw them off and laid a wreath at a monument to Columbus. Yanez said the ships were built to help promote the Expo '92 World's Fair in the southern city of Seville. Expo '92 is expected to attract 20 million visitors to Seville from April to October 1992. ``An Expo such as this one is a unique occasion to launch a country's image around the world,'' the exposition's commissioner, Manuel Olivencia, has said. At least 105 countries and 20 international organizations have signed commitments to build pavilions in Seville to display their newest technologies and designs. The ships aren't the only promotion for Expo '92. A promotional quiz game that cost $707,000 to develop is to begin running soon in Spanish newspapers to familiarize Spaniards with the discoveries of the past 500 years. The government is also pumping an estimated $1 billion into Expo '92 to modernize Seville's public works communications systems and $6 billion into the rest of the southern region of Andalusia. The ships are a particular point of pride. Last year, Queen Sofia christened the single-decked 117-foot-long Santa Maria. Her daughter, Princess Elena, christened the Nina and Princess Cristina the Pinta. The two smaller caravelles are 50 feet long. While the sailors will attempt to follow the exact sailing methods of Columbus, the ships are equipped with sophisticated equipment to navigate via satellite and carry modern-day lighting. For protection, a navy frigate will escort them.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Needs Opposition for New Election Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl says a proposal for early elections and unification is the will of the German people, but he may need the will of the opposition for his wish to become reality. In a statement from his vacation retreat in Austria, Kohl welcomed East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's call Friday for all-German elections on Oct. 14, six weeks earlier than planned. ``The proposal corresponds with the wishes of the people in East Germany and also in West Germany,'' Kohl said. De Maiziere said Friday that unification would be formally declared the day before the election. He said said the Volkskammer, East Germany's parliament, could meet in a special session the day before the vote and make that decision. Kohl supports that idea. But the opposition Social Democrats were quick to criticize the deal Kohl and de Maiziere reportedly reached in a late night talk at Kohl's vacation house earlier this week. The Social Democrats' candidate for chancellor, Oskar Lafontaine, called the proposal ``transparent manipulation'' and said, ``this date-shifting carries panicky consequences.'' The environmentalist Greens called it ``a bad day for Germany.'' The Germanys are working on finalizing a unification treaty that lays out the legal unification of the two states. They merged their economies on July 1. It has been East Germany's crumbling economy, lurching from communism to capitalism, that has spurred the push for early unification. ``I think this is the right way,'' Kohl's chief of staff Rudolf Seiters was quoted as saying in today's mass-circulation Bild newspaper. ``Only a strong unified German government is in the best position to master the problems in East Germany.'' Kohl, in his statement, said the proposal ``corresponds to the evaluation of people in both parts of Germany, that a quicker unification process reduces difficulties and financial expenditures.'' On Thursday, representatives of the Germanys agreed on an election treaty setting the conditions for the balloting. Parties in both countries had previously agreed on Dec. 2 as the election date. Under West Germany's constitution, the country must elect a new Bundestag, the law-making lower house of parliament, between Nov. 18 and Jan. 18. For an earlier election, West German lawmakers could try to dissolve the Bundestag through a majority vote of no-confidence for the chancellor, using an article of the constitution as an emergency exit and not for its intended purpose. Kohl's governing coalition has a simple majority. Lawmakers could also, by a two-thirds vote in the Bundestag, vote to change the constitution to allow earlier elections. Kohl's governing coalition of Christian Democratic Union, Christian Social Union and Free Democrats has a combined 282 seats in the Bundestag. But it would need 346 for a two-thirds majority of the 519-member chamber. The Social Democrats have 193 members in the Bundestag. De Maiziere told a news conference in East Berlin that the all-German vote should coincide with East German elections that will create five state governments to mirror West Germany's federal system. Under Bonn's constitution, those states could immediately seek unity with West Germany. The Bundestag meets next week to vote on ratification of the election treaty. Kohl said that special session would also discuss the latest proposal for German unification.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors of Ship Destroyed By Hurricane Bertha Arrive in Maine
DOC.TEXT: Merchant sailors who bobbed in 30-foot seas after Hurricane Bertha splintered their cargo ship stepped ashore with praise for their Soviet rescuers and acceptance of the ocean's fury. Rolando Arellano, an apprentice officer from Manila, Philippines, said Friday he would resume his oceangoing life and vowed not to give in to fear. ``No _ this is life at sea,'' Arellano said. Twenty-one survivors of the wrecked freighter Corazon were brought ashore by a Soviet fishing support ship that plucked them from churning seas in the Atlantic about 400 miles east of New York. Six crew members, including most of the ship's officers, died in the wreck Tuesday. ``What made the whole operation complicated was the wind and the height of the waves, as well as the rainstorms, very little visibility,'' said Capt. Vladimir Pushnoy, skipper of the Soviet ship M-V Leonid Leonidov, speaking through an interpreter at a news conference. One man spent about 10 hours in the water before he was hauled to safety, Pushnoy said. The survivors were mostly Greek or Filipino sailors aboard the 593-foot freighter hauling tons of cement from Greece to New York. ``We are very lucky,'' said ship's cook Pantelis Potiris, of Athens, Greece. ``It was very bad, very rough.'' Arellano said he spent about five hours floating in the water after his life raft capsized. ``I hope only to stay alive,'' Arellano said. ``I always pray to God. We are thinking of our family and to save ourselves.'' Many survivors had only life jackets for flotation, and the yellow vests were hard to see amid the foam and spray of the rough water, Pushnoy said. After the Corazon sent a distress signal Tuesday afternoon, the U.S. and Canadian coast guards provided information to help the Leonid Leonidov and several other ships find the survivors. Two other ships in the area got close to Corazon crew members but couldn't get them aboard. Pushnoy said his ship was able to pull off the rescue because his 46-member crew is used to working on the open sea and tying up with other vessels under adverse conditions. Survivors from the Corazon hugged their rescuers after the rusty Soviet ship pulled into port. ``The Russians are good,'' said one survivor, giving a thumbs-up sign.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Sources Doubt That Kuwait Terrorists Freed
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait puts Saddam Hussein in control of 15 jailed pro-Iranian terrorists whose freedom is demanded by factions holding Western hostages in Lebanon. Shiite Moslem sources, familiar with the case of the 16 Western captives, say Saddam's control of the 15 terrorists held in Kuwaiti jails gives the Iraqi leader a role in the hostage issue. Seventeen terrorists were convicted by the Kuwaiti authorities in connection with the 1983 bombings of the U.S. and French embassies and other targets in the tiny oil-rich desert state. Two of them were released after completing their prison term. That left 15, two of whom have been sentenced to death but the sentence was never carried out. Freedom for the terrorists, some of whom belong to the Iraqi Al-Dawa Shiite fundamentalist group that has been working for Saddam's overthrow, has been a key demand by captors of American hostages. Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, which has demanded the release of the convicts in Kuwait, holds two Americans _ journalist Terry Anderson and educator Thomas Sutherland. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held foreign captive in Lebanon. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Kuwait refused to release the convicted terrorists and the United States has refused to pressure Kuwait into succumbing to the kidnappers' demands. One Shiite source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Saddam's control of the 15 prisoners ``gives him a window open on the hostage issue.'' The American ABC television network reported Friday the 15 were ``all free'' after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``Does this affect the fate of the American hostages? We don't even know who freed the Kuwait prisoners,'' the ABC announcer said. The Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, which is believed to be the umbrella for the hostage-holding factions, withheld comment on the ABC report. ``No comment is our answer,'' said the head of Hezbollah's information department, known only as Abu Hawraa. He refused to elaborate. The Shiite source, commenting on the release report, said: ``I think it's far-fetched. The Kuwaitis were not in a position to free them before their country fell to the Iraqis.'' ``I would swallow it if I heard that they were moved to baghdad. Saddam is not likely to release them free of charge, that is if he releases them at all,'' the source said. ``I believe that if he controlled them, Saddam would use the prisoners to curb the West's moves against him for invading Kuwait,'' the source added. One scenario, speculated upon by the Shiite source, would be for Saddam to ``offer to swap the 15 for the Western captives in Lebanon.'' ``Such a move by Saddam would embarrass the West, but would Syria permit such a swap? I doubt it,'' he said, Syria, Iraq's main Arab foe, has 40,000 troops deployed in predominantly Moslem regions of Lebanon and all previous hostage releases have been carried out with Syria's help or approval. The foreign captives currently missing in Lebanon, in addition to Anderson and Sutherland, are four Americans, four Britons, two Swiss, two West Germans, an Italian and an Irishman.

DOC.HEAD: Five Slightly Injured in Plane Evacuation After Bomb Hoax
DOC.TEXT: A hoax bomb threat prompted the hurried evacuation of a Delta Airlines jet and 15 passengers sliding down emergency chutes suffered minor scrapes, bumps and sprains, an airline official said. Delta Flight 748 landed safely Friday afternoon at its scheduled stop, Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, about 10 minutes after a telephoned bomb threat was received at the Delta reservations desk at Los Angeles International Airport, said airline spokesman Joe Licitra. There were 230 passengers and 11 crew members aboard the flight that originated in Los Angeles. Those hurt were treated and released for minor injuries at local hospitals, Licitra said. Bomb-sniffing dogs found no explosives on the Boeing 767, Licitra said, adding that the plane returned to service later that evening.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Scattered in South; Showers in Indiana
DOC.TEXT: Early morning rain and thunderstorms hit parts of Missouri, Florida and Oklahoma today, while light showers fell in Indiana. Elsewhere in the nation, weather was mostly dry. Many areas had temperatures in the 70s before dawn, with Las Vegas registering 86 degrees and Phoenix 84 degrees as mid-summer heat was expected to rise nationwide throughout the day. Thunderstorms roamed across central Oklahoma and at St. Louis. There was a light rain in Indianapolis and thunderstorms were over the tip of Florida at Key West. Today's forecast called for showers and thunderstorms to fall in southern Illinois and western Ohio as a cold front pushes across the Great Lakes region into the Ohio Valley. Across the southern end of the front, rain and thunderstorms are expected to develop in the Texas panhandle, southern Oklahoma and northern Arkansas. Scattered thunderstorms are likely in the afternoon and evening along the eastern Rockies, but the remainder of the West was to have dry weather with temperatures soaring into the 100s in California and Oregon. The Eastern seaboard, Southeast and southern Plains were expected to bask in dry and sunny weather, and temperatures were to be above normal in the Northeast. A few thunderstorms were considered likely to form over the Applachians. DOC.HEAD: North Sea Oil Workers Stage Sit-in Over Safety Concerns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: FIXES typo in 1st graf.
DOC.TEXT: About 1,300 North Sea oil workers protesting allegedly lax safety procedures have staged a sit-in at their offshore platforms, officials said. The sit-in began Friday and affects eight oil platforms and three floating accommodation units. It follows a 24-hour wildcat strike Thursday by 4,000 North Sea oil workers at 40 offshore installations. Ronni McDonald, a spokesman for the Offshore Industry Liaison Committee, the unofficial council representing the main oil industry unions, said the sit-in affected Shell U.K. and British Petroleum installations.
