Tribble drove off, rammed two police vehicles blocking his escape, drove back to the hotel and fled into a wooded area, said Prince George's County, Md., police. In a brief court session on an unrelated matter, Barry's chief lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy said he ``wants a representation on the record'' that the jurors weren't aware of the incident operation. Judge Jackson agreed and said ``I was assured'' by the U.S. Marshals Service, which provides court security, that ``our jurors were oblivious'' to the sting. Mundy pointed out that someone would have had to ask them a question about the sting to ensure the jurors were unaware of it. ``They may have been aware there was a commotion,'' said Jackson, who then agreed to include such an assurance in the court record. One of the cocaine possession charges Barry faces stems from his Jan. 18 arrest in an FBI sting operation at a downtown Washington hotel. After speaking to the teen-agers at the youth forum, Barry met with top staff members and cabinet officials in his office. It was the first time the mayor had visited city hall without having to rush back to the federal courthouse since jury selection in his trial began June 4. Barry was tried on 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor conspiracy count and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his drug use. After closing arguments in the case Thursday, he predicted he would be acquitted completely. The jury on Friday asked for complete sets of the 32-page instruction booklet read Thursday by Jackson, and later asked to look at a chart listing the month and year that government witnesses have testified that they used drugs with Barry. The panel also requested a copy of a form in which one witness agreed to cooperate with the government.

DOC.HEAD: Zoo Expansion Draws Opposition From Advocates for Poor
LaserPhoto KX1
DOC.TEXT: Voters will decide Tuesday whether to add $10 a year to the average property tax bill to put the big cats, apes and other animals at the city zoo into better housing. Opponents say the money would be better spent on people. Friends of the Kansas City Zoo want to double the zoo's size, providing large, open habitats that would allow animals to roam together as they do in the wild. They say the zoo is substandard and needs renovating to ensure better care for the animals. They also say the plan would help with sagging attendance. Critics, particularly some black groups, say the tax money is needed to combat more immediate problems like drugs, crime, substandard housing and lack of health care for the poor. Opponents also say higher-income taxpayers in the suburbs should pay for zoo improvements they will enjoy as much as the people of Kansas City. The $50 million bond issue to finance the proposal will require 57 percent of the votes cast Tuesday, and both sides are predicting a close election. ``It's just a low priority right now, especially when you're talking about public funds,'' said the Rev. Nelson Thompson of the Black Agenda Group. ``We feel it's an undue burden; it's an untimely proposition.'' Opponents also say the expansion would displace popular gathering areas in Swope Park, one of the largest municipal parks in the country. The planners ``didn't sit down with the various neighborhood residents,'' Thompson said. ``It appears as though we have an adversarial role, but actually if we were consulted before the fact, then we wouldn't have come out against the plan the way we have.'' Some critics say it's the wrong time to add to city tax bills. Residents of the school district soon are likely to pay a property tax increase for teacher salaries. That tax hike has been approved by a federal judge in the city's school desegregation case and awaits action by the school board. The zoo bonds would add about $10 a year to the average Kansas City homeowner's property tax bill. ``The current zoo is not a distinguished one,'' said Albert P. Mauro, president of Friends of the Zoo, a non-profit booster group. ``It's just on the border of meeting its regulatory requirements. It's close to having to spend a lot of money just to stay open.'' The bond issue would provide the money needed to double the 81-year-old zoo to 160 acres and increase the number of species from 168 to 263. The plan calls for completing the expansion by 1994. New African and Australian exhibits would let several species interact as they do in their natural habitats. The 90-acre African section envisions safari-like tram, canoe and Land Rover rides overlooking forest, grassland and water habitats. ``The visitors will suspend their disbelief,'' said Bob Berkebile, main architect of the master plan. ``They will think they are in Africa even though they know they are not.'' Planners want to boost educational functions of the zoo with a start-to-finish theme of conservation. An entrance pavilion would acquaint visitors with animals they are about to see. An exit pavilion would teach viewers what steps humans can take to save endangered creatures. ``Our assumption is, unless we change our actions, we humans will be the next endangered species,'' Berkebile said. ``We believe we are immersing the visitor in a complete experience.''

DOC.HEAD: Impact from Iraqi Action Could Be Widespread
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's conquest of Kuwait is expected to produce political realignments in much of the Arab world, reinforce U.S. ties with Israel and threaten the economies of oil-poor countries far removed from the Persian Gulf, experts say. While the full impact of the Iraqi action is difficult to measure, there was almost unanimous agreement that the events of this past week probably have made an Arab-Israeli accommodation more remote than at any time in the past generation. They also have raised the possibility at least that two Iraqi foes in the region, Syria and Iran, could be encouraged to seek more cooperative relationships with the United States and other Western countries. Both appear to have few other options. Three days after the invasion, the political fallout was uncertain, partly because no one is quite sure what Iraq meant on Friday when it said the invading force will be withdrawn beginning Sunday. The main concern in the United States is Saudi Arabia and whether Iraq, either through force or intimidation, will attempt to impose its will on that strategic Gulf state. President Bush has declared Saudi Arabia a ``vital interest'' for the United States and warned that he would not acquiesce in an Iraqi takeover of the Kingdom. Under some worst case projections, Iraqi domination of the OPEC oil cartel could shoot prices from the present $24.50 into the $40-plus range, wreaking havoc in oil importing countries everywhere, especially the Third World. These were the countries which suffered the greatest hardship from OPEC price increases in the 1970s. Alternatively, Bush has said that sharp curtailment of supplies would have a ``devastating effect'' on the free world. The Iraqi invasion occurred at a time of widespread complacency in international relations, an attitude spawned by the success of the United States and the Soviet Union in easing tensions after more than 40 years of high stakes rivalry. The Brookings Institute's Judith Kipper believes the Soviet-American accommodation actually enhances the possibility for regional flareups such as the one in the Gulf. ``This is the first post-Cold War crisis,'' she said. ``With the end of East-West competition, little countries can act with impunity.'' While many experts consider Iraqi domination of Arab politics _ especially oil politics _ likely, Leonard Spector of the Carnegie Endowment believes that outcome can be avoided. A combination of economic and military pressure by the West and by Gulf countries might be enough to tame President Saddam Hussein's ambitions, Spector said. ``Right now he looks unstoppable,'' Spector said. ``He could be stoppable in 10 days. Each country pursuing its interests individually could restore the power balance.'' Saddam would appear to be most vulnerable to a show of Western military power, widespread international adherence to an embargo of Iraqi oil, loss of access to oil pipelines through neighboring Turkey and Saudi Arabia and to Soviet military spare parts. The Soviets have been Iraq's main military supplier but announced a cutoff Thursday after the invasion. Bush said Friday that the possibility of Turkey closing the Iraqi pipeline ``will be an option, I'm certain.'' Without decisive action, Saddam almost certainly will be able to call the shots in the Gulf. ``I think if everybody trembles and fall, then obviously he's going to move on,'' said Shireen Hunter of the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Gary Sick, a former National Security Council aide, warned that Saddam, left unchecked, could become the ``ultimate arbiter'' of OPEC policy, able almost singlehandedly to determine supply and price levels. There was broad agreement among the experts that the Gulf crisis will have a salutary effect on U.S.-Israeli relations, which had been suffering as a result of U.S. accusations of Israeli intransigence concerning the peace process. Even before the events of last week in the Gulf, Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat had been shifting allegiances from Egypt to Iraq, a switch that was hardly reassuring to Israel. ``Arafat left America's best friend for America's worst enemy,'' said Barry Rubin of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. Rubin noted that Iraq has been allied for some time with Abul Abbas, head of a Palestinian faction which claimed responsibility for an abortive attack on an Israeli beach two months ago. Against this background, Rubin said that the PLO is not going to do what is necessary to resume its dialogue with the United States, which President Bush suspended six weeks ago.

DOC.HEAD: US, Soviets Cut Deal, Make History
DOC.TEXT: When Dennis Ross, a top State Department policy maker, accepted an invitation to spend a few days at a Soviet dacha discussing the future of the world, nobody paid much attention. It was supposed to be a quiet time, a little vodka and a lot of talk. Then Iraq invaded Kuwait, and Ross and his Soviet counterparts helped make history. On Friday, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze issued a joint statement, prepared by Ross and Soviet officials, condemning Iraq's invasion and calling for an international arms embargo on Baghdad. For the first time since World War II, the superpowers acted as allies when confronted with a war. Moscow assented to Washington's request it cut weapons deliveries to Iraq. For the Soviets, the decision to join the Americans was a difficult one because of decades of close ties with Iraq. Moscow has a treaty of friendship with Iraq and is its biggest arms supplier. But, as Shevardnadze said during a hastily called news conference with Baker at a military airbase outside Moscow on Friday, ``this aggression is inconsistent with the principles of new political thinking.'' Perhaps more significantly, State Department officials said the Soviet Union put no restrictions on any U.S. response to the crisis. The genesis of the statement reads like a case study of ``new political thinking,'' Shevardnadze's buzzword for the changing relationship between Moscow and Washington. American officials who participated in the whirlwind talks, telephone calls and abruptly changed plans used words such as ``extraordinary'' and ``milestone'' to describe the negotiations with their longtime foes. Here is a day-by-day account of those talks: Wednesday _ A half-moon glimmered overhead when Baker stepped off his Air Force plane in the Soviet city of Irkutsk at 2:30 a.m. for talks with Shevardnadze. The talks in ``the Paris of Siberia'' were expected to focus on the 12-year-old civil war in Afghanistan and arms control. But in the first session Baker asked Shevardnadze to pressure Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein to withdraw troops massed on Kuwait's borders. Shevardnadze declined. Later, the foreign minister, in a remarkable step, admitted the response had been wrong. ``I really did not think at that time that the Iraqis would so openly engage in aggression against such a defenseless country,'' Shevardnadze said. Thursday morning _ Lt. Gen. Howard Graves, an aide accompanying Baker, tells the secretary that Iraq has invaded Kuwait. Baker informs Shevardnadze and requests the Soviets to cease arms supplies to Iraq. Thursday _ At 1:30 p.m. Baker's jet touched down in Ulan Bator, Mongolia, making him the first top American official to visit this vast, land-locked nation in 46 years. But events in the Middle East overshadowed his trip. In Moscow, the Soviet Union condemned the invasion and stopped arms deliveries to Iraq. Enter Dennis Ross. After the Irkutsk talks with Shevardnadze, Ross went to Moscow with Shevardnadze's men for what were originally planned as broad discussions on the next two years. In a dacha outside Moscow, the Americans raised the idea with Soviet officials of a joint statement. ``There was a fair amount of discussion about the consequences of allowing naked aggression to go unchallenged,'' said a senior State Department official. ``If you allow someone to engage in this kind of action and get away with it, you're going to invite more.'' Back in Ulan Bator, Baker gamely watched Mongolian wrestling and archery competitions, as the crisis unfurled. Lt. Gen. Graves kept him posted. ``We've got more phone lines out of Mongolia than the Mongolians,'' Graves quipped as scantily clad Mongolian wrestlers grappled with each other on a grassy plain outside Ulan Bator. At 8 p.m., Baker received a call from President Bush, who was interested in the joint statement. At a banquet that night, Baker toasted Mongolia's moves toward democracy, then announced he cut short his trip. ``It is with a very heavy heart,'' he said. The Texan had planned a two-day hunting trip on the Gobi Desert. In Moscow, Ross and his Soviet colleagues thrashed out details of the statement. An international arms embargo was agreed on. State Department officials declined to say whether there were any disagreements but they said the Soviets did not make Washington rule out any option against Iraq. Friday, 1:45 a.m. _ Bush, flying on Air Force One to Colorado, called Baker again and approved the statement. ``Wake up and get a pencil,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler told one reporter at 3 a.m. ``We're going back to Moscow.'' Friday, 7:30 p.m. at Moscow's Vukunovo II military airport _ ``This has been a rather unusual meeting,'' Shevardnadze said of his just concluded talk with Baker. Then the two men read the statement, each in his native tongue.

DOC.HEAD: Abu Nidal Follower Killed
DOC.TEXT: Two gunmen armed with silencer-equipped pistols on Saturday killed an official of terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal's Palestinian faction in a southern Lebanon refugee camp, police said. A police spokesman said the gunmen shot Abdul Fattah Aziz, known by the code-name Kifah Ghalib, shortly after midnight at the Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp. ``Aziz was hit in the chest and neck. Death was instantaneous,'' said the spokesman, who cannot be named in line with police regulations. Abu Nidal, whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, broke away from Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization in 1973 and set up the Fatah-Revolutionary Council. It has bases in Iraq, Syria, Libya and Lebanon. Last month Arafat's guerrillas routed Abu Nidal's followers at the Rashidiyeh refugee camp. Five guerrillas allied with Abu Nidal's were killed, 16 wounded and 40 taken prisoner in the fighting. A U.S. State Department report last year described Abu Nidal as the world's most dangerous terrorist. It blamed his hirelings for 34 terrorist attacks in 20 countries since 1973. At least 900 people were killed or wounded in these attacks, the report said. The atrocities included the December 1985 attacks on Rome and Vienna airports that killed more than 20 people. Nidal's group was torn by a bloody internal feud in late 1989 in which some 200 dissidents were slain. The group's strength is now estimated to be less than 100.

DOC.HEAD: House Campaign Finance Bill Survives Vote
DOC.TEXT: Campaign finance reformers are looking to congressional leaders and the Bush administration to begin serious negotiations on cleaning up future elections when Congress returns in September. The House kept the issue alive by voting 255-155 late Friday night for a highly partisan Democratic bill that even many of its supporters acknowledged privately stands no chance of becoming law. President Bush has vowed to veto any bill that imposes absolute spending ceilings on congressional candidates _ as both the House and Senate versions do _ and that doesn't curb labor and business PACs' rapidly escalating role in politics. Democrats in the Senate bowed to Bush's call to ban special interest political action committees entirely even though lawmakers in both parties acknowledge that the Supreme Court is likely to rule it an unconstitutional prohibition on free speech. House Democrats sought only to curb what they called ``fat cat'' corporate executive PACs, cutting the amount they can contribute to each candidate for combined primary and November election campaigns to $2,000 while leaving the current lid of $10,000 on such gifts for union PACs. Although reform groups such as Common Cause had called the House Democratic bill a ``sham'' and ``fraud,'' they urged lawmakers to hold their nose and pass it before Congress went on vacation Saturday to prevent the issue from dying. ``It's part of the process that you have to work your way through to go to the next step of the process,'' said Common Cause President Fred Wertheimer. ``The House must not block the Senate's efforts to clean up its own campaign finance system.'' League of Women Voters President Susan Lederman said the House version ``is dangerously close to being an incumbent protection bill rather than a campaign reform bill.'' ``At least the House action keeps the legislative process alive,'' she said. The House bill would establish a $715,000 ceiling on how much candidates could spend on their primary and general elections combined. Originally it would have provided a ceiling of $550,000. But the bill's authors modified it Thursday night, weakening several other provisions in the process, after several disgruntled Democrats complained privately the original version would have crippled their re-election bids in 1992. Also removed from the package, Republicans said, were criminal penalties on candidates who overspend the limits and prohibitions on lobbyists doubling as fundraisers. A Republican alternative with no spending ceilings cutting allowable contributions from special interest political action committees and banning so-called leadership PACs involved in recent House ethics scandals was rejected earlier by a 241-169 vote. Also rejected, by 128-122, was a proposal by Reps. Mike Synar, D-Okla., and David Obey, D-Wis., that would have provided up to $100,000 in public financing matching funds to candidates who raise an equal amount in contributions of $50 or less from in-state residents. Obey and Synar also would have limited candidates to getting no more than 40 percent of the proposed ceiling from PACs, compared to a 50 percent lid on PAC contributions from the Democratic bill by Rep. Al Swift, D-Wash., that was passed. They would have financed the public matching funds by raising from $1 to $3 the current voluntary checkoff for presidential elections on individual income tax returns. Republicans overwhelmingly voted ``present'' on the amendment, which had been approved earlier on a voice vote but was brought up again after Democratic leaders feared it would kill the bill. Swift's bill had no public financing but it would allow a 100 percent tax credit up to $50 to encourage small contributions.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Forces Reportedly Mass on Saudi Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th pvs, `Shipping sources...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with Lloyd's unable to confirm that U.S. ship seized in the gulf, also saying the Sea Wolf is not in the gulf at the moment. Pickup 6th, `U.S. officials...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,5, FRA1, AMM1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today it was creating a new Kuwaiti army to prop up the government it installed in Kuwait. U.S. reports that Baghdad has massed troops on the Saudi border prompted fears the invasion could spread. On Friday, a government communique read on Baghdad radio had said Iraqi forces would start withdrawing from Kuwait in two days ``unless something appears that could threaten the security of Kuwait and Iraq.'' But the White House expressed skepticism that Iraq would pull out. President Saddam Hussein faced mounting international pressure to withdraw from Kuwait. U.S. warships headed toward the Persian Gulf, Arab leaders sought a diplomatic solution, and many countries moved to isolate Iraq economically. In other developments: _Shipping sources in the Persian Gulf said Iraqi troops today seized the 20-man American crew of the tanker Sea Wolf docked at Kuwait's main port, removed the men from the vessel, and took them to an undisclosed location. But Lloyd's Shipping Intelligence Unit in London said it could not confirm a U.S. ship had been seized and did not believe the Sea Wolf was even in the gulf. U.S. officials are already seeking information on 14 Americans, mostly oil workers, missing in Kuwait who apparently were seized by Iraqi forces to help keep oil installations running. About 3,000 Americans live in Kuwait. _Iraqi soldiers took 35 British servicemen acting as advisers to Kuwaiti forces from their homes in Kuwait on Friday night and early today, the British Ministry of Defense said in London. Their fate was not known. _Jordanian officials said an emergency Arab summit scheduled in Saudi Arabia on Sunday to discuss Iraq's invasion was postponed due to a dispute between Saudi Arabia and Iraq over whether Kuwait should be represented at the meeting by its ousted rulers, who have taken refuge in Saudi Arabia. _In Rome, the 12 nations of the European Community voted today to impose a total embargo on imports of oil from Iraq and Kuwait in response to Baghdad's invasion of its oil-rich neighbor, an Italian official said. _Kuwaiti diplomatic sources who contacted Kuwaiti residents by telephone, said Iraqi tanks and armor had begun to withdraw from downtown Kuwait city. No further details were available. _There was no indication that Saudi Arabia and Turkey were prepared to close pipelines in their countries that carry Iraqi oil to the Red Sea and the Mediterranean. The pipelines constitute Iraq's major oil export outlets. Baghdad radio today broadcast a communique from the ``provisional government of free Kuwait'' announcing creation of an army that would accept all Arab nationals ``who wish stability for Kuwait in its new age.'' Iraqi television said more than 100,000 Iraqis had volunteered to serve. The U.S. State Department said parts of the Iraqi invasion force had pushed to within five to 10 miles of the southern Kuwaiti border with Saudi Arabia. The possibility of an Iraqi thrust into Saudi Arabia worried members of Congress. Lawmakers attending secret briefings on the crisis said 120,000 Iraqi troops massed along their southern border could easily attack the Saudis next. But a high-ranking Saudi official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said today that no Iraqi troops had entered Saudi Arabia. President Bush on Friday warned Iraq that attacking Saudi Arabia, with the world's largest oil reserves, would be attacking American ``vital interests.'' Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council led by Saddam said it planned to begin a withdrawal Sunday, but not in reaction to Arab or superpower demands. ``We refuse to respond to empty chatter,'' the ruling council said in a statement on official Baghdad radio. An Iraqi government spokesman warned that if anyone took action against Iraqi forces, Iraq would ``chop off his arm from the shoulder.'' Iraq did not say how many of the estimated 100,000 troops it originally sent into Kuwait would pull back or how long the withdrawal would take, leaving the door open for Saddam to keep forces in Kuwait for some time, according to Persian Gulf-based diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Telephone communications to Kuwait were partly restored today. A woman at Kuwait University was reached by her family in Bahrain and they quoted her as saying ``the situation is very quiet, almost eerie, and tense.'' In Kuwait City, guns were silent today, and residents could determine little about what was going on. Iraqi soldiers were stopping cars and ``politely'' asking people to step out so they could check them, the woman told her family. The Iraqi government on Friday issued a separate statement denying that its troops made incursions into Saudi Arabia. But residents of the Saudi border city of Khafji, reached by telephone from Bahrain, said Iraqi troops had laid down a checkpoint less than a mile from the frontier. A NATO source said the United States had ``contingency plans'' in case Iraq thrust further into the strategic region. He did not say what those plans were. The United States will send a third aircraft carrier with 15,000 personnel toward the Middle East next week to bolster its naval armada in the Persian Gulf, Pentagon officials said Friday. A second carrier was on its way Thursday. The ships will back up the Navy's task force of eight warships already stationed inside the gulf. The Soviet Union and United States issued a rare joint statement in Moscow demanding that all countries stop arms supplies to Iraq and that Baghdad withdraw from Kuwait immediately. The Soviet Union, Iraq's main weapons supplier, cut off shipments Thursday, while the United States froze Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets on the same day. France, Italy, Poland, Britain and other countries also imposed sanctions against Iraq. In Cairo, an emergency Arab League Council meeting on Friday strongly condemned the invasion, demanded the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops and rejected any foreign intervention. Driven by fears of a production drop, oil prices continued to climb. North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude, rose $2 a barrel Thursday and 86 cents more on Friday to close at $23.25. Last month, oil prices were as low as $16 a barrel. Iraq's invasion followed two weeks of threats and accusations against its small Persian Gulf neighbor. On July 17 Saddam accused it of stealing oil from a field that straddles their disputed border. He also blamed Kuwait for a fall in oil prices that cost Iraq $14 billion, saying it contributed to the oil glut by cheating on its OPEC oil cartel production quotas.

DOC.HEAD: Drugs Blamed For Violent End to Violent Decade
DOC.TEXT: The nation capped a violent decade with 21,500 homicides last year, the FBI reported Saturday, and experts blamed drugs. The nation's capital remained the killing capital for a second year, with 434 murders and other non-negligent homicides, according to the FBI's compilation of crime reports from around the country. That gave the District of Columbia a rate of 72 slayings per 100,000 people, compared with the national rate of 8.7 per 100,000. The national rate represented a 3.6 percent increase over 1988. Detroit and Atlanta again occupied second and third place for homicides, the positions they held in 1988. Atlanta, however, had the highest overall crime rate for the second straight year. Criminologists blame drug trafficking for the rise in murders and assaults that helped make 1989 the most violent year of the decade. Forcible rapes also rose over the decade _ by 3.5 percent _ although experts say the increase may be due to more such crimes being reported. ``The drug trade is driving the violence,'' said Richard Bennett, a professor of justice at Washington's American University. ``Things such as bad debts, territorial disputes. That's what driving a lot of our assaults and homicides.'' Noted Dr. Alfred Blumstein, dean of the School of Urban and Public Affairs at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh: ``Middle class folks take each other to court. That's not the way ... to resolve issues for people whose disputes are over illegal activities, like drug dealers. You can't tell the judge, `This guy is invading my corner.' It won't work.'' Detroit's 624 killings gave it a homicide rate of 60 per 100,000. Atlanta, with 246 killings, had a rate of 57.7 per 100,000. The homicide rate was actually higher at the opening of the decade. The FBI said 10.2 people per 100,000 died of violent crimes in 1980. But the overall violent crime rate reached a record high in 1989, exceeding the 1980 level by 11.1 percent. Among those violent crimes was forcible rape, which rose 3.5 percent in the decade. Atlanta led all major cities, those with 400,000 or more population, when all crimes surveyed by the FBI in its Uniform Crime Reports are considered: homicide, forcible rape, robbery, aggravated assault, burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft and arson. The overall crime rate in Atlanta last year was 207.6 per 1,000 population, an increase over the 176.2 crimes for 1988. Dallas moved from third place in 1988 to second with 168.5 crimes per 1,000 population, swapping places with its Texas neighbor, Fort Worth, which had 157.8 crimes per 1,000 population. The rate of violent crime in general _ 663.1 incidents per 100,000 population _ increased 4.1 percent from 1988 to 1989. During the year, the biggest increase during the year was robbery, where the rate hiked 5.5 percent to 233 robberies per 100,000 population. The rate of forcible rape increased 1.3 percent to 38.1 rapes per 100,000. Aggravated assault went up 3.6 percent to 383.4 attacks per 100,000. Although there were more property crimes than in 1980, the rate was 5.1 percent lower than at the start of the decade. The 1989 rate was 5,077.9 incidents per 100,000 population. The rate of motor vehicle theft has jumped by 25.5 percent over the decade to hit 630.4 incidents per 100,000 population. The rate of burglary has plummeted by 24.2 percent to 1,276.3 incidents per 100,000. The rate of larceny-theft has remained virtually constant between 1980 and 1989, increasing only 0.1 percent over the decade. Firearms were used in 62 percent of 1989's killings, compared with 59 percent in 1985. The most popular firearm remained the handgun, which was used in 47.5 percent of the killings last year, compared with 43 percent in 1985. The Uniform Crime Reports compile information submitted by about 16,000 law enforcement agencies nationwide representing about 96 percent of the U.S. population. The FBI extrapolates from that information to provide totals for the entire country.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Awards $3.68 Million to Family of Air Force Crash Victim
DOC.TEXT: The family of a businessman killed when an Air Force jet crashed into a motel has been awarded $3.68 million. Flora Murray, wife of Thomas C. Murray, sued the federal government last year in a wrongful death complaint that blamed pilot error and government negligence for the crash Oct. 20, 1987. Mrs. Murray's attorney, John Townsend, said the settlement awarded Friday by U.S. District Judge Larry J. McKinney was ``a very substantial, reasonable award.'' The Air Force has not said if it will appeal the award. Murray of suburban Carmel had stopped to use a telephone in the Ramada Inn Airport when the crippled fighter jet crashed into the lobby. Nine others also were killed. The jet crashed after it lost power, and pilot Maj. Bruce L. Teagarden lost control as he attempted to make an emergency landing at Indianapolis International Airport. The pilot ejected safely moments before the jet slammed into the hotel. Murray, 37, the father of four children, was a regional sales manager for Haynes International Inc., a metal products company in Kokomo.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Trying to Pressure Iraq to Withdraw From Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 10 grafs on White House statement; pick up 4th graf pvs, The White ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today the use of U.S. military force remains an option in trying to compel Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait and restore the Kuwaiti monarchy to power. After meeting with top aides for two hours, Bush disclosed that the governments of Japan, France and West Germany had joined the United States in freezing Kuwaiti assets to prevent their seizure by Iraq. ``We continue to seek the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and restoration of the legitimate government of Kuwait,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. ``As we have stated before, all U.S. options are under consideration.'' The statement, issued after Bush's meeting with aides at Camp David, Md., made no mention of any Iraqi threat to Saudi Arabia. Reports today from the Middle East said replenished Iraqi invasion forces had advanced south toward the Saudi border. The White House said it has no information on missing Americans in Kuwait. Sources in the Persian Gulf said today that 20 Americans had been seized from a U.S. oil tanker in a Kuwaiti port, and that other foreigners had been detained in Kuwait. Also, 14 American oil workers in Kuwait have been reported missing. The State Department said Friday it believed the 14 were being held by Iraqi forces. Fitzwater's statement also welcomed the decision today of the 12-nation European Community to freeze Iraqi assets, ban imports of Iraqi oil and halt arms sales to Iraq. Bush met at Camp David with Vice President Dan Quayle, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Secretary of State James Baker III, CIA Director William Webster, and senior military officials. Fitzwater said Bush would continue to monitor the Middle East situation and would meet with Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, and other aides on Sunday evening at the White House. On Friday, Bush had reached out to leaders in the Arab world and beyond to pressure Iraq to withdraw its invasion army from oil-rich Kuwait and pointedly warned that Saudi Arabia's freedom is ``very, very important to the United States.'' The White House on Friday was skeptical of Badhdad's announcement that Iraqi troops would be withdrawn from Kuwait on a timetable beginning Sunday. The Iraqi government added, however, that the Al-Sabah royal family that ruled Kuwait for almost 250 years ``is finished forever and will never come back.'' ``We need to wait and see,'' said presidential Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``We asked for immediate and unconditional withdrawal. If there are strings, we need to see what they are.'' Bush himself said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein should ``haul them out right now.'' Bush said he planned to stay in touch by telephone with world leaders over the weekend to try to tighten international sanctions against Iraq. In Moscow, Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze jointly called upon all countries to cut off arms supplies to Iraq. The Soviets have been Baghdad's biggest arms supplier. Asked about the possibility that Saddam might next invade oil-rich Saudi Arabia, which borders Kuwait, Bush said: ``I'm not discussing options, but I would simply say the status quo is unacceptable, and further expansion would be even more unacceptable.'' Pressed on whether he was committed to defending the Saudis, who ship 1.2 million barrels of oil to this country daily, the president said, ``When you look at vital interests of the United States, the relationship with Saudi Arabia and its independence and its freedom come under the heading of very, very important.'' If the Saudis ask for assistance, ``I would be inclined to help in any way we possibly can,'' he added. The White House said Americans could expect to pay 7 to 8 cents more per gallon at the gasoline pump from a $3-per-barrel jump in the price of oil. Bush said there is a surplus of crude oil now, but ``long-run economic effects on the free world could be devastating'' if supplies are curtailed. The State Department said Iraqi troops, hardened by eight years of war with Iran, were positioned five to 10 miles from the Saudi border. The chairman of the House Armed Service Committee, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said bluntly, ``I think it means war'' if Iraq expands its invasion. ``The world cannot sit back and watch a person like Saddam Hussein take over half of the oil reserves in the world.'' The Pentagon said a third aircraft carrier was being readied to head to the Mideast to bolster U.S. forces already scattered outside the Persian Gulf. Officials said the USS Saratoga would relieve the USS Eisenhower, which was sent to the region in March. The carrier Independence already is headed from the Indian Ocean toward the Persian Gulf to strengthen the eight-ship U.S. Navy presence there. With tensions rising, the State Department advised the 3,000 Americans in Kuwait and the 500 in Iraq to leave as quickly as possible. Airports and ports were closed in Kuwait, however. Fitzwater said Iraqi troops have been stationed around the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait city, ``but they have not gone inside. There is no indication they intend to do that.'' The administration said 14 American oil workers were known missing and believed to be in Iraqi hands. The United States demanded that they be accounted for and freed, Fitzwater said. A State Department official said today the administration is aware of reports that Iraqi military forces took some Americans into custody at Rumaliah oil field. The official was unable to confirm news reports about their release. The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Thomas Pickering, was in New York discussing what pressure the U.N. can bring against Iraq. Fitzwater noted that the U.N. charter allows members to impose a military blockade on a renegade state. The spokesman said Iraq had ignored international calls for withdrawal. ``At this point we have received only scorn from Iraq,'' he said. Iraq began jamming short-wave broadcasts from the Voice of America late Friday, said Richard Carlson, director of the government radio network. Two of the six frequencies carrying Arabic-language broadcasts to the Middle East were jammed, but weaker Arabic signals and English-language broadcasts were not affected, he said. NATO sources in Brussels said, meantime, that the United States alerted Western allies that it was prepared to respond should Iraqi troops push beyond Kuwaiti territory. ``We have told them that we don't rule out any military option and that everything is under consideration,'' Fitzwater said. ``We are considering all options.'' Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United States, Prince Bandar, met at the White House with Scowcroft, the national security adviser. Bush said he talked by telephone with Turkish President Turgut Ozal, whose country is a conduit for much of the oil flowing from Iraq. He said he and Ozal ``look at this matter with the same sense or urgency and concern.'' Asked if the Turks would close the Iraqi pipeline, Bush replied, ``That will be an option, I'm certain.''

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Costs Continue to Rise; Some Suprise Challengers
DOC.TEXT: Financial disclosure forms for this year's House and Senate races show few exceptions to the rule that incumbents have the edge in fund raising, according to a Federal Election Commission analysis released Saturday. Candidates raised $279 million and spent $192 million from January 1989 through the end of June, the analysis says. The candidates still in this year's races reported having $158.8 million available to spend for the November elections. The data confirm the overwhelming advantage of incumbents, particularly in receiving donations from special-interest political action committees. Proposals to significantly restrict or even prohibit PAC donations and other incentives designed to level the playing field for challengers are included in campaign-finance overhaul plans now before Congress. Overall, when races for open seats are excluded, four of every five dollars donated to congressional candidates went to incumbents. The 441 incumbents seeking re-election to House or Senate seats reported raising a total of $196 million in the 18-month period covered by the study, with $74 million of that total coming from PACs. Including primary races there were nearly twice as many challengers _ 793 _ but they raised just $46 million, with $6. 3 million coming from PACs. The total of challenger loans to their own campaigns eclipsed their overall PAC receipts by more than $1 million. But challengers have matched or even surpassed incumbents in raising money in a dozen races, some of them this year's hottest contests. In Oregon, for example, Democratic challenger Mike Kopetski is essentially even with incumbent Republican Rep. Denny Smith in a race considered a toss-up. And in California, actor Ralph Waite, running as a Democrat, reported raising $235,000 as of June 30, more than twice the total raised by incumbent Republican Rep. Alfred McCandless. Two Virginia races have challengers beating their opponents at fund-raising. Democrat James Moran, mayor of the Washington suburb of Alexandria, reported a slight edge over incumbent Republican Stan Parris. Republican Rep. Frank Wolf is expected to keep his seat but is being beaten at the fund-raising game by Lyndon LaRouche, the perennial fringe presidential candidate who is running despite being in a federal prison for a fraud conviction. In Senate races, where six-year terms give plenty of time to raise money, incumbents enjoy huge fund-raising edges. The king of Senate fund-raising is Republican Phil Gramm of Texas, who raised $8.9 million from January 1989 through June alone, and as of June 30 reported $6.2 million in the bank. Democratic challenger Hugh Parmer had raised $1.4 million over the 18 months but had just $20,500 left to enter the final months of the campaign. Not far behind Gramm was New Jersey Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley, who is considered a possible presidential candidate in 1992. Bradley raised $6.7 million over the 18-month period and had $4.3 million in the bank at the end of June. Republican challenger Christine Todd Whitman raised $228,000 and had less than $75,000 on hand. On the House side, members of the Democratic leadership have the biggest advantage. For example, Missouri Rep. Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader and another potential 1992 presidential candidate, raised nearly $1 million over the 18-month period. His Republican challenger, Malcolm Holekamp, collected just $18,436.

DOC.HEAD: Weak Revenues in 23 States Point to Recession, Study Finds
DOC.BYLINE: Ess: Subs 7th graf bgng: `The figure ... to CORRECT that unemployment rate rose to 5.5 percent, restoring dropped word `to'; SUBS 12th graf: `The two ... to CORRECT spelling of `principal.' ^By WILLIAM M. WELCH
DOC.TEXT: Nearly half the states have seen no real growth in revenues this year, indicating they are in recession or close to it, a study of state finances said Saturday. The impact was cushioned by a big round of tax increases last year, and even more are likely next year, the author of the study said. ``The pressure is building on states to raise taxes next year,'' said Steven D. Gold, director for the Center for the Study of the States at the Nelson Rockefeller Institute of Government at Albany, N.Y. ``If you see a state that has lower revenue this year than last year, you know they're under tremendous pressure and there's a good bet they'll have to raise taxes next year,'' he said. The report was issued by the center, which is part of the State University of New York at Albany. It said that in a survey of revenue collections in 43 states, 23 reported total tax revenue increases equal to or below the inflation rate _ meaning no increases after adjustment for inflation. The figure was in line with a Labor Department report Friday showing unemployment shot up to 5.5 percent last month and the economy grew by just 1.2 percent in the second quarter, below the level needed to create new jobs. Orders to factories for manufactured goods fell 1.5 percent in June, the third drop this year, a sign layoffs and cutbacks could be coming. Construction spending was unchanged in June after being down two straight months and the government's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, weak most of the year, showed no strength at all. The conclusion that many state economies are in or near recession is consistent with a report from the National Governors' Association and the National Association of State Budget Officers in April that states were in worse financial condition than a year ago. The fresh study said corporate income tax collections were the weakest component of the state revenue picture, with a 6.7 percent decline, reflecting a drop in earnings. The two other principal revenue sources, the sales tax and personal income tax, posted overall gains of 6.6 percent and 7 percent respectively. Those three taxes account for more than 70 percent of state collections. In most states the revenue figures were for the 12 months ending in June. Weak state economies were found in all regions of the country, but New England and Mid-Atlantic states were in the worst shape, the report said. In five states, revenue was lower than in the corresponding period a year earlier: Massachusetts, Maine, Michigan, New Hampshire and New York. Eighteen other states had increases of less than 5 percent, the approximate rate of inflation used in the report. They were: Rhode Island, Vermont, Maryland, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Iowa, Kansas, Nebraska, Alabama, Florida, Mississippi, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia, New Mexico, Colorado and Oregon. Only eight states had revenue increases of 10 percent or more: Illinois, Georgia, Louisiana, North Carolina, West Virginia, Idaho, Wyoming and Nevada. Tax increases enacted since last year have helped boost revenue in several of those states, including Illinois, Georgia and West Virginia. ``Things are even worse than they look when you consider the fact states raised taxes quite a bit last year,'' Gold said in an interview. ``If those tax increases hadn't occurred, the decline in revenues would be even lower.'' Thirty states raised taxes last year, about the same number as this year. Twelve of the 1989 increases were large, involving either income or sales taxes. Gold said last year's tax increases totaled about $5 billion, with $3 billion taking effect this year. That should have been enough to increase the overall revenue figure by about 1.5 percent, he said. Three states reported decreases in personal income tax collections: Hawaii, which cut its rates, and Michigan and New York. But 10 others had increases below the inflation rate. Maine and Massachusetts reported lower sales tax revenues, and 19 others had increases of 5 percent or less. Seven states did not provide figures for the study: Alaska, Delaware, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah, Washington and Wisconsin. The report said several of those states are known to have strong revenue growth _ North Dakota, Utah and Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Lose Export Sales to Another Invasion-related Embargo
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Reverberations of the gunfire in the Persian Gulf are being felt by many U.S. farmers, who are facing yet another trade embargo after a foreign invasion. Iraq's attack on Kuwait prompted President Bush to order economic sanctions that ended sales of U.S. commodities such as wheat, rice and tobacco to the Middle Eastern nation. Moreover, disruption of oil supplies from the warring countries has caused the costs of fuel to run tractors and for petroleum-based fertilizers to climb higher. So farmers' costs could be going up at the same time the embargo depresses prices. Paul Drazek, international trade specialist for the American Farm Bureau Federation in Washington, said the loss of sales to Iraq and Kuwait would be small, compared with total U.S. farm exports. ``It's not a big chunk of the action but it will have some impact on producers. In agriculture, even a small amount can have an impact on prices,'' Drazek said. The U.S. Agriculture Department estimated agricultural sales to Iraq in 1989 at $720 million, out of total farm exports of $40 billion _ or 1.8 percent. Sales were even smaller to Kuwait. Still, Drazek and others said they feared the administration's sanctions would be costly to American farmers. ``The worst thing to do is single out agriculture. You're signaling the world that you're using food as a weapon,'' he said. ``We're saying we support the president's action as long as it is across the board and not singling out agriculture.'' Wheat growers said they hoped the economic sanctions do not bring about a repeat of President Jimmy Carter's embargo in 1980 that cut off sales to the Soviet Union after that country's invasion of Afghanistan. ``Sanctions operations, particularly related to food products, usually don't work very well,'' said Nelson Denlinger, executive vice president of U.S. Wheat Associates, a Washington, D.C., cooperative organization that represents wheat producers. ``As with the Afghan invasion, you'll find that commodities of that sort are replaceable,'' he said. ``You usually will find somebody, somewhere, who will sell you something. Food is not a good weapon for changing another country's behavior.'' ``It's a never-ending challenge to figure out what kind of rhubarb is going to happen next that will affect the ability to market wheat,'' said John Oades of U.S. Wheat Associates office at Portland, Ore. ``It's a very politically vulnerable commodity.'' Middle Eastern oil is another politically sensitive commodity, said Carl Schwensen, executive vice president of the National Association of Wheat Growers in Washington, D.C. ``We're removing a significant source of petroleum imports from our consumption picture,'' he said. ``As prices increase, that will flow through to the farmer as higher fuel, chemical and fertilizer costs.'' The increasing petroleum costs come at a time when the price of a bushel of wheat is falling because of a large crop of 2.7 million bushels, up 700,000 bushels from last year, Schwensen and others said. In July, the average farm price for wheat was $2.81 a bushel, down from $3.78 during the same month a year ago. Iraq last year bought 1.3 million tons of wheat from the United States. Other agricultural commodities also get pinched by the embargo. Iraq has been the U.S. rice market's largest customer, accounting for as much as one-fourth of U.S. exports. Almost all of the exports to Iraq _ about 350,000 to 450,000 tons a year _ is long-grain rice grown in Arkansas, Louisiana, Texas and Mississippi. ``I think it will cause less sales for Arkansas rice, which in effect will hurt our economy and hurt our farmers,'' said John Tull, a Lonoke, Ark., rice farmer. ``And I think that next year we will probably have to have a reduction in rice acres.'' ``Our farmers are seriously affected, and we would hope that agriculture and rice would be treated in a separate way from political things,'' said Jim Willis, vice president for foreign market development at the Houston-based Council for Market Development. Earlier this year, the Bush administration decided not to extend to Iraq additional credit guarantees. Iraq had purchased U.S. rice through the use of about $1 billion a year in government credit guarantees. Iraq is an importer of U.S. tobacco products, said Britt Cobb, an assistant director of marketing for the North Carolina Department of Agriculture. Iraq in 1988 imported $21 million of American tobacco, he said. California agriculture exports to Iraq totaled a little less than $4.4 million in 1989, a little more than 1 percent of the state's total food and fiber exports, according to statistics compiled by California State World Export Commission. Cotton and livestock comprise the bulk of that total. Chicken growers also will feel the impact of the invasion, said Tommy Irvin, Commissioner of Agriculture for Georgia, a major exporter. During the first four months of 1990, the United States sold more than $3 million worth of pieces of chicken, 900 metric tons, to Kuwait and about 106 metric tons of whole chicken valued at $130,000, Irvin said.
WX

DOC.HEAD: European Community Imposes Oil Embargo on Iraq, Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The European Community on Saturday imposed an embargo on oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait as part of a series of tough sanctions aimed at ``striking at the heart'' of Iraqi economic and military interests. The action, described as the strongest punitive measures ever taken by the the 12-nation EC, was aimed at forcing Iraq to immediately, unconditionally withdraw its invading forces from neighboring Kuwait. ``We will not be satisfied until there is not a single Iraqi soldier in Kuwait and until there is a legitimate and sovereign government in Kuwait,'' a spokesman for the Italian Foreign Ministry, Giovanni Castellaneta, said. The measures were announced after a three-hour meeting of senior EC foreign ministry officials. Italy, which holds the rotating EC presidency, convened the emergency meeting to forge a joint response to the Iraqi invasion Thursday. In addition to the oil embargo, the 12 nations agreed to freeze Iraqi assets, halt arms sales to Iraq, and suspend all cooperation with Baghdad in the military, technical and scientific fields. They also decided to suspend Iraq's trade preference status. The Europeans are also seeking to protect Kuwaiti assets in their countries and deny Iraq financial benefit from its military action, which the officials condemned as a ``brutal invasion.'' Several of the EC nations _ whose members include France, West Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Belgium, Netherlands, Denmark, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, Spain, and the United Kingdom _ had earlier announced separate moves to freeze Kuwaiti assets and halt arms sales to Iraq. The most punishing sanction is the embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. Last year oil from the two countries accounted for 10.9 percent of the EC's total oil imports. At the same time, Iraq is almost totally dependent on oil for its export earnings. ``This will strike at the heart of Iraq,'' Castellaneta said. The oil embargo was formally proposed by France, but the Italian official said all other countries were in unanimous agreement. The embargo could hurt some of the EC members, such as Denmark, which depends on Iraq and Kuwait for more than 50 percent of its oil. Italian officials called the sanctions the toughest taken against Iraq by any countries other than the United States and said they hoped other nations and organizations would follow suit, especially the U.N. Security Council. The United States has also imposed an embargo on Iraqi oil, included in a decree issued Thursday that blocked all imports from Iraq and froze Kuwaiti and Iraqi assets in the United States. Iraqi oil had represented 7.5 percent of U.S. oil imports, according to the lastest industry figures this year. Ferdinando Nelli, the Italian official in charge of European political affairs, said the oil embargo marked ``without a doubt'' the strongest economic sanctions ever imposed by the EC. He described the sanctions as a near-total commercial embargo on Iraq. The strength of the measures and unanimity were in marked contrast to past crises, when the EC members have been divided over whether to impose sanctions and how strong they should be. During the U.S. hostage-taking in Iran, for example, trade sanctions imposed by the EC fell short of U.S. expectations. There have also been differences among the member nations on policy toward Libya. Italian officials said the EC members did not discuss the possibility of joint military intervention in the Persian Gulf, saying such a step would be taken only in concert with the United Nations. The 12 did not cut diplomatic relations or withdraw their ambassadors from Iraq because that would make it impractical to defend their citizens in the area, Castellaneta said. In a written statement, the countries described as ``groundless and unacceptable'' Iraq's justification for the military action. Iraq claimed it invaded after rebels overthrew Kuwait's government. The EC nations said they would do everthing they could to avoid an implicit recognition of the so-called provisional government Iraq installed in Kuwait. The statement said the EC was ready to take part in any effort to defuse the crisis and was in close contact with several Arab governments. Castellaneta said Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis had received a message from Secretary of State James A. Baker III explaining the American position on the Gulf crisis. The spokesman said Italy and the United States have ``identical viewpoints'' on the need for strong measures to force an Iraqi withdrawal.

DOC.HEAD: Credit Card's $5,000 Limit Ought To Go A Long Way: Recipient Is 11-Year-Old
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old who publishes an environmental newsletter says he is more concerned about the economy now that MasterCard has issued him a gold card with a $5,000 credit limit. Tommy Mullaney filled out the application before he went to summer camp, stating his birthday, Nov. 10, 1978; occupation, student and publisher; and income _ $5 a week allowance. The card was waiting for him in the mail when he returned last month. ``I jumped up and down and said `Wow!' The hologram on it was cool,'' Mullaney said. ``But it sure made me wonder about who was running the bank.'' Tommy's mother, Mary, said she allowed her son to fill out the application because it would be a good experience, but didn't think it would be taken seriously. She immediately canceled the card. Loraine Person of First National Bank said the bank made a mistake in issuing the card, but it does not know how it happened. In addition to school and collecting baseball cards, Tommy publishes Pollution Solution, a bimonthly newsletter. The experience, however, has him thinking about the economy. ``I'm very scared about how safe my money is right now if they are giving it away to kids like me.''

DOC.HEAD: Magazine: Dozens of German Companies Helped Iraq With Weapons
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A magazine alleged Saturday that dozens of West German companies have helped Iraq build rockets and chemical weapons, and assisted Baghdad acquire ``military nuclear technology.'' According to Hamburg-based Der Spiegel, more than 100 West German companies are suspected of having helped Iraq build its military might in recent years. ``German companies have helped Iraq with the development of military nuclear technology, construction of rockets and production of poison gases,'' the magazine said, without elaborating. In a telex to news media, the magazine said the Iraqis in the past few days finished building a cannon factory with the help of West German companies. They also helped Iraq buld an artillery shell factory that has already begun production, the magazine reported. The magazine's telex did not name any of the companies allegedly involved, or say how the information was obtained. The report will appear in the magazine's latest edition, which appears on newsstands Monday. There have been several allegations in the past two years of German involvement in weapons-producing efforts in many countries, including Libya, Iraq, Pakistan and India. One of the most famous cases involved West German help in building Libya's alleged chemical weapons plant at Rabta. On June 27 industrialist Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen was convicted of violating export laws and of tax evasion. Imhausen admitted playing a major role in helping build the Libyan chemical complex and was sentenced to five years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Study: DNA Tests Valid Court Evidence If Done Properly
DOC.TEXT: DNA testing, a way to identify people or parentage using the body's genetic code, is reliable courtroom evidence, but national standards for the tests are needed, the Office of Technology Assessment said Saturday. The OTA, which evaluates technical subjects for the Congress, said that DNA testing first was introduced into the courtroom in 1986 and already has been used in more than 2,000 criminal investigations in 49 states and presented as evidence in more than 185 court cases. Law enforcement agencies, particularly the FBI, want to establish a data bank of DNA markers, similar to the national files of fingerprints, to help in the investigation of crimes. But the OTA said that such files could pose a threat to basic civil liberties. In a report, the OTA said that the principles of DNA identification ``are solid'' and that ``forensic uses of DNA tests are both reliable and valid when properly performed and analyzed by skilled personnel.'' Evidence from DNA patterns have been used to convict murders, rapists and other criminals. It also has been used to determine parentage and to identify bodies. Innocent men have been freed by DNA testing and police have used the technology to guide their evaluation of suspects. Validity of DNA testing has become so widely accepted, the OTA said, that ``no state court has found that DNA testing per se fails to meet established tests for admissibility'' although some courts have limited or barred its use in specific cases. DNA, shorthand for deoxyribonucleic acid, is the protein molecule that contains the genetic pattern for each individual. Except for red blood cells, DNA is present in every cell of the body. Every human has a unique DNA pattern, with the exception of identical twins who share the same genetic structure. Thus, police who recover bodily fluids or tissue from a crime scene can use DNA from those specimens to connect suspects with the crime. DNA patterns can be extracted from recovered specimens of blood, semen, body tissue, bone, hair roots, saliva, urine or the pulp of a tooth. These patterns can then be compared to patterns found in blood or other specimens taken from the suspects. The OTA said the major difficulty with DNA identification is the assurance that uniform standards are followed in conducting the tricky laboratory procedures in conducting the tests. ``Instituting quality assurance mechanisms should proceed without delay,'' the OTA said. It called for a standardization that would assure that tests are conducted and interpreted the same way in each jurisdiction. Widespread use of DNA testing, the report said, could be a significant weapon in fighting crime. ``DNA testing can save law enforcement and courts time and money by exonerating innocent suspects before trial, or through plea bargaining for guilty parties as increasingly defendants are confronted with DNA typing results,'' the study said. The OTA said that society should prepare for the use of computer data banks for the storage of DNA identification tests. It said that 16 states and one county already have authorized or considered creating DNA files for known offenders. And the FBI is developing a system to store DNA profiles for investigative uses. ``Centralized or linked databases containing DNA profiles would permit rapid, electronic comparison of results from tests on different samples within a laboratory and among laboratories nationwide,'' the report said. DNA files kept of convicted offenders, for instance, ``could be used to analyze whether evidence found at a crime scene matched a profile in the database, and thus provide police with a lead toward identifying a suspect,'' the report said. The report said that computer files of convicted offenders would be particularly helpful in investigating rape cases since released rapists are 10.5 times more likely than other offenders to be rearrested for rape. The files also would aid police in investigating serial crimes because it would enable them to link individual cases more quickly. Creating such a computer data, however, the OTA predicted, will ``evoke several concerns about privacy.'' ``Because DNA is specific to an individual and so highly personal, some are reluctant to see any DNA test results become part of a de facto national database,'' it said. Many states now are hiring private laboratories to conduct DNA testing and to provide expert witnesses when the evidence is used in court. The OTA said there were three major companies providing the service, Cellmark, Forensic Science Associates and Lifecodes. Pricing systems vary with costs ranging from $325 per test to $1,500 for a case. Cost of expert witnesses range from $100 an hour to $1,000 a day, the report said. The report said that Congress could play a role in the development of DNA testing by establishing standards and funding laboratories or training for personnel. But the OTA said Congress also will have to consider whether to establish national computer databanks of DNA information and wrestle with the concerns about privacy and civil rights in collecting and storing DNA profiles.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Vows to Block Early Elections
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Social Democrats and their East German counterparts pledged Saturday to block a plan to hold all-German elections seven weeks earlier than planned. In East Germany, Social Democrats threatened to pull out of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's fragile coalition government over his proposal to hold elections for a single German parliament Oct. 14 rather than Dec. 2. Peter Kauffold, a leading member of the East German Social Democrats, said the party's parliamentary faction plans to discuss leaving the government Tuesday, West Berlin's Berliner Morgenpost newspaper reported. Social Democrats in both Germanys charged that the call for earlier elections was an attempt to rig the outcome of the all-German vote in favor of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, the leader of the Christian Democrat Party. The Social Democrats claim Kohl and his East German ally de Maiziere are calling for October elections out of fear that voters will turn against them as East Germany's economy worsens. Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of the West German Social Democrats, warned against any ``election manipulation'' Anke Fuchs, a leading Social Democratic lawmaker in West Germany, vowed ``All-German elections will not occur on Oct. 14.'' However, the campaign manager for Kohl's likely challenger Social Democrat leader Oskar Lafontaine, indicated the party would consider the idea. ``We are ready to have a discussion,'' Reinhard Klimmt was quoted as saying in this week's edition of the West German magazine, Der Spiegel. The magazine made Klimmt's comments available in advance of publication. Friedrich Bohl, parliamentary business chief for the West German Christian Democrats, said the Social Democrats have to seriously ask themselves whether ``they want to postpone unity and all-German elections ... in this historical hour.'' Karl-Heinz Hornhues, deputy leader of the West German Christian Democrat parliamentary faction, appealed to ``the reasonable majority'' of Social Democrats to support the push for the earlier election date. Kohl maintains that holding the elections Oct. 14 corresponds to ``the wishes of the people'' in both Germanys. All political parties had earlier agreed to the Dec. 2 date. The all-German vote would fuse the two countries under one government.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Hungry For Funds But Slow To Respond, Study Finds
DOC.TEXT: The Red Cross, the nation's biggest charity, often takes days to respond to disasters, has conflicts with other relief organizations and overstates its accomplishments, according to a newspaper report. A nine-month investigation by The Pittsburgh Press that examined emergency responses to more than 200 disasters, including every major one in the past five years, showed that, in some cases, the Red Cross lived up to its promise to deliver help quickly, fairly and compassionately. But in others, the review showed, there were widespread deficiencies. The alleged problems included delays of up to six days after a disaster hits before adequate numbers of trained workers arrive, a lack of cooperation with local agencies and an emphasis on staging news media events during disasters. The paper, in a series set to begin in Sunday's newspaper, also said the charity does not always spend all money donated for a specific disaster on that disaster. The Red Cross said it was unfairly criticized because of highly publicized shortcomings last year following Hurricane Hugo and the northern California earthquake. ``It's absurd to look at last fall's hurricane and earthquake and say the Red Cross can't do the job. The Red Cross may have had a few little problems, but we were dealing with two unprecedented disasters,'' said Barbara Lohman, a national Red Cross spokeswoman in Washington, D.C. ``If you want to be fair and get an accurate picture, look at the hundreds of other disasters that we worked on, and you'll find that the Red Cross performance was almost flawless,'' she told the newspaper. The Red Cross' unique operating position was created in 1900 when Congress passed a law making it the only volunteer agency required to aid victims of disaster. Today, funded almost totally by donations from the American public, the $1.2 billion operation promises immediate response to a disaster with food and shelter, medical care, clothing, temporary housing and other basic needs. To raise money, it is Red Cross policy to stress image even in the early hours of a disaster, according to the newspaper report. Two of the four names posted on the nightly call-out roster at national headquarters in Washington, D.C. _ those people to be notified in case of a major disaster _ are fund-raisers. ``We had a film crew and a still photographer on the ground, on the coast before (Hurricane) Hugo hit the mainland ... and with the earthquake, we had a video crew in San Francisco within the first 24 hours,'' Ms. Lohman acknowledged. Most of the national disaster staff did not arrive until several days later. The emphasis on fund raising irks many critics of the organization, founded by Civil War nurse Clara Barton in 1881. ``When the fund-raising ability of a disaster diminishes, so does the national Red Cross,'' said Carl Bradford, West Virginia's director of emergency management. ``The national organization is clearly driven by how much money it can raise, so when the television crews and reporters leave, the Red Cross is in the next cars out of town.'' Mayor Anita Wiley of Shadyside, Ohio, where 26 people were killed in flooding in mid-June, said the Red Cross didn't arrive for three days, ``and then all they care about is raising money and their public image.'' George Moody, chairman of American National Red Cross, conceded that problems sometimes occur. But he said they're rare. ``When you have 2,200 active chapters involved in delivering services, you're going to have inconsistency once in a while,'' he said. Allegations of diverting funds designated for a specific disaster area surfaced after the northern California earthquake. San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos charged the Red Cross was leaving town with $55 million contributed specifically for earthquake relief. The Red Cross announced a month later it would spend $40 million in additional earthquake relief. While the Red Cross is by far the nation's largest recipient of disaster contributions, totaling $175 million last year, the Press concluded that less publicized disaster relief groups, primarily the Salvation Army and other national church groups, usually arrive first, stay longer and do more.

DOC.HEAD: New Mir Crew Begins First Full Day of Work on Space Station
DOC.TEXT: The new crew on the Soviet space station Mir began its first full day of work aboard the complex Saturday, focusing on experiments to create pure ``crystals'' for use in semiconductors, Tass said. Cosmonauts Gennady Manakov and Gennady Strekalov conducted joint experiments with the outgoing crew, Anatoly Solovyev and Alexander Balandin, the official news agency reported. Solovyev and Balandin are scheduled to return to Earth on Thursday. Manakov and Strekalov docked their Soyuz TM-10 capsule with the space station Friday, two days after lifting off from the Baikonur Space Center in Soviet Central Asia. The cosmonauts have turned on a ``furnace'' to melt materials to produce the pure crystals, Tass said. Solovyev and Balandin have been producing the crystals in the special ``Krystall'' module docked to the Mir. Since they arrived in February, they produced 23 pure crystals, which Tass said were worth about $1 million each. The news agency said Friday that Manakov and Strekalov will engage in ``pilot commercial production'' of these crystals. The Soviet Union is focusing on the production of these materials to make its space program profitable. It expects the specialized manufacturing to bring in more than $40 million. The Soyuz TM-10 capsule that brought Manakov and Strekalov to the Mir had other passengers aboard: five Japanese quail. Tass did not specify what experiments were in store for the fowl. In December, the Soviets will launch an eight-day mission to the Mir that includes a Japanese cosmonaut. The cosmonauts also have begun an experiment to produce cellular cultures in zero gravity for use by pharmaceutical concerns, the news agency said. Radio Moscow said Manakov, the flight's commander who is on his first space mission, and Strekalov, on his fourth, were adjusting well to zero gravity. All four cosmonauts were reported in good health. Before they return to Earth following their six months in weightlessness, Solovyev and Balandin will undergo physical exercises in a special ``pneumatic vacuum suit'' that simulates gravity, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Jurors Deliberate Four Hours, Break for Weekend
DOC.TEXT: Jurors deliberated four hours without a verdict in Mayor Marion Barry's cocaine and perjury trial Saturday and then stopped work for the rest of the weekend. Deliberations halted until Monday after the panel asked the judge for another look at more than 150 prosecution and defense exhibits. Prosecutors introduced more than 100 exhibits and Barry's lawyers more than 60 during the six-week trial on cocaine and perjury charges. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson brushed off questions from reporters waiting at the courthouse, saying, ``Do you people ever feel silly doing this?'' The jurors are sifting six weeks of testimony from 44 witnesses, including 10 of Barry's friends who said they saw him use cocaine some 200 times dating back to 1983. Friday was the first full day of jury deliberations in the trial. The panel has been told to ignore such factors as the mayor's flamboyant personality and his central place in local politics. Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy said in his closing argument that Barry had engaged in ``occasional'' cocaine use. But he said the government failed to prove the instances of cocaine possession charged in the indictment. The government tracked down cocaine dealers, former aides and ex-girlfriends of the mayor, pressuring them into giving false testimony, his lawyers said. They said the FBI entrapped the mayor by supplying the crack cocaine he smoked in a videotaped sting operation. Rasheeda Moore, who lured Barry to the hotel where he was arrested in a drug sting, testified that the mayor slapped her to the floor when their two-year affair ended in 1988. She said their relationship mixed sex with cocaine, opium and marijuana. ``I guess you all figured that I couldn't resist that lady,'' Barry told FBI agents after Moore persuaded him to come to her hotel room seven months ago on the night of the sting. Barry lawyers attacked the credibility of prosecution witnesses. Moore was unable to recall specific dates of cocaine use. She said that was because she was not good with numbers. Mundy said the actual reason was that her testimony was made up. Another key witness against the mayor was convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, son of a prominent Virgin Islands family. He testified that he and Barry constructed a makeshift crack pipe out of a sherbet glass and smoked cocaine at a Washington hotel. A city attorney backed Lewis' testimony, saying he found Barry one night in a bathroom, slumped over and surrounded by drug paraphernalia. Mundy depicted Lewis as the center of a drug and prostitution ring whose testimony was aimed at shortening his prison term.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhotos NY44, LON6
DOC.TEXT: ``Happy Birthday Grandmother England,'' read a banner carried by one of thousands of admirers outside the London home of the Queen Mother, who celebrated her 90th birthday Saturday. Crowds of fans, some of whom had camped out overnight to get a better viewing position, were rewarded when she stepped onto the geranium-framed balcony about 11 a.m. to wave and smile. The Band of the Coldstream Guards played ``Happy Birthday'' as she appeared. The mother of Queen Elizabeth II then emerged to greet the crowd around Clarence House, the mansion that has been her London home since she was widowed 38 years ago. Dozens of children gathered around her, offering balloons and bouquets of daisies, zinnias, lilies and baby's breath. She gently patted the shoulder of each. Looking cool and relaxed despite the hot weather, she spent nearly a half-hour shaking hands and saying ``Thank you'' to the crowd lined up along police barricades on the mansion's grounds. ``It's been marvelous. Everybody has been so kind,'' she said. She then walked beyond the house gates, despite the objections of nervous security guards, to visit with the crowd. Nearly anything associated with her pleased the crowd, which even cheered when her corgi dog appeared at the door to the house. ``For me, she is everything that belongs to Britain. She's the figurehead ... the grandmother to us all. She's absolutely wonderful,'' said Emily Coughlin, who had waited outside since Thursday. After the appearance, the Queen Mother was joined for lunch by her daughters, Queen Elizabeth II and Princess Margaret, and her grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

Kevin Costner, Lloyd Bridges, Goldie Hawn, Harrison Ford, Jane Fonda, Steve Martin and Danny de Vito seem to realize it's not easy being green. So they're among the big Hollywood stars pumping money into the sweeping ``Big Green'' environmental initiative on California's November ballot. Entertainers have contributed much of the $1.4 million raised to support Proposition 128, according to reports filed last week with the state. The initiative, Proposition 128, would phase out the use of pesticides known to cause cancer, eliminate use of gases that damage the ozone layer and forbid the cutting of old redwoods. It also would impose stricter rules to prevent oil spills and set up a new state agency to enforce environmental laws. Opponents, including chemical manufacturers, farmers, grocers and other business people, say it would fail to clean the environment while driving up food and energy costs. ``If I'm Bruce Willis and I make $6 million a picture it's not going to hurt me to pay 70 cents more for a gallon of gas,'' said Don Schrack, a spokesman for the No On 128 Committee.

Cancellation of local showings of a revival of the hit musical ``The Fantasticks'' starring Robert Goulet has prompted the touring company to sue a downtown theater. Fantasticks Touring Co., a part of Pace Theatricals Inc. of New York, filed a lawsuit Friday in Hennepin County District Court.
