The suit alleges that publicity for the show was mishandled and seeks more than $220,000 in damages from the Minneapolis Community Development Agency, which owns the Orpheum Theater, and from Theater Live!, its operator. According to the lawsuit, the touring company and the Orpheum agreed in May to present ``Robert Goulet starring in The Fantasticks.'' Eight performances were scheduled between June 25 and July 1. ``The Fantasticks'' is the longest-running show in U.S. theater history, having opened in a New York off-Broadway theater in May 1960. The musical was supposed to open its first national run in Minneapolis, but after the shows were canceled, the debut was moved to Dallas. The lawsuit names as defendants Fred Krohn, Theater Live! president; and Krohn's financial partners, identified in the complaint only as John and Jane Doe. The lawsuit alleges that Krohn and the others failed to carry out the publicity plan and informed the touring company on June 20 that they would stop promoting the performances. On June 21, the performances were canceled. Krohn said an agreement was never signed and that ``the deal was in a state of flux before the show.'' He said he had not received a copy of the lawsuit.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Longer version moving on some sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Detroit Piston John Salley debuts this weekend with the Detroit Symphony Orchestra _ narrating ``Casey at the Bat.'' And he says that's as close to baseball as he wants to come. ``I don't like the idea of this white thing coming at your head 90 miles an hour,'' said Salley, a forward on the two-time National Basketball Association champion team. Salley said he was happy to do the show, though. ``I got time, plus it's cultural. I like all music except heavy metal,'' he said. And his ultimate goal in music? ``I just one day want to be able to go to a club, see a piano and entertain everybody,'' he said. ``I can't say I can sing, but I can talk a lot of words.''

DOC.HEAD: Quiet Hearing Belied High Stakes in Pa. Abortion Court Battle
DOC.TEXT: The stakes were high, but both sides in the abortion debate refrained from public protests during a federal hearing on a challegnge to Pennsylvania's strict abortion law. Three days of testimony ending last Thursday took place in an atmosphere of restrained decorum. The courtroom in Reading, with seating for about 15, was only occasionally filled. The closest it came to high drama was when Senior U.S. District Judge Daniel H. Huyett admonished a witness for being evasive. But belying the hearing's mannerly discourses, the special-interest groups were hard at work. Seated beside Senior Deputy Attorney General Kate L. Mershimer throughout the trial was Maura Quinlan, a Harrisburg attorney whose law firm lists the Pennsylvania Catholic Conference among its clients. On the other side, the suit filed on behalf of a group of abortion clinics and doctors was being handled in part by Kathryn Kolbert, an attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union. Attorneys for the clinics also received legal aid from Planned Parenthood in New York. The suit challenges the law's provisions mandating a 24-hour waiting period and that women notify their spouses in most cases before they have an abortion. Other contested sections require minors to get the permission of one parent, or a court order, before having an abortion and require clinics to file detailed reports with the state on each abortion. Huyett is not expected to rule for about a month. The judge has blocked the disputed sections of the law pending a decision. An appeal is likely, regardless of the outcome. Pennsylvania's law is the most stringent of any state; a tougher one was passed last month by the Louisiana Legislature, but it was vetoed by Gov. Buddy Roemer. Only Guam, a U.S. territory in the Pacific, has adopted stricter controls. Mershimer's witnesses characterized the law as a reasonable set of guidelines that would protect the interests of women and families. But attorneys for the clinics argued that the law set up draconian requirements that would set up a series of difficult hurdles for women seeking abortions. The case has been closely monitored by abortion activists because it poses a potential of spawning a case that could lead to a U.S. Supreme Court decision overturning Roe vs. Wade, the 1973 ruling that established abortion as a constitutional right. Still, advocates on both sides said they decided not to protest because it wouldn't serve a useful purpose. Planned Parenthood spokeswoman Suzanne Mayer said abortion rights advocates were informally discouraged from protesting during a meeting last month of Pennsylvanians for Choice. ``Huyett is very fair; there's no need to annoy him with protests,'' she said. ``If it's in the courts, you're going to leave it to the courts.'' Garnett Biviano, president of the Pennsylvania Pro-Life Federation, said protests are appropriately aimed at the Legislature, where the law was drafted. ``We recognize the difference between the legislative branch and the judicial branch of government,'' she said. During closing arguments, Huyett gave some clues that he might have concerns with the law. He previously has upheld challenges to Pennsylvania's 1982 abortion law, much of which was later struck down by the Supreme Court. Parts of that law were redrafted into the existing statute. Huyett said there may be a problem with the defining which medical emergencies would permit doctors to perform immediate abortions to avoid substantial injury to the mother. On the 24-hour waiting period, Huyett, citing testimony, speculated that the requirement might create ``a delay of several days or a week'' for some women and, at certain times of pregnancy, that wait could be medically significant.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Removes 22 Bodies from Embattled Area
DOC.TEXT: Red Cross workers on Saturday removed 22 bodies from the battlefronts of warring Shiite Moslem militias in southern Lebanon. The International Committee of the Red Cross said the corpses were taken out of three villages in south Lebanon's embattled Apple Province. The Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the more secular Amal militia, which is allied with Syria, accused each other of breaking the ``mercy cease-fire'' while the Red Cross removed the dead. No Red Cross volunteers were injured in the shooting. The Red Cross on Friday collected 60 corpses from the battlegrounds near Israel's self-designated ``security zone'' in southern Lebanon. The new corpses raised the overall casualty toll to 211 killed and 570 wounded since the the latest round in Amal-Hezbollah fighting broke out Jan. 16. The militias are fighting for dominance of Lebanon's Shiites, the nation's largest sect. The 2- to 10-mile deep Israeli security zone was set up in 1985 after Israeli troops pulled back a force that had invaded Lebanon three years earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Member Kuwaiti Military Cabinet Announced in Baghdad
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Baghdad Television announced Saturday a list of the nine military officers comprising what it called the free provisional government of Kuwait. No pictures were shown of the men, who Iraq claimed were Kuwaiti army officers. They were not known public figures in the Persian Gulf emirate that Iraq invaded. Some Arab diplomatic sources dismissed the declaration of the provisional Cabinet as a list of fake names. Others insisted the names were of Iraqi officers. The names are: Col. Ala Hussein Ali, prime minister, commander-in-chief of the armed forces, minister of defense and minister of the interior. Lt. Col. Walid Saoud Mohammed Abdullah, Minister of Foreign Affairs. Lt. Col. Fuad Hussein Ahmad, minister of oil and acting minister of finance. Maj. Fadil Haidar Al-Wafiqi, minister of information and acting communications minister. Maj. Mishal Saad Al-Hadab, minister of health and public works. Lt. Col. Hussein Ali Al-Shammari, minister of social affairs and labor, acting minister of housing. Maj. Nasser Mansour Al-Mandil, minister of education and acting minister of higher education. Maj. Issam Abdul Majeed Hussein, minister of justice and acting minister of Islamic affairs. Maj. Yacoub Mahmoud Shallal, minister of trade and acting minister of planning.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators to Marshal Opposition to Federal Excise Tax Increases
With AM-States-Recession, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: State legislators are worried that efforts by President Bush and Congress to balance the federal budget will knock their state budgets out of balance. Proposed federal tax increases are targeting some of the revenue sources states depend on to keep their ledgers from dipping into the red, said Illinois House Minority Leader Lee Daniels. Daniels will be presiding this week over the annual meeting of the National Conference of State Legislatures, where the federal budget will be a major topic for 2,000 state lawmakers. Recent U.S. Supreme Court decisions have set the stage for discussions on states' power to ban public financing of abortion and to require pregnant teens to get the consent of a parent or a judge before having an abortion. Another Supreme Court decision on the agenda: the Missouri case involving a family's right to halt life-sustaining treatment and the state's interest in preserving life. Daniels said some issues may be divisive, but not the subject of the federal budget deficit. States fear proposals being discussed in Washington, D.C., could cost them up to $4 billion by 1995, he said. He said state legislators fully support efforts to reduce the federal deficit. But a National Conference of State Legislatures study suggests federal tax hikes on gasoline, tobacco or alcoholic beverages would damage state economies and reduce state collections of similar taxes between 1991 and 1995. ``Federal budget negotiators must understand that states cannot accept proposals that would result in damage to state fiscal systems,'' Daniels said. ``States rely on these taxes to a far greater extent than the federal government, because the federal government pre-empts much of the income tax base and restricts many other revenue sources.'' The study showed the largest damage would come from a proposed 6-cent per gallon increase in the federal gasoline tax, which could cost states $3.15 billion. Among the speakers at the legislators' 16th annual summer meeting will be White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and U.S. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Both have been attempting to negotiate a plan to slash $500 billion from the federal budget deficit over the next five years.

DOC.HEAD: Wrong Patient Gets Open-Heart Surgery
DOC.TEXT: A doctor was fined and another still faces disciplinary action for mistakenly performing open-heart surgery on the wrong woman after a mix-up in patient records. Besides fining Dr. Howard W. Ramsey of Gainesville $5,000 on Friday, the state Board of Medicine ordered him to write an article for other doctors warning them about making the same mistake. Board action is still pending against Dr. Daniel Knauf, a University of Florida surgeon who operated on the healthy Palatka woman in 1988, for letting an assistant, who was not a doctor, examine the patient before surgery instead of doing it himself. During surgery, Knauf found the woman's valve normal and sewed her up again. She survived and sued Ramsey, Knauf, North Florida Regional and Shands. The suit has yet to be heard. ``This case reveals the most bizarre sequence of events that I have heard of in a cardiologic practice,'' wrote Dr. Marshall A. Burns, who reviewed the case for the board. ``One fiasco followed another.'' Ramsey couldn't explain how the Palatka woman's name wound up on the report of another patient with a more serious problem. ``Nothing the board can say to me can be as severe as the humiliation and chagrin and anger I have that this could have happened,'' Ramsey said. The woman underwent cardiac catheterization supervised by Ramsey at North Florida Regional Medical Center in Gainesville, but her name was erroneously placed on the report of a patient who had a serious heart-valve defect. After taking the erroneous report to Shands Hospital at the University of Florida for a second opinion, she was examined by Knauf's assistant and sent to surgery.

DOC.HEAD: House Banking Chairman Says US Loans Helped Finance Kuwait Invasion
DOC.TEXT: An Atlanta-based Italian bank helped finance the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait by supplying $3 billion in credits partly guaranteed by the U.S. government, the chairman of the House banking committee said Saturday. ``There is no question but those $3 billion are actually financing the invasion of Kuwait,'' Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, told The Associated Press. ``There is no question that the greater portion of that was dealing with armaments.'' Gonzalez said $800 million of the credits made during the 1980s, when Iran and Iraq were at war, was guaranteed under an Agriculture Department export financing program. Gonzalez first made his assertions in an interview Friday with the Austin (Texas) Statesman-American. Justice Department investigators months ago began looking into activities of the Atlanta affiliate of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, a large, Rome-based institution owned primarily by the Italian government. The Atlanta bank is one of several BNL branches in the United States. Others are in New York, Chicago, Miami and Los Angeles, Gonzalez said. He said a number of officials of the Atlanta bank recently were fired as the investigation intensified. Gonzalez said the Defense Intelligence Agency is also looking into the arrangement. He also said that the Italian government has sent an investigator to Atlanta to look into the case. Gonazalez scheduled an Aug. 14 hearing in the case by his House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee. The inquiry followed reports that the Atlanta bank extended $3 billion in letters of credit to Iraq, some guaranteed by the Department of Agriculture's Commodity Credit Corp. The Commodity Credit Corp. and other Agriculture Department agencies normally guarantee loans by private banks to foreign countries as a means of financing exports of American farm products and related goods. Gonzalez said in this case the CCC guaranteed $800 million of a total of $3 billion in credits for Iraq. He said the loans were supposed to finance purchases of grain and machinery. Gonzalez said, however, there was clear evidence that armaments perhaps including chemical weapons were obtained by Iraq under the deal. He said some agricultural exports may also have been included. The cost to Iraq of seizing and occupying Kuwait may never be known, but Iraq did borrow an estimated $30 billion from its Arab neighbors over the course of its eight-year war with Iran. He said full details of the arrangement are hard to come by because Iraq later settled with the parent bank in Rome. He also complained that there is too little federal regulation of such operations. ``Banca Lavoro is just small potatoes, even though Italy, astoundingly, is second in foreign banking activity in the United States,'' Gonzalez said. ``What worries me is that there is probably $500 billion of this in Lord knows how many similar transactions going on.'' Gonzalez said full details of the arrangements between the Atlanta bank and Iraq remain unknown, in part because Iraq has since settled its debt with the parent bank in Rome. ``It's locked in a maze of secret transactions that unfortunately are entered into outside the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Experts Checking if Mass Graves Contain Victims of Military
DOC.TEXT: Experts were investigating whether the remains of 28 people discovered in four mass graves are from leftists executed under the past government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the government said Saturday. The new findings raised to at least 69 the number of remains discovered since President Patricio Aylwin's civilian government took power. Forty-one of the bodies have been officially identified as dissidents executed after Pinochet's 1973 military coup. Many of the bodies were discovered with the hands bound. The latest finding were made in Constitucion, a resort city 223 miles south of Santiago, and in Calama and Tocopilla, in the country's northern Atacama desert, deputy Interior Minister Belisario Velasco said. Interior Minister Enrique Krauss said the goverment is investigating 1,000 cases of leftists who were reportedly executed and 800 cases of people who reportedly disappeared following Pinochet's coup. He said, however, the figures are approximate. ``When we don't known where the missing Chileans are, it is difficult to determine how many Chileans are missing,'' he added. But the minister called on all Chileans ``to avoid trying to find a political advantage from this painful situation.'' Aylwin, an elected civilian, replaced Pinochet on March 11. The 74-year-old general, however, remains commander of the 60,000-member army. In Mutrum hill, near Constitucion, Velasco said, at least 12 bodies were found, some of them with their hands tied with plastic ropes. Three more bodies were found in an illegal grave at the city's cemetery, he said. Seven more bodies were unearthed near Calama, a mining city 1,000 miles north of Santiago. Six others were discovered in the neighboring port city of Tocopilla. Workers have been digging for the last six days on the banks of the Mapocho river, which crosses Santiago, after human rights activists and residents of slums in the area reported that at least 33 executed leftists were buried there in 1973. Following the coup, the military launched a campaign against leftists who supported the toppled government of Salvador Allende, an avowed Marxist. Thousands were detained and forced into exile abroad, many others were tortured. Hundreds were executed. In most cases the relatives of the victims were officially notified of the executions but the bodies were never delivered to them. Military officials at the time said the executions were the result of a ``state of internal war,'' which they blamed on the Marxists.

DOC.HEAD: Sanctions, Condemnations of Iraq Expand
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The European Community, Japan, and the United States used diplomacy, economic sanctions and military muscle Saturday hoping to force Iraq to pull its invasion force from oil-rich Kuwait. In Rome, the 12-member European Community imposed an embargo against imports of Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil. It also banned exports of weapons to Iraq, suspended that country's preferential trade status and froze Iraqi assets. Warships from France, the United States and Great Britain steamed toward the Persian Gulf to reinforce international forces already in the Gulf region, but Arab nations warned against foreign intervention in the crisis. However, Arab diplomatic efforts foundered Saturday. Arab leaders postponed a summit planned Sunday in Saudi Arabia to discuss Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. And the 45-nation Organization of Islamic Conference on Saturday drafted a resolution condemning the Iraqi action and demanding the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi forces. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said Saturday that France would consider supporting a naval blockade of Iraq or disruption of its oil pipelines if diplomatic efforts and sanctions are ineffective. The United States, which on Thursday imposed an embargo on oil and other Iraqi imports, reportedly approached Turkey and Saudi Arabia about cutting Iraq's oil pipelines to the Mediterranean and the Red Sea. Iraqi pipelines run through both countries. But Turkey's president, Turgut Ozal, told reporters: ``There had been no demands from the United States for the closure of the pipeline. Such a demand is out of question.'' In Tokyo, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told President Bush that Japan would impose sanctions against Iraq if the United Nations votes to do so. The United States has proposed that the U.N. Security Council impose sweeping economic and military sanctions against Iraq, and U.N. diplomats discussed it Saturday. Japan also joined nations freezing Kuwaiti assets to block the Iraqi-backed government's access to them. Britain, the United States, France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, Norway and Luxembourg have frozen Kuwaiti assets. Britain announced Saturday it was joining France and the United States in blocking Iraqi assets. The Soviet Union, Iraq's biggest arms supplier, froze weapons shipments to Baghdad on Thursday. Italy and Czechoslovakia have also halted arms deliveries. Moscow and Baghdad have had a friendship treaty since 1972, but the Soviet press denounced the Iraqi government Saturday as a ``totalitarian regime.'' On Friday, the United States and the Soviet Union made an unprecedented joint condemnation of Iraq and called on all countries to cut arms supplies. In Beijing, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen indicated Saturday that China would not join the United States and other nations in imposing sanctions. ``The issue should be solved within the scope of inter-Arab relations,'' the official Xinhua News Agency paraphrased Qian as saying. On Friday, Egypt and the Gulf Cooperation Council _ Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Oman _ condemned the invasion and called for immediate Iraqi withdrawal. Iran, which fought a eight-year war with Iraq, condemned the invasion but said Baghdad's Western and Arab backers were to blame. A Tehran radio commentary Saturday said a solution had to be found that would avoid giving the United States an excuse to intervene militarily. ``Foreign military intervention, more than economic and military embargos, will make the Persian Gulf a flashpoint,'' it said. ``The world, and especially the backers of the Iraqi regime, were warned that military arming of Iraq, and providing all economic and political means to strengthen this regime, will have very dangerous effects for the future of the region,'' the radio said. The British government said it was ``extremely skeptical'' that Iraq would meet its pledge Friday to begin withdrawing its troops from Kuwait this weekend. ``This is unacceptable. We want an unconditional return to the status quo. This means that the royal family must be restored,'' said a Foreign Office spokesman, referring to Kuwait's ousted monarchy. In Aspen, Colo., British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said she would travel to Washington on Monday to meet with Bush over the invasion. In Israel, Defense Minister Moshe Arens warned Saturday that Israel will act against Iraq if it moves its forces into Jordan. ``We are ready, we are prepared and we are strong,'' he said on Israel radio. ``We have a significant deterrent capability and we can guard our interests.''

DOC.HEAD: Propane Leak at Plant that Exploded Prompts Evacuation
DOC.TEXT: About 100 workers cleaning up a plant rocked by fatal explosions last month were evacuated Saturday after a propane leak was discovered. Cincinnati police Sgt. Charles Horstman said the leak came from a large tank buried in the rubble of the BASF Corp. plant, but it was contained swiftly. No one was injured. A local propane company removed the tank Saturday afternoon. ``Everything is under control,'' Horstman said. ``This is the type of thing that is expected in a clean-up. Tanks containing all types of chemicals, including propane, are buried in the rubble. But they (workers) have procedures to avoid explosion.'' A series of blasts at the plant July 19 killed one worker and injured at least 68 others, many of them residents of the surrounding neighborhood who were cut by flying glass. Vapors from a cleaning solvent leaked from equipment used to mix chemicals, leading to the explosions and fire.

DOC.HEAD: Hike Marks Red Letter Day for Melville and Hawthorne Fans
DOC.TEXT: For the last 12 years, literary enthusiasts have hiked up a rocky mountain peak in the Berkshires to toast the first meeting of Nathaniel Hawthorne and Herman Melville. ``It's great fun and a wonderful way to mark the beginning of the most famous literary friendship in American history,'' Lea Newman said before Sunday's hike marking the 140th anniversary of the picnic on Monument Mountain at which the two authors met. The North Adams State College professor is president of the national Hawthorne Society and has written books about both authors. She said that as a result of the meeting, Melville entirely revised the novel that became his most famous, ``Moby Dick.'' Melville dedicated the novel to Hawthorne. Over the decades, the friendship between the young Melville and the older and already established Hawthorne has piqued literary scholars' interest and generated a flood of doctoral dissertations. ``They run the gamut from they were practicing homosexuals, even though both had wives and families, to they really hated each other,'' Newman said. ``Melville was by far the more flamboyant of the two, but I like to think it was a mutual relationship,'' she said. ``They did a lot of drinking, smoking and philosophizing together.'' And that's the cue taken by the literary fans who make the annual trek up Monument Mountain, she said. ``Whoever wants to, goes. You just have to be interested in either Melville or Hawthorne,'' she said. As they munch their picnic lunches, the hikers read an account of the 1850 picnic written by Melville's publisher, and William Cullen Bryant's poem ``Monument Mountain.'' For years Gloria McInerney, who helped start the jaunts sponsored by the Berkshire Historical Society, has hauled champagne up the mountain in her husband's black doctor's bag. Oliver Wendell Holmes, who was a doctor as well as a poet and writer, carried the bubbly up the mountain for his literary friends at the first picnic in 1850, Newman said. ``At one point Melville jumped out on a rock ledge and pretended he was on the top mast of a whaling ship,'' she said. ``It was after the champagne. ... Then it began to rain and they all scurried for cover under the rocks. That's happened to us some years, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Troops Seize U.S. Crew of Tanker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with shipping sources saying Iraq seized ships and crews of all vessels in Kuwaiti ports. Pickup 10th pvs, `The U.S. ...'
DOC.TEXT: Persian Gulf shipping sources said Saturday that Iraqi troops seized the crews of all ships docked at Kuwaiti ports and impounded the vessels. No reason for the measure was announced, but there has been at least one skirmish in a Kuwait port between a Kuwaiti naval patrol boat and Iraqi forces on shore. The crews seized were from many nations, the sources said, including at least 20 Americans and some Iranians. They were taken to an undisclosed location. ``All seamen irrespective of nationality were taken off the ships and are under Iraqi control, call it arrested, call it seized,'' said one shipping executive, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``There were plenty of ships of all nationalities'' in Kuwait waters at the time of the invasion, he said. The State Department cast doubt on the report of a seized U.S. crew. ``We did check into the story,'' said an official for the department's Kuwaiti task force, speaking on condition of anonymity. `We have no confirmation it is true.'' The name of the impounded American ship was not known. The original name given by the shipping sources for the ship _ Sea Wolf _ proved incorrect. The sources were checking to determine the correct name and ownership. The American ship was docked at Shuwaikh port, the main port of Kuwait City, said the sources. The gulf sources said two Iranian ships, Iran Hormuz and Safeer, were among those seized. In Washington on Friday, U.S. officials were trying to confirm rumors that other Americans might have been picked up by Iraqi troops, said one official. The U.S. diplomat in Baghdad reminded the Iraqis ``of their commitment to safeguard the safety of Americans,'' said State Department spokesman Richard Boucher. The commitment was given to U.S. diplomats in Baghdad during the early hours of the invasion, Boucher said. Iraq's ambassador to Washington, Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat, denied Friday that his country was holding any Americans following its invasion Thursday of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Rowdy Youths Beat Up On Moviegoers In Trendy Theater District
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of rowdy youths rampaged through the city's trendy Westwood theater district, beating up on moviegoers and pedestrians before police restored order early Saturday. Police initially said the incident didn't appear to be gang-related, but some of the assailants were described in reports as wearing gang-style clothing, said police Sgt. Rick Walker. Police closed off several blocks of the district near the University of California, Los Angeles. Officers made nine arrests. Three people received hospital treatment for minor injuries at the UCLA Medical Center and were released. Fights broke out and the youths pummeled pedestrians in a disturbance that began late Friday night and lasted until about 1:30 a.m. Saturday. From 400 to 600 youths participated in the melee, police said. ``Groups of teen-agers ran down the street and hit people for no apparent reason,'' said Sgt. Jeff Hanson. The Police Department sent dozens of officers to restore order, he said. Arrests were made for disturbing the peace, fighting, resisting arrest and illegal possession of a billy club, Hanson said. Westwood is the city's showcase theater district, but the trendy area has suffered periodic outbreaks of urban violence that afflicts the nation's second-largest city. In 1988, the slaying of a young woman caught in a gang crossfire prompted a citywide crackdown and focused nationwide attention on gang violence. In 1984, on the eve of the Summer Olympics, a crazed motorist drove onto a crowded Westwood sidewalk, killing a woman and seriously injuring 54 people.

DOC.HEAD: Mom Gets Hospital Discount for 12th Baby
DOC.TEXT: Do all things get cheaper by the dozen _ even children? Things are starting out that way for Vicki and Stephen Kesler. Valley View Hospital, where Mrs. Kesler had delivered six of her most recent children, provided its services free when she went there for her 12th. The child, Breanne Marie, was born in July. ``I thought it would be nice to do something for them because they had supported us so much over the years by having their children here,'' said John Johnson, the hospital administrator. Betty Mahan, a hospital spokeswoman, said Saturday she did not know how much the free services were worth. The couple have lived in Rifle, in western Colorado, for 10 years. He is an engineer and she is a homemaker. Mrs. Kesler said that anytime she has to fill out a form that asks about her employment, she writes, ``The Kesler home, as mother of 12. That should be sufficient.'' The children range to age 19.

DOC.HEAD: Trinidad Prime Minister Said He was Gagged, Beaten by Moslem Rebels
With AM-Trinidad-Uprising, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson said he was gagged, beaten and shot in the leg by Moslem fundamentalists who held him and other Cabinet ministers hostage in an attempt to overthrow the government. ``I was incensed at the manner in which we were treated,'' Robinson said in a television interview broadcast Friday night. It was his first public appearance since he was freed Tuesday. ``We were roughed up, made to lie face down on the floor, our pants down, legs tied ... unable to turn except with excrutiating pain,'' he said. Robinson, whose right cheek was badly bruised, spoke from his hospital bed to Trinidad television. Robinson spoke briefly of his five-day captivity inside the Parliament chamber and of the Moslem insurgents who held Cabinet members inside the building until they surrendered on Wednesday. ``I really do not wish to re-live those events at this particular moment,'' he said. ``But it is a fact I was gagged; that the gag was being pushed down my throat by a gun.'' Robinson said the gag thrust down his throat caused him to vomit. He said he was shot in the right leg after shouting ``Murderers! Torturers!'' and calling on his two-way radio to the armed forces to storm the building. Robinson said his leg ``is still in such a state that I cannot use it.'' The prime minister, who is losing his eyesight because of glaucoma, was released by the rebels Tuesday for health reasons. ``Now, I could have been out before on medical grounds, but I was convinced that my duty was to stay with my colleagues until the fate of all of us was certain,'' he said. Robinson did not say whether he signed an agreement with the rebels, who had insisted on his resignation and early elections as conditions for the release of the hostages. Besides Robinson and his Cabinet, the rebels also held 26 other hostages inside the Trinidad and Tobago Television station. Officials said an estimated 38 people were killed during the coup attempt. Maj. Dave Williams said the government is still trying to determine the count. Abu Bakr, the leader of the Moslem radicals, and more than 100 of his followers were being held at the Chaguaramas military headquarters. Lawyers were meeting Saturday to draw up charges against them that could include murder, treason and kidnapping. On Saturday, one of Bakr's followers was killed in a shootout with police. Police Inspector Winston Cooper said Njassane Omuaali, 21, was killed during an exchange of gunfire and was among a ``band of Moslems'' who fired on police. But Omuaali's grandmother, Elaine Bailey, said her grandson, the son of Bakr's first wife, was killed after police seized him. ``They grabbed him, kicked him down the stairs and killed him. They shot him,'' said Ms. Bailey, 75, in a telephone interview. She said Omuaali was scheduled to return Saturday to Washington, where he was studying finance and accounting at Howard University on a U.N. fellowship. In another development, Guyana sent 40 troops to Trinidad to assist authorities. More than 100 other troops from Jamaica and Barbados were assisting Trinidadian troops. A state of emergency remained in effect with a curfew in Port-of-Spain from 6 p.m. to 8 a.m. Soldiers and police were still combing the city for any explosives that could have been left behind in the coup attempt.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Man Tried To Blow Up Wife Rather Than Go Through Divorce
DOC.TEXT: A man tried to kill his wife with a car bomb because he had married another woman and didn't want to face a messy divorce, police said. ``It was a love triangle and rather than go through the bother of a divorce and its resulting complications, he elected to get rid of his first wife by making her go `boom,''' police Cmdr. Rodney C. Remblad said. Ronald M. Harnois, 40, and his second wife, Tammy Petrin, 20, were charged with conspiring to kill Joanne Harnois, 36, said Remblad. Mrs. Harnois was not injured when one of six pipe bombs attached to the undercarriage of her car exploded Wednesday night as she was driving through Woonsocket, police said. Petrin did not know Ronald Harnois was married until two months after she tied the knot with him in May 1989, Remblad said Mrs. Harnois, who married Ronald Harnois in 1983, did not know anything about the second marriage until Woonsocket police told her Friday. ``It was a total surprise ... when I told her,'' Remblad said. Harnois was charged with assault with intent to murder, conspiracy to commit murder, two counts of assault with a dangerous weapon, bigamy and filing a false document. He was arraigned Saturday and jailed in lieu of $500,000 bail. Petrin was charged with conspiracy to commit murder. She was arraigned and freed on $10,000 bail.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Cuts Money for Cambodia, Afghanistan, Sources Say
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Saturday approved an intelligence budget for 1991 that eliminates U.S. support for a covert war in Cambodia and sharply restricts money for rebels in Afghanistan, according to sources. The legislation, passed by voice vote in the early morning hours, authorizes U.S. intelligence activities around the world from spy satellites to secret operations. While most of the bill is secret, it is believed to authorize spending in the neighborhood of $30 billion. Most of it is hidden away in the Defense Department's budget. When the Senate Intelligence Committee approved the measure on June 28, it eliminated a $13 million program of covert aid to a rebel coalition fighting Cambodia's communist government, sources said. The move was prompted by congressional fears that the aid was primarily helping the ruthless Khmer Rouge, which is fighting alongside U.S.-sponsored rebel groups. Soon after the committee action, President Bush announced a series of policy changes in Cambodia reflecting similar concerns. The Khmer Rouge was responsible for the deaths of more than 1 million Cambodians during its 3{-year reign in the late 1970s. It was chased from power when neighboring Vietnam invaded. Reflecting a growing distaste on Capitol Hill for proxy conflicts in the Third World, the committee also slashed $100 million from the $300 million request by the administration for aid to the Mujahadeen rebels of Afghanistan, who are battling the Soviet-sponsored government in Kabul. Washington and Moscow have been trying to engineer an accord to end the conflict. The bill governs the budgets of the Central Intelligence Agency, the National Security Agency, which electronically spies on the world and Defense Intelligence Agency. It also provides for operations of the super-secret National Reconnaissance Office, which is building and launching a new generation of spy satellites. The House Intelligence Committee has deferred action on its version of the bill until Congress returns in September, hoping that by then policy decisions will have been made resolving disagreements on whether to fund conflicts like those in Cambodia, Afghanistan and Angola.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Congress Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, is a comparison of President Bush's proposed spending for various military weapons and the changes approved by the Senate on Saturday and the House Armed Services Committee on Tuesday.
DOC.HEAD: TOTAL DEFENSE BUDGET
DOC.TEXT: Bush proposed spending $307 billion on defense. The Senate approved a $289 billion defense bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1; The House panel adopted a $283 billion bill. Actual spending must be done through separate appropriations bills.
DOC.HEAD: B-2 BOMBER
DOC.TEXT: In January, Bush called for a total of $5.5 billion for five planes next year and advanced procurement money for 10 planes the following year. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced a revision in April that proposed two planes in 1991 and advanced procurement of six planes in 1992 at a cost of $4.6 billion. The Senate agreed with the revised plan. The House panel eliminated all procurement money and included only enough funds to cancel the program after the 15 planes currently under development.
DOC.HEAD: STRATEGIC DEFENSE INITIATIVE
DOC.TEXT: Bush proposed $4.7 billion for the program, commonly known as Star Wars. The Senate cut nearly $1 billion for a total of $3.7 billion. The House committee slashed close to $2 billion for a total of $2.9 billion.
DOC.HEAD: MX MISSILE
DOC.TEXT: The president's request included $1.6 billion for procurement and military construction costs and $548 million for research involved with moving the MX nuclear missile from fixed silos to railroad cars. The Senate approved only the research money. The House panel eliminated all money for the program and instead created a fund of $610 million for advanced missile work, calling on Bush to decide in 90 days what it should be used for, the MX or the unbuilt Midgetman.
DOC.HEAD: MIDGETMAN
DOC.TEXT: Bush proposed $202 million in research money for the mobile single-warhead missile. The Senate approved the request. The House committee eliminated the funds in favor of the $610 million strategic missile pot.
DOC.HEAD: V-22 OSPREY
DOC.TEXT: Bush's budget cancels the tilt-rotor aircraft that takes off like a helicopter but can fly like a plane. The Senate added $238 million in research money for the plane. The House committee included the research money as well as $165 million in procurement funds.
DOC.HEAD: PERSONNEL
DOC.TEXT: The administration proposed a reduction of about 38,000 from the current total of 2.1 million military personnel. The Senate adopted a cut of 100,000, including 50,000 in Europe. The House committee approved a reduction of 129,500.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Race Turns Negative As Young Shoots For Upset
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6 pvs. beginning `Then, in ...' with four grafs to UPDATE with campaign charges Saturday by Young and Miller. Picks up 7th graf pvs., `Race has ...'
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young's hopes to become Georgia's first black governor have been reduced to a long shot as the former Atlanta mayor tries to land a punch against Lt. Gov. Zell Miller, the white front-runner. The Democratic primary runoff in Georgia headlines elections Tuesday in four states, including a strong challenge to Kansas Gov. Mike Hayden in a Republican primary. Voters in Michigan and Missouri also will go to the polls. Young came out swinging shortly after his second-place finish in Georgia's July 17 primary, in which he suffered a weaker-than-expected showing among black voters. Young charged that Miller, who is chairman of a small bank, helped himself and key supporters by pushing banking laws through the Legislature. ``If it doesn't embarrass his supporters that he passed a tax bill and ended up with a bank, I don't know what would embarrass them,'' Young said during a campaign stop in DeKalb County Saturday. He added that he and Miller ``just live by a different standard. If I'd done that, I'd have been in jail.'' In the only negative advertising of the campaign, a Young television spot featured a Miller cutout bouncing across the screen while an announcer accused him of changing positions on taxes and abortion. On Saturday, Miller soaked up the cheers of a crowd of 20,000 as grand marshal of the Georgia Mountain Fair parade in Hiawassee, and criticized Young for mounting a negative campaign. ``The Andy Young I used to know would not engage in that type of mudslinging,'' Miller said. Two polls released last week showed Miller favored by more than 50 percent of likely Democratic voters and Young trailing by margins of from 17 to 20 percent. Race has been little discussed in the runoff race, and voter attention seems centered on Miller's proposal to legalize a state lottery. Young says he favors a referendum on a lottery, but Miller says Young lacks the conviction to see it through. Both favor no new restrictions on abortion and say they don't expect to need to raise taxes. Miller captured 41.2 percent of the vote against four challengers in the primary last month. Young placed second with 28.8 percent, securing a majority of the black vote but not with the same strength that Jesse Jackson showed during his 1988 presidential bid. Georgia law requires a candidate to win a majority of the vote to avoid a runoff. The winner of Tuesday's Democratic runoff will face GOP state Rep. Johnny Isakson, who easily won a four-man primary race. In recent weeks, Young has increased his efforts to woo the black vote _ an aspect of the campaign that critics said he had been neglecting. Miller, meanwhile, chided Young for negative advertising and continued pushing the lottery. He also summoned news reporters and camera crews to scenic locales _ a mountain stream, a race-car driver's shop, a high school science lab _ to record his thoughts on issues. The signs point to a disintegrating Young campaign, said Atlanta pollster Claibourne Darden. ``It's impossible for Andy to win at this point. ... One of the sure signs of a crumbling campaign is for the politician to openly and consistently cultivate his pocket vote _ the vote he should have in his pocket,'' Darden said. State Rep. Calvin Smyre, who is black, said Young's problems among blacks stem from the perception that ``he left his base'' and pitched his campaign toward whites. Blacks make up about 28 percent of the state's registered voters. Some critics contend that Young's effort to broaden his base by wooing urban, suburban and rural whites during the primary campaign left black voters and black elected officials feeling ignored. Also working against Young, Smyre said, was that ``Zell Miller has not had a bad record when it comes to issues which relate to the black community, and he's worked very well with black elected officials.'' Darden said Young's failure to score with more than about 15 percent of the state's white Democratic voters showed he failed to erase the liberal image he developed in public life. ``Andy had the blueprint handed to him from (the successful campaign last year of Virginia Gov. L. Douglas) Wilder, and Andy refused to go with it and take a walk down the middle,'' Darden said. In Kansas, Hayden faces a strong challenge in the GOP gubernatorial primary from a political newcomer. Challenger Nestor Weigand, a Wichita real estate executive, has capitalized on widespread increases in property taxes as a strong issue against Hayden. Former Gov. John Carlin appears to be well ahead of his two opponents, Joan Finney, the state treasurer, and Topeka preacher Fred Phelps, in seeking the Democratic nomination for governor. GOP Sen. Nancy Kassebaum faces only token opposition in the primary. In Michigan, U.S. Rep. Bill Schuette is favored over attorney Clark Durant to win the GOP Senate nomination. The winner will take on Democratic Sen. Carl Levin in November. Michigan's Democratic Gov. James Blanchard has no primary opposition. His opponent in November is expected to be state Senate Republican Leader John Engler, who has only token opposition in the primary. Missouri has no governor or Senate race this year.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Threatens Americans, Other Foreigners in Liberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with detail on Johnson killing, earlier appeal for Marines to intervene. Pickup 14th pvs, `Nigerian and...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is a report from a pool of journalists, including AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith.

Rebel leader Prince Johnson said Saturday he is ordering the arrest of all foreigners in Monrovia in hope of provoking international intervention in the nation's bloody civil war. Johnson, whose troops have occupied much of the city in their battle to oust President Samuel Doe, told reporters the roundup would begin Monday and single out American, British, Lebanese and Indian civilians at first. Four U.S. warships containing 4,000 Marines have been stationed off the Liberian coast for weeks, but Washington repeatedly has ruled out intervening. The forces could presumably evacuate the few hundred remaining Americans. Fighting has shifted considerably throughout the capital in recent days, and it was unclear whether foreigners in sections now under Johnson's control could move freely to areas controlled by Doe's troops. A Lebanese trader on Saturday became the first foreigner reported killed in the fighting, which began as an insurgency in December but which has since turned into vicious tribal war including massacres and torture. Mohamed Farhat, who had lived in the Liberian capital for more than 15 years, was reportedly shot and killed in front of his wife and four children when he tried to stop Doe's troops from looting his furniture store. Johnson himself shot and killed a Liberian wearing a Red Cross emblem Friday, claiming the man was selling rice that was supposed to be free, according to a Western journalist who saw the shooting. ``I want the world to know how we deal with profiteers,'' Johnson said before firing a burst from his AK-47 assault rifle, killing him instantly while another detained relief worker _ still handcuffed to the victim _ said rice vouchers were being sold to prevent a stampede. The victim, whose name was not known, was arrested with Jacques Monthouroy, a Frenchman working for the U.S. Catholic Relief Services. Monthouroy was released after the U.S. Embassy vouched for him. The killing has stopped rice distribution in Monrovia. The fighting in the civil war is centered in Monrovia, where forces loyal to Johnson are trying to topple Doe, whose troops were defending Doe's fortified mansion. Forces loyal to a rival rebel leader, Charles Taylor, had been stopped by Doe's troops east of the capital. At least 2,000 foreigners, mostly Lebanese and Indian traders, still live in the embattled capital. Besides the Americans, the Westerners include a few dozen Britons. It was not clear whether Johnson's order included the many diplomats who remain in Monrovia, including U.S. Ambassador Peter de Vos and British Ambassador Michael Gore. ``I have decided to give a rigid order to arrest all foreign nationals,'' Johnson told reporters at his field headquarters in the capital's Bushrod Island. Those arrested would be held at a secret location, he said. ``They will not be harmed,'' Johnson promised. ``I hope this will create an international incident, so foreign troops can come in to intervene,'' he said. In an interview Monday, Johnson said he had telephoned the deputy chief of the U.S. mission, Dennis Jett, to ask for direct intervention by the Marines cruising offshore. The Marines are on standby to evacuate Americans and some other foreign nationals from the besieged capital if it becomes necessary. Nigerian and other foreign troops would be welcome in Liberia as part of an international force, he said, ``but not on their own initiative.'' West African leaders are scheduled to discuss sending a joint flotilla to enforce peace in Liberia at a summit in Banjul, Gambia, on Monday, according to Nigerian government sources in Lagos. Three Nigerian naval ships, including one armed with missiles and heavy guns, came to Monrovia last week to evacuate Nigerians in the capital but were turned away by Johnson's men. The Nigerian sources in Lagos said the ships, now in Freetown, capital of neighboring Sierra Leone, could form the core of a West African task force that would include ships from Guinea and Sierra Leone. As Johnson spoke to reporters, he received word his forces were being attacked by Taylor's rebels. Johnson said he had no more information about the attack, which came two days after Taylor vowed to defeat Johnson before assaulting Doe's mansion. About 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have died in the rebellion in this nation founded in 1847 by freed American slaves. The rebels accuse Doe, who took power in a 1980 coup, of corruption and human rights abuses. But massacres have been carried out by both the rebels and government forces. Last week, government troops killed up to 600 people sheltered in a refugee compund in Monrovia. Taylor said he believed his father was among those killed in the sanctuary of St. Peter's Lutheran Church. There was no independent confirmation of the claim.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says It Will Restore Ties With Britain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to ADD background on British hostages, businessman held in Iran, Britain wanting Rushdie death sentence lifted; FIXES typo in 4th graf; RECASTS lead. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani said Saturday that Tehran is ready to restore ties with Britain, severed over Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death call on author Salman Rushdie. Britain said obstacles remain to restoring ties. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted an Iranian official as saying that recent remarks by British foreign secretary Douglas Hurd had made resumption of ties possible. Rafsanjani had instructed the Foreign Ministry to proceed with restoration of ties following a meeting of the National Security Council on Saturday, IRNA said. In London, the Foreign Office said: ``We have noted the (IRNA) report with interest. We will be studying it. Nevertheless, obstacles to better relations remain. We look for a substantive gesture of goodwill from the Iranian authorities.'' Britain has demanded that Iran lift the death sentence against Rushdie, an Indian-born Moslem who is a British citizen. It has also sought Iran's help in obtaining the release of four British hostages believed to be held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups in Lebanon and a British businessman imprisoned in Tehran for espionage. Hussein Musavian, director-general for West European affairs at the Iranian Foreign Ministry, said Hurd's remarks met conditions set by an Iranian parliamentary ruling last year for resumption of with Britain. Hurd said in a British Foreign Office letter released Wednesday that his government has no wish to insult Islam and it understands that Rushdie's novel, ``The Satanic Verses,'' offended Moslems. ``The British government had nothing to do with the publishing of `The Satanic Verses,''' Hurd said in his letter. The letter did not specifically condemn the book, but Musavian's remarks indicated that Iran was prepared to accept it as a condemnation. IRNA quoted him as saying that the letter was an ``adequate response to the demand set by the Majlis,'' or parliament. ``The members unanimously agreed that the Majlis demand has been met with, thus, removing the legal obstacle in the way of resumption of political ties between the two countries,'' IRNA quoted Musavian as saying. The March 1989 ruling banned any restoration of ties with London unless the British government condemned Rushdie's book, ``The Satanic Verses,'' and pledged to respect Islam. In February 1989, Khomeini issued the death call on Rushie, saying that the novel offended Moslems worldwide. Many Moslems around the world had protested the Rushdie has been in hiding since. The resumption of ties could be a major blow for Rafsanjani's hard-line opponents, headed by former interior minister, Ali Akbar Mohtashemi. They consider confronting the West a cornerstone of the 1979 Islamic Revolution. For Rafsanjani, who has been moving to circumvent his opponents and restore ties with the West in order to attract foreign investment and technology for Iran's sluggish economy, the move is an important victory. Rushdie's book caused an uproar in February 1989 when Khomeini called for the Indian-born British writer's head for insulting Islam in his novel. Tehran severed ties with Britain after London objected to the call and supported Rushdie on grounds he was exercising his freedom of speech. Hurd's remarks, and Tehran's subsequent move to restore ties, is part of behind-the-scenes dealings between Iranian and British officials, reliable sources say. A source said that Iranian and British officials had met ``more than once at a Mediterranean capital'' he declined to name. The sources spoke on condition they not be identified further. The British government had been seeking to restore ties in order to try to gain Iranian help in freeing the four Britons among the 16 Westerners missing in Lebanon. They are Church of England envoy Terry Waite, journalist John McCarthy and retired pilot Jack Mann. Britain is also seeking the release of Belfast teacher Brian Keenan who has dual British-Irish citizenship. The government has also been pressing for the release of Roger Cooper, a British businessman imprisoned in Iran since 1985. He was sentenced earlier this year to 10 years in prison for spying.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Criticizes Release as Gilbert Settles at Home
DOC.TEXT: The judge who sentenced Roswell Gilbert to a life prison term for killing his ailing wife said the retired engineer did not deserve clememcy because it was an act of murder, not mercy. ``Roswell held himself above the law. Not one of us has that right, and punishment is appropriate,'' Circuit Judge Thomas M. Coker Jr. said in a letter to Gov. Bob Martinez. The letter was released Friday. State officials commuted Gilbert's life sentence Wednesday and freed the ailing 81-year-old inmate Thursday, after he had spent more than five years in prison. Coker objected to descriptions of the 1985 shooting death of Gilbert's 72-year-old wife, Emily, who suffered from Alzheimer's disease, as a mercy killing. ``It is indeed my sincerest hope that the media will eventually cease and desist from referring to this homicide as a mercy killing,'' the judge wrote. ``There can be no serious question that it was murder, and not mercy.'' A television movie of the killing and trial starring Robert Young as Gilbert was titled ``Mercy or Murder?'' ``Nowhere in the record of this case is there any suggestion that Mrs. Gilbert ever asked her husband to kill her,'' Coker said. Back in the condominium he shared with his wife, Gilbert said he thought of her but was determined to return to live there. ``It's easy to come back. This is my home,'' he said Friday. ``It doesn't bother me to be alone because I know my friends are near me.'' Gilbert ate Chinese food and a welcome-home cake and drank champagne and some Jack Daniels ``in moderation'' as a stream of friends and acquaintances welcomed him back. ``I always have Emily in the back of my mind,'' Gilbert said. ``I grieve for my wife, but I'm going to have to deal with it.''

DOC.HEAD: Armenian Parliament to Consider Independence on Monday
DOC.TEXT: The Armenian parliament elected a pro-independence nationalist as the republic's president Saturday as it prepared to debate whether to begin breaking away from the Soviet Union. The election came just days before a Kremlin deadline for about 40,000 members of pro-nationalist Armenian paramilitary units to turn in their weapons or face forcible confiscation by Soviet troops. The Armenian parliament has already refused to comply with the order. The republic's parliament was scheduled to consider an independence resolution Monday, said legislator Raphael Popoyan. If Armenia adopts the resolution, it would become the fifth of the 15 Soviet republics to move toward complete separation from the Soviet Union. Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and Georgia have already taken such steps. However, unlike the other independence-seeking republics, Armenia is locked in a deadly ethnic and territorial dispute with the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan. The conflict turned into civil war for several weeks in January before Soviet troops cracked down. In the past, Armenia sought affiliation with czarist Russia, a fellow Christian nation, as a means of defense against its traditional enemies, the Moslem Azerbaijanis and Turks. The new Armenian president elected Saturday is Levon Ter-Petrosyan, a leader of the Armenian National Movement. Ter-Petrosyan spent six months in jail last year for helping organize mass demonstrations against Azerbaijani control of the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. Ter-Petrosyan defeated Armenian Communist Party chief Vladimir Movsisyan by 140 votes to 76, Popoyan said. On Monday, the Armenian parliament will also consider a less radical measure calling for ``sovereignty'' within the Soviet Union, Popoyan said. Similar autonomy resolutions proclaiming a republic's right to overrule national laws have already been approved by eight Soviet republics. The independence proposal calls for specific steps toward achieving separation from the Soviet Union, Popoyan said. It does not follow the example of Lithuania, which declared immediate independence, with the details to be worked out later. Lithuania's defiance led to a 10-week oil and gas embargo by Kremlin. It ended a month ago, when the Lithuanians agreed to freeze the declaration for 100 days, starting from the date the Soviet Union begins negotiations on independence. Lithuanian and Soviet officials have been meeting regularly to set up those talks. Popoyan said the victory of Ter-Petrosyan, a supporter of the independence proposal, indicated the parliament probably will support complete separation from the Soviet Union. Tensions have been rising in Armenia over Thursday's deadline for turning in weapons as fears grow of a confrontation between the Soviet army and the Armenian paramilitary groups. The situation worsened when the army reported 100 flame-throwers had been stolen from a weapons depot this past week and launched a massive search for the thieves. Popoyan said the flame-throwers were turned in anonymously on Saturday, as the Armenian parliament ordered, after Ter-Petrosyan's election was announced. The Armenian parliament has stated it will take responsibility for maintaining the peace and controlling weaponry on its own territory, Popoyan said. The Baltic republics started their independence drives with sovereignty declarations two years ago. But sovereignty became a major issue when Russia, the largest of the 15 republics with half the country's population, also claimed the right to overrule the Kremlin. The Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Byelorussia and Moldavia also have declared sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven Americans Believed Accounted For in Iraq
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 6th graf, Iraq's U.S. ..., to DELETE second sentence. Both US and Iraq say 11 Americans are accounted for.
DOC.TEXT: Three American oil workers who had been missing since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait have turned up in Baghdad apparently unharmed, the State Department said Saturday. An official said U.S. authorities were told that eight additional Americans among a group of 24 Westerners also have been taken to the Iraqi capital. As of late Saturday Iraqi time, the eight had not been contacted by U.S. consular officials but were reported to have checked in to a Baghdad hotel, the official said. He added that the two groups may account for all Americans thought to have been missing since the invasion Thursday. The names of the Americans were not available from the State Department. Efforts were being made to contact their relatives in the United States. Iraq's U.S. ambassador, Mohammed Sadiq Mashat, said the 11 were found and are in Baghdad. Mashat said he hadn't heard reports attributed to Persian Gulf shipping sources that 20 Americans had been seized off a vessel in Kuwait. The State Department also said it could not confirm the reports. There was no information on the nationalities of the 16 other Westerners among the group of 24. Initially, the State Department had thought 14 Americans were unaccounted for, but the official indicated there may have been only 11. Saturday's disclosure came 24 hours after the State Department demanded that Iraq account for the missing Americans ``as soon as possible on an immediate basis.'' The Americans had been working at three different sites for various oil companies in Kuwait. During the early hours of the invasion, Iraqi authorities had given U.S. officials assurances that Americans in Kuwait would not be harmed. On Friday, Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly summoned Iraq's ambassador and demanded an accounting of the missing Americans. An estimated 3,000 Americans were in Kuwait at the time of the invasion. On Friday, John Mika, vice president of the Santa Fe International Corp. in Alhambra, Calif., said the company had been informed that eight of its employees were ``detained by Iraqi troops.'' Among them were six Americans, one Englishman and one Canadian. One of the missing Americans, according to his family, was Donald Whatley of Shreveport, La., a Sante Fe employee. Another was Charles Amos, 56, a Santa Fe employee whose family resides in Gilmer, Texas. An American woman who fled to Saudi Arabia from Kuwait had confirmed that Whatley and Amos were taken into custody by Iraqi troops. The others were identified as Rainard L. Walterscheid, of Dallas; Gary Carr, hometown unknown; Bobby G. Parker, of Vidor, Texas; and B.J. Tinch, originally from Nashville, Tenn.

DOC.HEAD: Founder of Famous Racing Car Company Dies
DOC.TEXT: Ettore Maserati, a founder and guiding force of the famed racing car company, died Saturday. He was 96. His death was reported by the ANSA news agency. With one of his five brothers, Alfieri, Maserati produced his first racing car in 1926. Maseratis went on to become a power in racing with victories in the Indianapolis 500 in 1939 and 1940, and the 12-hours of Sebring in 1953. In 1937, the company was bought by the Orsi group in Modena, where Maserati worked for 10 years as technical director. After leaving Orsi, he and his brothers founded a new car-manufacturing company in 1947 called ``Osca Maserati.'' Ettore Maserati retired in 1966 at the age of 72, the last surviving brother. The Maserati company is now based in Modena, controlled by Argentine-born Alejandro de Tomaso. ``He was the last survivor of that group of avant-garde super-technicians of the 1930s,'' de Tomaso said of Maserati. ``Today one talks a lot about overall quality, but in those days the Maseratis controlled their creations one by one, piece by piece.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq Rdp Bjt
Japanese Implored to Stop Importing Iraqi Oil
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alphonse D'Amato implored the No. 2 official in the Japanese Embassy Saturday to urge his government in Tokyo to back President Bush's call for a worldwide boycott of Iraqi oil and other exports. D'Amato, R-N.Y., a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, invited Takayuki Kimura to his Senate office to hand over a letter signed by all 100 members of the Senate. The letter, addressed to Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, said, ``We urge that the government of Japan take official action against Iraq, including blocking Iraqi assets and prohibiting import into Japan of all goods and services of Iraqi origin, and make these sanctions both mandatory and comprehensive.'' Frank Coleman, a spokesman for D'Amato, said that Kimura, the deputy chief of mission at the embassy, accepted the letter but was noncomittal in his statements. ``He said that Kaifu had talked to Bush, and that no options were precluded,'' Coleman said of Kimura. ``The DCM said he couldn't say specifically (what course of action would be taken) but that an announcement would be made.'' A White House statement issued after a Bush meeting with top advisers at Camp David, Md., Saturday said that Japan, along with West Germany and France, had decided to join the United States in freezing Kuwaiti assets in order to stop Iraq from confiscating them. But Kaifu has said that Japan would impose sanctions against Iraq only if the United Nations votes to do so. D'Amato's office said that Japan gets 8 percent of its imported oil from Iraq and 5.9 percent from Kuwait. Describing his meeting with Kimura, D'Amato said he told the envoy that the Japanese ``should understand the depth of feeling in the United States Senate on this issue.'' The senator said in a telephone interview that ``if they deal in their own self-interest and aren't willing to share in the burden (of boycotting Iraqi oil), I think that portends a very poor future for U.S.-Japanese relations.'' ``It seemed to me that his indications were very positive,'' D'Amato said, ``and I told him to stop this business of waiting to see what the world community does.'' D'Amato said he told Kimura the Japanese should understand that Iraq's occupation of Kuwait presents a ``window of opportunity'' for Tokyo to demonstrate its willingness to cooperate with the United States as an ally on difficult national security questions.

DOC.HEAD: Miami Tourism Begins to Pay for Snub to Mandela
DOC.TEXT: The snub that city leaders gave Nelson Mandela over his praise for Fidel Castro is beginning to cost Miami convention bookings by national black organizations. The National Bar Association, a group of black lawyers with about 2,000 delegates, decided last week to move its 1993 convention from Miami to another city. A leading black fraternity, Omega Psi Phi, canceled plans for a 1991 meeting in Miami. Another fraternity, Alpha Phi Alpha, considered canceling its Miami Beach convention this year but stayed because of longstanding booking obligations. City officials refused to issue a proclamation in honor of Mandela, the South African anti-apartheid leader, when he visited June 28. Cuban exiles were offended by Mandela's show of gratitude to Castro for his support when Mandela was imprisoned. Jewish leaders also were upset over Mandela's embrace of Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Some local black leaders have endorsed the boycott, citing the Mandela flap as well as alleged employment discrimination against blacks in the tourism industry and the arrest of Haitian demonstrators during a violent scuffle with police July 5. ``We're very concerned,'' said Mary English, spokeswoman for the Greater Miami Convention & Visitors Bureau. ``For the last several years, we have put a great deal of emphasis on working with black groups. They offer tremendous business potential for the community. It's frustrating to see this happening now, but we understand their concerns.'' Merrett Stierheim, the convention bureau's president, sent letters to black leaders assuring them the tourism agency will back an affirmative action plan. Stierheim also asked black leaders to reconsider the boycott because ``it is injurious to the economy of this community and hurts all people, including blacks.'' The bureau has been running an aggressive campaign to lure more blacks, who represent 17 percent of Dade County's visitors, and up to now had been succeeding. Nine major black organizations had scheduled conventions in Miami this year, up from five in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes $28 Billion Appropriations Bill
With AM-Congress Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Saturday passed a roughly $28 billion transportation appropriations bill for the new year, including money for upgrading the nation's airports, mass transit systems and Amtrak. ``There can be no prosperity without mobility,'' Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., said in hailing the legislation, passed by voice vote shortly before the Senate recessed for its August vacation. Lautenberg, chairman of the Senate Appropriations transportation subcommittee, said the measure, which will now have to be reconciled with a slightly less expensive House version, ``takes some critical steps'' to improve America's network of highways, bridges and public works facilities. The bill provides $13.8 billion for highway construction, $8.08 billion for the Federal Aviation Administration, $3.3 billion for mass transit facilities and just over $3 billion for the Coast Guard. The appropriation for the Coast Guard includes nearly $53 million for oil spill cleanup activities. The measure includes a provision seeking to tie federal highway funds to efforts by states to suspend the licenses of drivers convicted of drug-related offenses. ``Suspending the drivers' licenses of drug offenders is an effective weapon in the war on drugs,'' said Lautenberg, who sponsored the provision. ``It will make people, especially young people, think twice before getting involved with drugs.'' The measure also includes $125 million to switch from diesel to electric power the rail line between New Haven, Conn. and Boston _ a move that supporters said would shorten commuters' travel time by two hours.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Of People Apply For Visit To North Korea
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of South Koreans lined up before dawn Saturday for passes that would allow them to travel to North Korea during a proposed five-day border opening. President Roh Tae-woo made the proposal July 20, and South Korean officials said it could promote unification of the two countries. However, North Korea has effectively rejected the border-opening proposal. The Seoul government decided to receive applications from would-be travelers despite the North Korean rejection, apparently to put pressure on North Korea for the unprecedented border opening. Saturday was the first day for government offices throughout the country to begin accepting applications. Government officials said they believed more than 10,000 people submitted applications during the day. Officials predicted the total applications would reach 1 million before Wednesday, when officials stop accepting them. The Seoul government has said all 42 million South Koreans can cross the border if North Korea guarantees their safe return. North Korea made no direct mention of the applications being received in South Korea on Saturday. But its official Korean Central News Agency said in a report monitored in Tokyo that Roh's border opening is ``a deception.'' The agency reported a commentary carried by the North's Communist party organ, the Rodong Shinmun, criticizing Seoul's refusal to receive a letter concerning Pyongyang's plan to dispatch a team to meet a jailed South Korean radical student. North Korea had earlier said it planned to send a delegation across the border during the five-day period to ``console'' Im Su-kyong, a 22-year-old South Korean woman student jailed for making an illegal trip the North last year. ``Judging from the fact that they refuse to receive even a letter addressed to Roh Tae-woo ..., it is clear that his talk about `grand exchanges of people' and `free travel' is a lie,'' the report said. The two Koreas have been bitter rivals since the division of their peninsula in 1945. They fought the 1950-53 Korean War. Their border is tightly sealed and there is no mail or other means of communications between them. Most of the applicants Saturday were elderly North Koreans who want to see relatives left behind when they fled the Communist state during the Korean War. There are about 10 million separated family members in both sides of Korea. Some came in groups but most applied individually. The one-page application asks for name, occupation and the place to be visited, plus two headshot photographs. ``I feel crazy whenever I think about my relatives left in the North,'' said Mrs. Lee Sung-sil, 69, who fled the North 40 years ago. ``My parents must have died, but some of my brothers and sisters may probably alive.''

DOC.HEAD: Sheriff Forms Group to Excuse Officers from Abortion Protest Duty
DOC.TEXT: Police and sheriff's deputies have formed an anti-abortion group that will press for a law allowing officers to refuse duty protecting clinics. The local group is led by Nueces County Sheriff James T. Hickey, who said he wouldn't send deputies to help police clear clinic entrances because ``I would be aiding in murder of babies if I did.'' Officers for Life is apparentlhy the first of its kind in the country, said Ron DeLord, president of the Combined Law Enforcement Agencies of Texas. Elva Bustamante, director of New Women's Clinic, targeted by anti-abortion protestors, said she was astounded that officers would form such a group. ``This is outrageous,'' she said. ``I can't believe this, I really can't ... Maybe they should find another means of earning a living.'' The city of 230,000 has become a focus of growing anti-abortion activism. The Roman Catholic bishop on June 1 excommunicated Rachel Vargas, director of Reproductive Services Inc., the other clinic in the city that performs abortions, and warned Bustamante she could be excommunicated. A group called Body of Christ Rescue has held more than 20 protests at the clinics since November. At one rally, Sheriff Hickey prayed on the sidewalk while police pulled his wife and other protesters from a doorway. Petitioners obtained a referendum on the November ballot that would create a city charter amendment declaring human life begins at conception. The declaration would have no bearing on the law. Ruben Rodriguez, a sheriff's department communications supervisor, said about 12 police and deputies attended Officers for Life's first meeting on July 26. ``We want to unite law enforcement and public safety personnel to share and discover the truth about life in the womb,'' said Rodriguez, who wears a brass replica of the feet of a 10-week-old fetus on the collar of his uniform. Hickey said most law enforcement officers are opposed to abortion and that legislating a ``conscience clause'' would simply give them a right already granted hospital employees and other medical personnel. DeLord said he doubted the state Legislature would pass a law permitting officers to be selective about which laws they enforce. ``I'm supportive of their right to have a group, and the right to legislate,'' he said. ``...But they have to set aside their personal beliefs to enforce the law.'' Police Chief Henry Garrett said the issue had been raised only once, by an officer who had friends among the anti-abortion protestors. He said he wouldn't object to his officers joining Officers for Life. ``If they have their personal opinion and want to express it by being a member of that group, that's OK, as long as it doesn't affect their ability to do the job,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Approves Five-Year AIDS Assistance Bill
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Saturday gave final congressional approval to compromise legislation supplying more than $4 billion over five years to help AIDS sufferers and their health-care providers. The legislation, which now goes to the White House, was especially designed to assist 15 U.S. metropolitan areas with the most AIDS cases and San Juan, Puerto Rico. The House approved its version of the bill earlier Saturday, and the measure garnered the approval of the Senate by voice vote just before that chamber adjourned for its summer recess at the dinner hour. ``America responded within days to the California earthquake last fall. We have pledged hundreds of billions of dollars to rescue the savings and loan industry,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. ``AIDS is a comparable disaster, and now we begin to respond accordingly.'' The bill authorizes nearly $900 million per year in AIDS spending for five years. The bill authorizes a total of $275 million in fiscal 1991 and fiscal 1992, to be divided among the cities, and ``such sums as may be necessary'' through fiscal 1995. A similar amount would be authorized for distribution to the states for improving quality and availability of care for people with the AIDS-causing HIV virus. A major portion of the money would go as direct aid to cities hardest hit by AIDS to help provide health and social services. The first half of the money, about $137 million, would be divided among the 16 areas singled out for special assistance. The other half would be redistributed in fiscal 1992 based on the number of AIDS cases at that time. They are Atlanta, $3.8 million; Boston, $3 million; Chicago, $4.2 million; Dallas, $3 million; Fort Lauderdale, Fla., $2.7 million; Houston, $5.6 million; Jersey City, N.J., $2.8 million; Los Angeles, $13 million; Miami, $5.3 million; New York, $51.3 million; Newark, $6.3 million; Philadelphia, $3.6 million; San Diego, $2.4 million; San Francisco, $20.4 million; San Juan, P.R., $4.1 million and the District of Columbia, $5.3 million. Other sections of the bill provide grants to the states, health centers or other health care providers for testing and diagnostic services, outpatient treatment, and for AIDS research. The legislation was named in honor of Ryan White, the Kokomo, Ind., teen-ager whose long battle with AIDS drew worldwide attention. Jean McGuire, executive director of the AIDS Action Council, which lobbied for the bill, urged President Bush not to veto the bill and ``sign this significant contribution to a `kinder and gentler' national AIDS policy.'' The House approved the original version on June 13 by a vote or 408-14. The Senate approved its version May 16 by a 95-4 vote. It was sponsored in the House by Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., and in the Senate by Kennedy and Orrin Hatch, R-Utah.

DOC.HEAD: Sheriffs Lament Lack Of State Funding For Marijuana Raids
