DOC.TEXT: While federal agents prowled remote mountain areas on a sweep to uproot marijuana this weekend, local sheriffs were forced to send their eradication teams home because of funding problems. Mendocino County is disbanding its marijuana team on Sunday because the state has not renewed its funding. The sheriffs of Trinity and Humboldt counties plan to dissolve their teams within weeks unless they get state help. State and federal agents last Sunday began ``Operation Green Sweep,'' which they said was the largest anti-marijuana operation ever conducted on public land. The drug hunt in the King Range National Conservation Area in Humboldt County also was the first in the continental United States to use Army troops. But some local sheriffs refused to participate and characterized the operation as political grandstanding, saying that local programs were a more consistent way of reducing cultivations in the area about 180 miles northeast of San Francisco. ``It really shows a lack of good planning and vision to waste all our money on some kind of a flash-in-the-pan military exercise,'' said U.S. Rep. Doug Bosco, D-Sebastopol. This area of Northern California has been dubbed the ``Emerald Triangle'' because the emerald-green pot plants thrive during the long, sunny growing season, while growers enjoy the privacy of large empty spaces. Since 1984, the state has provided Mendocino, Trinity and Humboldt counties with money to patrol the mountains and yank the weeds, valued at up to $3,000 each. Last year the counties received a total of $2.2 million. Staff members at the state Office of Criminal Justice Planning said the sheriffs should know within about a week how much money is available in the new state budget. But it could be September before they get any guarantees. Last year, criminal justice officials advanced the money for the pot raids but were forced to make cuts in other programs after the Legislature refused to reimburse their budget. Mendocino County supervisors have made sure that won't happen with local funds, and Mendocino Sheriff Tim Shea said he would disband his nine-person marijuana eradication team on Sunday. ``I'm afraid we're going to be right back in the same situation we were in 1984,'' said Shea, referring to a year in which of increases in drug-related killings and assaults. Trinity County Sheriff Paul Schmidt said he was spending local dollars to fight pot growing, but could do that for only another week or two. Humboldt Sheriff Dave Renner said he would keep his team on duty for a few more weeks.

DOC.HEAD: 8 More Bottles of Columbian Drink Test Positive for Cocaine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Colombian in lead and 8th grafp
DOC.TEXT: Tests found cocaine in eight more bottles of a Colombian soft drink and officials Saturday warned consumers not to drink the beverage, which already caused one case of critical poisoning. The eight bottles of Pony Malta de Bavaria that tested positive for dissolved cocaine Friday had been collected by government officials from a distributor who supplies the drink to mobile vendors for streetside sales. Each of the 6.16-ounce bottles contained lethal dosages of up to 10 grams of cocaine, said George Niblack, environmental supervisor for the Dade County Health Department. Niblack said the lethal dosage was 1 gram. A Miami-area man, Maximo Rene Mendez, 25, drank from a bottle of the soft drink on July 26 and suffered convulsions and cardiac arrest. He was still in a coma Saturday. Two bottles from a lot Menendez had purchased also tested positive for the drug _ one contained 54 grams and the other 37 grams. Drug traffickers frequently smuggle cocaine by dissolving it in liquids. The soft drink, popular in the Hispanic community, is similar to a non-alcoholic beer. It is manufactured by Cerveceria Bavaria S.A., based in Bogota, Colombia. The company has undertaken a voluntary recall of the product, and some of the wholesalers that distribute the drink in Miami have recalled it, said Clifford S. Purdy, an investigator for the Miami office of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Distribution of the suspected lot of the drink has been limited to south Florida. ``I'm afraid there may be still some out there,'' Niblack said.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Car Collision Leads to Big Cocaine Discovery
DOC.TEXT: Police waited and waited for a driver of a van to return after a minor accident Saturday. Then they found out why he didn't _ the van was stuffed with $12 million worth of cocaine. Metro-Dade police officer Donald Blocker estimated 1,000 pounds of cocaine were packaged in sealed cocaine bricks inside 40 cardboard boxes filling the back of the van. ``The accident was so minor that it probably would have been resolved by the two parties without anything being written'' by police, Blocker said. ``It looked like the person just panicked.'' The van had rolled backward into a car, causing no damage to either vehicle, Blocker said. A police officer was driving by at the time and the driver left, telling witnesses he had to call his uncle. ``He just walked away because no one suspected that he wouldn't return,'' the officer said. ``But after a period of time, they said, `Where is he?' By that time, he had gone. He escaped.''

DOC.HEAD: Seoul, Moscow Agree On Economic Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: South Korea and the Soviet Union, once bitter enemies, have agreed to broad economic cooperation as a step toward formal diplomatic ties, newspapers reported Saturday. The agreement was made at two days of government-level talks that ended in Moscow on Friday, the newspapers in Seoul said in reports from Moscow. The talks were arranged after Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent a letter to President Roh Tae-woo last month calling for joint efforts to help promote economic and other relations between the two countries. The two leaders met in San Francisco in early June in the first encounter of top leaders of the two countries, which do not recognize one another. The Soviet Union is a close ally and arms provider for Seoul's rival, Communist North Korea. Both sides agreed to continue the negotiations in Seoul next month, the newspapers said. Seoul newspapers, quoting Korean delegates in Moscow, said the Moscow talks laid a solid foundation for an early normalization of relations between the two countries. During the two-day talks, both sides presented details of projects or cooperation they want to promote in 11 sectors, including fishery, forestry, electronics, aviation, steel and metals, natural gas and petrochemicals, the newspapers said. The Soviet Union also presented a list of consumer goods it wants from South Korea, the newspapers said. South Korean delegates said in Seoul before departing that they would offer to help ease an acute shortage of consumer goods in the Soviet Union such as soap, shoes, toothpaste, radio and television sets and other electronic items. Government sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, indicated that South Korea may provide loans for the Soviet Union to import Korean consumer goods. Despite the lack of diplomatic relations, Seoul and Moscow have greatly strengthened economic and other non-political links in recent years, especially after the 1988 Olympics in Seoul. Establishing formal ties with the Soviet Union is a prime goal of South Korea's policy of improving ties with socialist and communist nations. Seoul officials believe such ties would help open North Korea's closed society and thus ease tension on the Korean peninsula.

DOC.HEAD: Showers Across the Midwest, South
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Rainshowers and thunderstorms swept much of the Midwest, South, and the Rockies on Saturday, with unseasonably hot weather in the Pacific Northwest. Rain extended from eastern Michigan through Ohio and Indiana to Tennessee, in southern Illinois and Missouri, Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas. Showers and thunderstorms also reached from Florida across Alabama to western South Carolina and North Carolina.. There were scattered showers and thunderstorms from southeast New Mexico across the southern and central Rockies into northwest Wyoming. Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included almost an inch at Apalachicola, Fla. and .82 inches at Indianapolis. High temperatures in the Northwest included 106 at Medford, Ore., and 98 in Portland, which broke by one degree a record set in 1952. It was 89 at 1 p.m. in Seattle. The mercury climbed to 100 degrees in Corpus Christi, Texas, breaking the record high for the date. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 57 degrees at Crescent City, Calif., to 104 degrees at Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada. The low temperature for the nation was 32 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Mohawk Protesters Block St. Lawrence Seaway
DOC.TEXT: About 250 protesters angry about a Mohawk blockade occupied a drawbridge over the St. Lawrence Seaway for five hours Saturday, blocking passage of ships. Police finally cleared away the anti-Mohawk demonstrators, who were also demanding more action by the federal government to settle an armed standoff elsewhere between Quebec provincial police and Mohawks. The Mohawks have blocked the Mercier Bridge for more than three weeks. The bridge closure has forced long detours for people traveling across the St. Lawrence River between Montreal and its south shore suburbs. Indians from the Kahnawake Mohawk reserve near Montreal have blocked the bridge in sympathy with Mohawks in the town of Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, who have been engaged in an armed standoff with provincial police. The standoff in Oka began July 11 after police rushed a barricade set up by the Mohawks to stop the expansion of the local golf course on land they claim is theirs. An officer was killed in the gun battle that followed, but it is still not clear if he was shot by Indians or fellow officers. The anti-Mohawk demonstrators blocked a drawbridge over the Ste-Catherine locks on the St. Lawrence Seaway, which connects the river with the Great Lakes. The Ste-Catherine locks near Montreal are entirely in Canadian territory. During the afternoon protest, two freighters as well as several pleasure boats were held up on the Great Lakes side of the drawbridge. Normally between 10 and 30 ships pass through the locks daily, most of them heading for Ottawa. About 50 provincial police equipped with clubs arrived on the scene to catcalls from the demonstrators, but the crowd ignored a police order to disperse within five minutes. Police then lined up three abreast and pushed the crowd off the drawbridge. One man with a cane fell to the ground in apparent convulsions and was taken away by ambulance. ``It was a good demonstration because it affected international opinion (by blocking an international shipping lane),'' said the demonstration's leader Jean-Pierre Potvin, the president of the local Chamber of Commerce. ``It didn't bother the ships' crews, they just did a bit of housecleaning.'' The protesters _ mainly from Montreal's South Shore suburbs _ said that by blocking the Seaway traffic to the Canadian capital, Ottawa, they hoped to send a message to the federal government that their needs cannot be ignored. Meanwhile, traffic was flowing freely on the Champlain Bridge and on South Shore roads after police removed several blockades put up by anti-Mohawk local residents on Friday. The protesters had threatened to maintain the barricades until the Mercier Bridge is reopened. The roadblocks went up at daybreak Friday and some remained late into the night, causing chaos for travelers.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Lifts Objection To Savings-and-Loan Panel
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration lifted its objections to legislation creating a commission to probe the savings and loan collapse after being assured the panel would not interfere with criminal prosecutions, Senate sponsors of the bill said Saturday. Sens. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., and Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., released letters from the departments of Justice and Treasury indicating the administration ``dropped its objections'' to a Senate-sponsored bill setting up an eight-member bipartisan investigative commission. Administration officials had said they would fight a rival version of the legislation, the Banking Law Enforcement Act of 1990, passed by the House on July 31, and had spoken out against a proposal by the National Governors' Association last week for such an investigative panel. In a letter to Sens. Bond and Dodd, made public Saturday, Deputy Assistant Attorney General Bruce Navarro, restated administration concerns that the House version of the legislation ``could pose real dangers'' to ongoing savings-and-loan criminal investigations. ``We are particularly pleased that, unlike the House bill, your proposal takes care to ensure that ongoing criminal investigations and prosecutions conducted by the department are neither compromised nor impeded.'' The executive and legislative branches of government historically have feuded over companion investigations of various scandals by the Justice Department and congressional committees. This was dramatized recently in a federal appellate court's decision reversing one of former Marine Lt. Col. Oliver North's Iran-Contra convictions and ordering a lower court to review other convictions to determine whether immunized testimony North gave the Congress was impermissibly used against him by Iran-Contra prosecutors. Bond and Dodd got the administration to lift its objections to their S&L fact-finding commission by agreeing to amend the legislation. Under the new version, the commission would be required to inform the Justice Department when it plans to call witnesses implicated in savings and loan failures. The two senators said in a statement Saturday that if the department or the Resolution Trust Corporation certifies that commission testimony could jeopardize a pending criminal investigation, ``the commission would not call the witnesses.'' ``However, the commission has the authority to request additional powers after 60 days if it believes the investigation is impaired in any way,'' their statement said. In his letter, Navarro said: ``We have concluded that your proposal constitutes a workable compromise solution that adequately takes into account the legitimate concerns of all involved. Consequently, we have no objection to its enactment.'' Bryce Harlow, an assistant Treasury secretary in charge of legislative affairs, said in a separate letter that his department is satisfied the Senate proposal ``has sufficient safeguards to protect ongoing civil and criminal investigations.'' A host of congressional committees already is conducting various investigations into the savings-and-loan debacle, and the administration had previously shown no enthusiasm for the separate effort by a study commission. The bipartisan commission would be constituted of two members appointed by President Bush, two by Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, two by House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and one each by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., and House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Weighs Options, Monitors Reports of Missing Americans
DOC.TEXT: President Bush huddled Saturday with senior advisers to devise a strategy for pushing Iraqi occupation forces out of Kuwait, while an Iraqi envoy announced that ``Kuwaiti authorities'' were now in control of the oil-rich nation. Mohammed Sadiq Mashat, the Iraqi ambassador to the United States, read a government statement reiterating Baghdad's intention to begin withdrawing from Kuwait on Sunday ``unless a threat to the security of Kuwait or Iraq has reemerged.'' Mashat, speaking at the Iraqi Embassy, also said Iraq will not attack Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, and he confirmed that 11 of 14 Americans missing in Kuwait had been found, taken to Baghdad and are now free to leave the country. The ambassador declined to elaborate on the Americans' plight. Mashat said the troop withdrawal was deemed possible because order had been restored. ``The situation in Kuwait is back to normal,'' he said. ``Security and stability are maintained for all the population _ indiginous and resident. Kuwaiti authorities are consolidating their control over all aspects of life in Kuwait.'' The Bush administration has expressed doubts about Iraq's pledge, first delivered on Friday, to begin withdrawing its invasion force from Kuwait on Sunday. ``I assure you he does not intend to withdraw,'' Saud Nasir Al-Sabah, the Kuwaiti ambassador, told reporters at a news conference shortly after the Iraqi ambassador spoke in Washington. ``They (Iraqi forces) have already dug in. They have already dug in the south, along the Saudi border, they have dug in our country deeply. They have taken over the central bank. They have ransacked all the banks in Kuwait, all the institutions. They have even gone to the low of going into houses and taking private property.'' Al-Sabah, a member of Kuwait's ruling family, said the Iraqi forces have ``conducted themselves in a way that no other occupying force has.'' He said he interpreted during a telephone conversation earlier Saturday between Bush and the Emir of Kuwait, but declined to disclose what was said. He said the Kuwaiti embassy in Washington also facilitated a letter exchange between Bush and the exiled leader. White House spokesman Douglas Davidson said Bush also spoke by telephone Saturday afternoon with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and Prime Minister Turgut Ozal of Turkey, but the spokesman gave no details on the conversations. Although Al-Sabah had called earlier for military intervention from the United States, he said Saturday that he was grateful for economic and diplomatic sanctions arranged by the United States. The question of military assistance, he said, is a ``decision (that) has to be made by the administration according to their readiness and their policy making. The bottom line is we are pleased the United States is moving and cultivating the whole world behind it.'' Bush met for two hours with Vice President Dan Quayle and the president's top military and national security aides at his Camp David, Md., mountain retreat to consider possible U.S. actions and to monitor reports on Iraqi troop movements. A White House statement issued after the meeting said three key U.S. allies _ Japan, West Germany and France _ had decided to join the United States in freezing Kuwaiti assets in order to stop Iraq from confiscating them. In all, 11 nations have frozen Kuwaiti assets. The actions take aim at Kuwaiti government investments that amount to as much as $100 billion and that include massive holdings of U.S. government securities, chains of gasoline stations across Europe, an American oil services company and stakes in other major corporations. Also on Saturday, the 12-nation European Community agreed to ban imports of Iraqi oil, freeze Kuwaiti assets and halt arms sales to Iraq. The United States banned imports of Iraqi oil on Thursday and Bush has encouraged others to do the same. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, indicated in a statement on the Camp Cavid meeting that Bush was keeping open the possibility of resorting to military force to compel Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait. ``We continue to seek the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and restoration of the legitimate government of Kuwait,'' Fitzwater said. ``As we have stated before, all U.S. options are under consideration.'' Fitzwater said the White House had no information on missing Americans in Kuwait. Iraq announced on Friday that its troops would begin withdrawing from Kuwait on Sunday, but that the Kuwait royal family that ruled the city-state would not be allowed to return. In Bahrain, Persian Gulf shipping sources said Iraqi troops on Saturday seized the American crew of a ship docked at a Kuwait port and took them off the vessel. The sources said the fate of the 20 Americans from the ship was not known. The vessel was docked at Shuwaikh port, the main port of Kuwait City, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. The State Department questioned the report on the seized crew. ``We did check into the story,'' said a spokesperson for the department's Kuwaiti task force. ``We have no confirmation it is true.'' Another official, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said earlier the department thinks the story is untrue. Mashat, the Iraqi ambassador, said he had not heard of the report. The State Department also said Saturday that three of 14 American oil company workers believed to have been detained by Iraq in Kuwait had turned up in Baghdad apparently unharmed. A U.S. official said eight others also were believed safe. As of late Saturday Iraqi time, the eight had not been contacted by U.S. consular officials but were reported to have checked in to a Baghdad hotel, the official said. He added that the two groups may account for all Americans thought to have been missing since the invasion Thursday. The names of the Americans were not available from the State Department. A central dilemma facing the Bush administration in considering a further response to the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait is the complications of a U.S. military operation. The United States has no ground forces based in the area. Iraq has one million men under arms and is by far the strongest army in the region. Pentagon sources said Saturday that Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, briefed Bush at Camp David on the military situation in the gulf. ``The situation with the Iraqi military seems to be pretty static,'' said one senior Pentagon official, speaking on condition he not be identified. ``Right now, we're looking to see if they withdraw their forces from Kuwait, as they said they would.'' One senior military official, who spoke privately, said some ``refined options'' apparently were offered to the president by defense officials, but that he could not discuss what they were. Bush earlier had been presented with what was described as ``a spectrum of options'' for military action that included offering war-fighting hardware to Kuwait's neighbors and more aggressive moves, such as a naval blockade or tactical air strikes or bombing runs against Iraq, Pentagon sources said. ``But just because we presented these to the president, doesn't mean that we'll use them,'' cautioned another senior Pentagon official. ``Providing such a range is what we do here _ contingency planning is our job.'' The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Les Aspin, D-Wis., said Saturday that Kuwait appears to be firmly in the grip of Iraq, putting the administration in a quandary if Saddam Hussein installs a puppet government and withdraws his forces. ``I think it's going to be difficult to sustain an economic boycott or military action in any case, with the American public and the world,'' Aspin said on CNN's ``Newsmaker Saturday.'' ``I think that's a very tough situation for us to deal with'' if such a situation is tolerated by Iraq's Arab neighbors.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Oozes Into Marshlands, But Fishing Resumes in Parts of Galveston Bay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Coast Guard's afternoon report, plan to use microbes on Sunday, quotes from wildlife official. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `One of ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: Oil oozed into sensitive marshlands on the north end of Galveston Bay, but fishing resumed Saturday in parts of the bay where up to 700,000 gallons of oil spilled from a damaged barge. Cleanup crews used vacuum trucks to suck up the oily mess, which has washed up along an estimated seven-mile stretch of Houston Point. The oil has struck marshes and some residential property in the area. Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene, who flew over the area Saturday, said he was encouraged by the shoreline cleanup but expected it to last another week. ``We're at the point where most of the oil is on the beach. I think we can deal with that,'' Greene said. ``There's no more oil coming from anywhere. It's just a matter of finishing the job.'' Environmentalists were worried by reports of at least two oil-soiled birds. Workers used noise makers along the oily shore to keep birds from landing in the goo. Booms along the shoreline trapped some of the oil and stopped new crude from washing ashore, the Coast Guard said. New oil was reported Friday morning along Houston Point, on the north end of the bay between the Houston Ship Channel and Trinity Bay. Crews were laying additional absorbent booms to protect marshes further into Trinity Bay, Greene said. The Coast Guard also plans to spray oil-gobbling microbes on some marshy areas Sunday, he said. State officials dumped the microbes on a 400-yard stretch of beach on Pelican Island on Thursday, but results weren't expected for several weeks. ``My comfort level is much higher today as far as the oil we can see,'' said Larry McKinney, director of resource protection for the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. ``For the long-term, I'm still concerned because we can't account for about 500,000 gallons.'' Coast Guard officials estimated that between 500,000 and 700,000 gallons of oil spilled, but they have been perplexed by the relatively small amount of oil that has been cleaned up or has washed ashore. The oil spilled into Galveston Bay when a tanker collided with two barges July 28 in the ship channel, the Coast Guard said. One of the barges nearly sank, but it has since been raised and moved to shallower waters in the bay. Salvage crews Saturday were considering the possibility of cutting it in half, then moving the pieces out of the bay. Limited traffic resumed Friday in the ship channel after the barge was moved. In Beaumont, Texas, two federal lawsuits were filed on behalf of hundreds of people who say their livelihoods have suffered because of a massive oil spill in Galveston Bay. Both class-action lawsuits name Apex RE&T Inc., owner of the barges, and Eletson Corp., owner of the tanker Shinoussa, as defendants. The lawsuits seek monetary awards for each fisherman expected to lose money because of the spill, which occurred with the shrimping season's peak period approaching. Neither lawsuit asks for a specific amount of damages. Lawyers in Houston for both companies did not return calls from The Associated Press Saturday. Meanwhile, a ban on all commercial and recreational fishing in the bay was partially lifted early Saturday. But Texas Health Commissioner Robert Bernstein cautioned fishermen and consumers to avoid eating fish tainted with visible oil or fish caught in oily waters. A federal inquiry investigating the cause of the accident also resumed Saturday in Houston. On Friday, a Houston pilot, Capt. Raymond Fincher, disputed claims by crewmen of the tanker Shinoussa who said the pilot ordered the vessel to speed through the ship channel and then to turn into the barges in the oncoming lane. Fincher blamed Shinoussa helmsman Mohammed Haque of Bangladesh. Fincher said Haque failed to turn correctly, setting the ship on a collision course with three barges towed by the tugboat, Chandy N. The third barge was not hit by the tanker. U.S. Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Robert Douville said findings of the panel are not expected for at least six months.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Names Kuwaiti Government; Iraqi Forces Massing on Border
LaserPhoto FRA1
DOC.TEXT: Baghdad on Saturday announced a new military government for Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, and foreign reports said Iraq was massing troops along Kuwait's southern border with Saudi Arabia. Baghdad television said the new Kuwait leadership is made up of nine Kuwaiti army officers. Earlier, Iraq said it was building a new Kuwaiti army to back the government it installed. In Washington, Iraqi ambassador Mohammed al-Mashat denied U.S. and other foreign reports suggesting that Iraq plans to invade Saudi Arabia. U.S. and Kuwaiti officials expressed skepticism that Iraq would begin a withdrawal this weekend from Kuwait _ as it had indicated Friday. Reports of the withdrawal, to begin Sunday, came in a communique read on Baghdad radio. Saud Nasser Al-Sabah, the Kuwaiti ambassador to Washington, told reporters at a news conference that Iraq ``does not intend to withdraw'' its troops from Kuwait. In Rome, the 12-member European Community announced it was imposing an embargo on oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait, suspending arms sales to Iraq and freezing Iraqi assets in Europe. That action was only the latest in mounting pressure on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait, which his forces invaded Thursday to settle disputes over oil and land. In Washington, al-Sabah said there were reports of ``800 or maybe more'' casualties from the fighting, although he said he had no contact with his homeland because lines have been cut. Persian Gulf-based Arab diplomatic sources have estimated that at least 200 people were killed or wounded during the Iraqi invasion, but could not confirm the higher casualty figures. In other developments: _U.S., French and British warships steamed toward the Persian Gulf, and French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said France would consider supporting a naval blockade of Iraq. In Washington, the Pentagon said a third aircraft carrier would head for the Middle East to bolster the eight-ship U.S. Navy presence already there. President Bush said Friday that if Iraq moved against Saudi Arabia it would be attacking U.S. ``vital interests.'' _Arab leaders warned against foreign intervention in the region and sought a diplomatic solution, but an emergency Arab League summit to discuss the crisis initially planned for Sunday in Saudi Arabia was postponed. _ Persian Gulf shipping sources said Iraqi troops seized the crews of all ships docked at Kuwaiti ports and impounded the vessels. The crews from many nations included at least 20 Americans, the sources said. However, spokesmen at the U.S. State Department said they had no information to confirm the report of U.S. crewmen being seized. _In London, the Defense Ministry said Iraqi soldiers took 35 British servicemen acting as advisers to Kuwaiti forces from their homes in Kuwait overnight. It said they were later flown to Baghdad. The servicemen were among 66 British military advisers in Kuwait. Britain said it has been assured by Iraq that all 35 were safe. _Kuwaiti diplomatic sources who contacted Kuwaiti residents by telephone said Iraqi tanks and troops had begun to withdraw from downtown Kuwait city. Gulf-based Arab diplomatic sources, who are in contact with their embassies in Kuwait, said there was scattered shooting and looting by Iraqi troops in the Kuwaiti capital. Iraqi soldiers broke into banks, supermarkets and automobile showrooms, driving off with luxury cars, the diplomatic sources said. _ Three U.S. oil workers missing since the Iraqi invasion turned up in Baghdad apparently unharmed, the State Department said in Washington. An official said U.S. authorities were told eight other Americans had also been taken there in a group of 24 Westerners. Iraq's U.S ambassador said the Americans would be free to leave. U.S. officials, who earlier said 14 Americans were missing, said the 11 Americans may account for all those thought missing. Iraq said the new Kuwaiti government is headed by Col. Ala Hussein Ali. He holds the positions of prime minister, commander in chief of the armed forces, minister of defense and interior minister. The other eight members were lieutenant colonels and majors. Diplomatic sources elsewhere in the gulf, however, said those names could be fake, or the people on the list could actually be Iraqis. ``I assure you ... that none, I repeat none, of the names ... put forward are Kuwaiti nationality or citizenship,'' said al-Sabah, the Kuwaiti ambassador in Washington and a member of the royal family. ``They are all Iraqi military people.'' Iraqi TV showed no pictures of the government members. Also Saturday, Baghdad radio broadcast a communique from the ``provisional government of free Kuwait'' announcing it was creating a popular army that would accept all Arab nationals ``who wish stability for Kuwait in its new age.'' The official Iraqi news agency said that 140,820 Iraqis living in the border area with Kuwait had volunteered to serve. The gulf diplomatic sources said busloads of the Iraqis began arriving in Kuwait. There were reports from the U.S. State Department, intelligence officials and witnesses that Iraq was moving parts of its invasion force to Kuwait's almost 150-mile-long southern border with Saudi Arabia, the monarchy that has the world's largest oil reserves. Residents of the Saudi border city of Khafji, reached by telephone from Bahrain, said Iraqi troops laid down a checkpoint less than a mile from the frontier. The U.S. State Department said some of the invasion force had pushed to within five to 10 miles of the Kuwait-Saudi border. The possibility of an Iraqi thrust into Saudi Arabia worried members of Congress. Lawmakers attending secret briefings on the crisis said 120,000 Iraqi troops massed along Kuwait's southern border could easily attack the Saudis next. On Saturday, Bush said in Washington that the use of force in resolving the crisis remains an option. Saudi Arabia ships 1.2 million barrels of oil to the United States daily. A high-ranking Saudi official said Saturday on condition of anonymity no Iraqi troops had entered Saudi Arabia. On Friday, Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council, led by Saddam, said it planned to begin a withdrawal Sunday, ``unless something appears that could threaten the security of Kuwait and Iraq.'' But in Washington, presidential Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater expressed skepticism Iraq would begin its withdrawal. ``We need to wait and see,'' he said. The Soviet Union, Iraq's main weapons supplier, cut off shipments Thursday, while the United States froze Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets on the same day. France, Italy, Poland, Britain and other countries also imposed sanctions on Iraq. In Iraq, people crowded grocery stores Saturday to buy rice, sugar and cooking oil after they heard reports that the U.S. economic sanctions included a cutoff in agricultural credits. The credits are used to buy grain and other foodstuffs. The atmosphere was tense, though generally quiet in Kuwait city, according to residents reached by telephone. Some Kuwaitis had been distributing anti-Iraqi leaflets near downtown mosques, the gulf diplomatic sources said. Iraqi tanks shelled al-Beda, a man-made island on the city's southern coast near an industrial center, said one diplomat on condition of anonymity. He did not know why it was shelled. Iraq's invasion followed two weeks of threats and accusations against its small Persian Gulf neighbor. On July 17, Saddam accused it of stealing oil from a field that straddles their disputed border. He also blamed Kuwait for a fall in oil prices that cost Iraq $14 billion, saying it contributed to the oil glut by cheating on its OPEC oil cartel production quotas.

DOC.HEAD: Government Settles With Spouse of Woman Killed by Glacier
DOC.TEXT: In what may be the first time a government has been sued for the movement of a glacier, the United States has agreed to pay the husband of a woman killed when ice fell on her in Kenai Fjords National Park. Thais Grabenauer, 59, of Napa, Calif., died one day after the June 16, 1987, accident during the couple's outing to the spectacular Exit Glacier. According to a National Park Service investigation, Mrs. Grabenauer was standing beneath overhanging ice while her husband, Ken, stepped away to take a photograph. Half a ton of ice broke off and knocked both of them to the ground. Rangers flew Mrs. Grabenauer to Anchorage, where she died in a hospital of internal injuries. The lawsuit filed two years later by Ken Grabenauer charged the park service with negligence for failing to warn visitors adequately of the hazards of glacier ice and for failing to erect barriers. Park service officials admitted no liability in the out-of-court settlement, reached in March. Both parties agreed not to disclose the amount of the settlement. Grabenauer, 68, had asked for $1.5 million. Assistant U.S. Attorney Sue Ellen Tatter in Anchorage said last week the settlement was considerably less than that. One of the main issue in the case was whether the Park Service is responsible for warning people and keeping them out of dangerous areas. The once-remote glacier had become more accessible in the years before Mrs. Grabenauer's death. A two-lane highway was built over a wild river that past visitors had to ford to reach the glacier,15 miles from Seward, which is 125 miles south of Anchorage. The Grabenauers were on a driving vacation to Alaska and decided to visit the glacier on a lark, after seeing promotional material in Seward that said they could ``walk up and touch a glacier.'' The Park Service, which has placed new warning signs since the accident, claimed those up at the time adequately warned of the dangers of approaching the ice. It also noted that the couple left an established trail. Speaking by telephone from California, Grabenauer said the dangers are apparent to him now. ``But how does one know unless you're living there and familiar with those geographical conditions?'' he said. The Park Service has measured the glacier's downhill movement at an average of 20 inches a day, said Ted Patterson, a park volunteer. ``The glacier is real,'' said park superintendent Anne Castellina. ``People think when you attach `National Park' to something then it's going to be hazard-free,'' she said. ``You go to Disney World for that.''

DOC.HEAD: Leader of Pro-Walesa Party Calls for President To Resign
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a political party backing Lech Walesa for president said Saturday that the current holder of that post should step down soon. Jaroslaw Kaczynski, chairman of the pro-Walesa Center Alliance, said his party would support a proposed change in the constitution to make the president elected directly by the people. But he said the president should then be given stronger powers than under the current parliamentary system. Kaczynski said a fight for the presidency could occur between Walesa, chairman of the Solidarity trade union, and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, Walesa's former ally and adviser. But he said his party would not be afraid of such a battle. ``A clash between Walesa and Mazowiecki in presidential elections would not be very favorable for Poland from the political point of view, but if this is the will of the people, too bad,'' Kaczynski said, speaking at a news conference at his office. ``The Center Alliance calls for the president of the republic to resign in the shortest possible time. We think that it could happen even in the next few weeks,'' Kaczynski said. The current president, Wojciech Jaruzelski, was Poland's Communist leader before its transition to democracy last year. Although the Center Alliance has been calling for the parliament to quickly install Walesa as president, Kaczynski said the party would support changing the constitution to allow a direct election in light of opinion polls showing that method is far more popular with the public. But he added: ``Changing the president is more important than the manner in which it should be done.'' If a constitutional change cannot be agreed to swiftly, then Walesa should be elected by the current parliament for six to 10 months, he said. During that time, he said a new parliament would be elected and a new constitution written. After this provisional presidency, Walesa could run again for a full term in a direct election, he said. Kaczynski also said sweeping cabinet changes should follow the proposed elections but advocated leaving Mazowiecki as prime minister. He added that it is ``highly probable'' that Mazowiecki would resign after the new president's appointment. Kaczynski said a petition passed among Parliament members calling for the immediate resignation of Jaruzelski, which began circulating July 28, now has 125 signatures. There are 470 deputies in the Sejm, the lower house, and 100 senators.

DOC.HEAD: Surburban Company Sets Out On Aid Mission to Iran
DOC.TEXT: A plastics company sent nine employees to Iran on Saturday to build 1,200 houses for those left homeless by an earthquake that killed more than 50,000 people. The workers from FANA Inc., of Springfield, took with them heat-shrink film and pipes that will be used to build the structures, said FANA president Anthony Seraphin. The film is a thick, opaque plastic that is designed to be shrunk on pipe frames to form a shelter. The homes are not designed as permanent structures but should last two to three years. ``We can put these buildings up quickly. A home 20-by-20 (feet) takes two hours, tops,'' Seraphin said. ``We won't build all the structures. We will be showing them how to do it and then go on to the next town.'' The company, which also aided earthquake victims in Soviet Armenia two years ago, started planning the trip shortly after an quake struck in Iran on June 21, leaving more than 50,000 dead and 500,000 homeless. But the task became mired in complications because the United States severed relations with Iran more than a decade ago over the hostage crisis. ``It certainly has been a long road,'' Seraphin said. ``Armenia was nothing compared to this.'' First, the Iranian government insisted on assigning a department to take charge of the effort but couldn't decide which one, Seraphin said. Iranian officials finally settled on the Revolutionary Guard. Then, Seraphin said, the company encountered difficulty in getting an air carrier to haul the equipment and the company workers. ``The military wanted to take us, but the State Department had to say no because they can't help us over there,'' Seraphin said. The company finally lined up Pakistani Airlines International to take the workers to Frankfort, Germany, where Iranian planes will pick them up, Seraphin said. The equipment left several days ago on a third carrier, Alitalia, Seraphin said. The entire effort has been financed with $45,000 in private donations, he said. Seraphin said Iranian officials have promised him the company's problems will end once the workers reach Iranian soil for the 10 days of work. ``We have been assured by the Iranian government that we will be able to move from town to town,'' he said. ``We have been assured we will be very welcomed there.'' Another relief agency, AmeriCares, based in New Canaan, Conn., distributed 40 tons of supplies to survivors of the Iranian earthquake shortly after the disaster struck. ``I think this is a major breakthrough in relations,'' Seraphin said. ``We're just going in there to help the people. In Armenia, there were tears when we left, and I'm sure the same will be true this time.''

DOC.HEAD: Marchers Call For Investigation Of Medical Examiner
DOC.TEXT: The family of a black teen-ager fatally shot by a white police officer marched with 200 supporters Saturday and called for an investigation of the coroner who made errors in the youth's autopsy. Bergen County Medical Examiner Lawrence J. Denson was relieved of his medical duties last week after errors were found in his autopsy of Phillip Pannell, 16, of River Edge, who was shot April 10. ``We want an investigation on the medical examiner, to determine whether his alleged mistakes were truly mistakes or if they were intentional,'' said Ted Wells, a lawyer with the Bergen County chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The father of the slain boy said that conspiracy, not incompetence, was at question. ``No mistake whatsoever, it started out as a coverup,'' said Phillip Pannell Sr. ``The problem is that this system doesn't work.'' State Medical Examiner Robert Goode wrote in a letter dated Wednesday that Denson made mistakes in concluding where Pannell's hands were when he was shot, a crucial point in the controversy surrounding the youth's death. Witnesses said Pannell had his hands up when he was shot by Officer Gary Spath, but Spath maintains Pannell was turning and reaching for what the officer thought was a gun in his coat pocket. A forensic specialist brought in by the Bergen County Prosecutor's office concluded Pannell's arms were raised because the bullet hole in Pannell's down jacket indicated the jacket had ridden up his back. A state grand jury last week voted not to indict Spath, but Attorney General Robert Del Tufo said a second grand jury will investigate the shooting using the results of the second autopsy. ``We want the new forensic evidence presented, and an indictment for murder returned against Officer Spath,'' said Wells. Carrying the flags of the United States and South Africa's African National Congress, the 200 marchers walked the length of Cedar Lane, the main commercial street in this New York City suburb. Some of the predominantly black marchers voiced anxiety about the future of Teaneck, held by many to be a model of racial harmony after it voluntarily desegregated its schools in the late 1960s. ``I moved here because this is a special town and I want to preserve it,'' said Eunice Pruitt, whose four children and two grandchildren grew up in Teaneck. ``This whole thing makes me sick,'' said John Gish of Hackensack, a gay activist who said he marched to protest all bias violence. A rally April 11 to protest the shooting turned into a riot, with youths smashing windows and overturning police cars.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Investigating Alleged Sexual Assault Aboard Soviet Ship
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last 2 grafs, bgng `At a...' with 5 grafs to show Khvatov is commander of Soviet Pacific Fleet, information on Iraq shared, details of sendoff for Soviets, previous US-Soviet exchanges; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. and Soviet navies are investigating a claim that a Soviet sailor sexually assaulted a U.S. Navy woman aboard a Soviet warship in port on a goodwill visit, officials said Saturday. The enlisted woman allegedly was assaulted Tuesday morning when she became separated from friends during a tour of a Soviet ship. She was dressed in civilian clothes at the time, officials said. The Soviet destroyers Admiral Vinogradov and Boyevoy were opened to public visits during a five-day stop at the port that began Tuesday. The woman was not identified and officials did not say which ship she visited. No further details of her claim were revealed. ``Both of our navies are jointly evaluating whether there is any basis to this allegation,'' said Adm. Charles Larson, commander of the U.S. Pacific Fleet. ``A joint evaluation of evidence must be made to decide if there's any basis in fact.'' The woman was not able to describe the assailant or provide additional information to Naval Investigative Services agents, said Lt. Cmdr. Bob Pritchard, a Navy spokesman. When the Navy finishes its investigation the findings will be turned over to the Soviets, who would have jurisdiction, Pritchard said. If there is enough evidence for a court marshal, the sailor would likely be prosecuted in the Soviet Union and not extradited to the United States, said Col. Nicholay N. Bessubchenco of the Soviet Political Directorate. The allegation surfaced on the eve of the departure of three Soviet ships. ``We are checking our sailors to ask them about everything,'' Bessubchenco said. ``It's very serious. This a very serious report.'' The Soviet port call in San Diego was part of an ongoing goodwill exchange between navies of the two countries. ``Two Pacific fleets of two great countries reached out for a handshake,'' said Adm. Genadiy Khvatov, the Soviet Pacific Fleet commander, before hundreds of people gave the Soviet sailors a rousing sendoff. ``Let this handshake become a warranty of good naval (relations) and mutual understanding.'' Larson said he shared with Khvatov everything he knew about Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait earlier this week. The United States and the Soviet Union have jointly condemned Iraq's aggression and called for the invaders to withdraw. Three Soviet ships visited Norfolk, Va., last July and three U.S. warships visited the Black Sea port of Sevastopol last August. Larson is scheduled to take three ships from the U.S. Pacific Fleet to Vladivostok, the Soviet Union's main Pacific port, on a similar visit next month.

DOC.HEAD: Advisory Council Calls for Further Study of Proposed Art Grants
DOC.TEXT: The National Council on the Arts on Saturday called for further study of five controversial grant proposals that a panel of artists had recommended for approval by the National Endowment for the Arts. The advisory panel voted to put off consideration of the grants on procedural grounds, allowing the endowment to postpone action on the grant applications during the ongoing debate over public financing of controversial art that some deem obscene. Acting at the urging of NEA Chairman John Frohnmayer, the council backed a plan to study whether there had been a conflict of interest involving the peer panel of artists that reviewed the grant applications. The proposed grants for performance artists Karen Finley and Holly Hughes and three other groups are to be reconsidered at the council's next meeting in November. The council also voted to approve two $40,000 grants to Philadelphia's Institute of Contemporary Art, which had organized the photography exhibit by Robert Mapplethorpe that some members of Congress considered obscene. The council at an earlier meeting had recommended that the applications be rejected.

DOC.HEAD: Britain's Queen Mother Celebrates 90th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of admirers of the Queen Mother, one carrying a banner reading ``Happy Birthday Grandmother England,'' gathered outside her home Saturday to help celebrate her 90th birthday. The Queen Mother marked the day serenaded by a band and surrounded by her royal family. The indefatigable mother of Queen Elizabeth II was greeted with wake-up music by pipers playing Scottish airs. Her day was climaxed by an unannounced evening visit to the Royal Opera House to watch the Royal Ballet's performance of Prokofiev's ``Romeo and Juliet.'' In between, there was a 41-gun salute in Hyde Park followed by a 62-gun salute at the Tower of London, a peal of bells at St. Paul's Cathedral and a special birthday tribute from Poet Laureate Ted Hughes. Crowds of fans, some of whom had camped out overnight to get a good view of the dowager queen, were rewarded when she stepped onto the geranium-framed balcony of her London home to wave and smile. ``For me, she is everything that belongs to Britain. She's the figurehead, the grandmother to us all. She's absolutely wonderful,'' said Emily Coughlin, who had waited outside Clarence House since Thursday. The Band of the Coldstream Guards played ``Happy Birthday'' as the Queen mother appeared, dressed in a triple strand of pearls, a powder-blue dress with a matching coat and matching hat decked with flowers and a veil. Dozens of well-mannered children gathered around her, offering balloons and bouquets of flowers. She gently patted the shoulder of each. Looking cool and relaxed despite the heat, the ``Queen Mum'' spent nearly a half-hour shaking hands and saying ``thank you'' to the crowd lined up along police barricades on the Clarence House grounds. The Queen Mother was joined for lunch by the rest of the royal family, including Queen Elizabeth II, Princess Margaret, her grandchildren and great grandchildren. Five months ago, the Queen Mother protested that she wanted her 90th birthday to pass without ``fuss.'' Since then, there have been a crescendo of parties, celebrations and a giant parade through central London. Born Aug. 4, 1900, Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon was the vivacious and dainty daughter of one of Scotland's most celebrated families. Some Scots thought she was marrying beneath her when she wed the second son of the Hanoverian dynasty, Albert. But when Edward abdicated to wed the divorcee Wallis Warfield Simpson, Albert was crowed King George VI. He died of lung cancer in 1952. Over the decades, she has become a symbol for many of Britain's best qualities _ its dignity, strength and sense of humor.

DOC.HEAD: Forty-two Aliens Detained at Ice Cream Warehouse
DOC.TEXT: Immigration agents arrested 42 undocumented workers who allegedly paid the smugglers for the trip from Mexico by turning over earnings they gained from pushing ice cream vending carts, officials said. Agents also arrested a manager and supervisor of the Delicias de Michoacan warehouse, which district immigration director Robert Moschorak said was the final destination of a network bringing undocumented workers from Mexico. ``They were being smuggled into the United States, transported to this location and harbored there,'' he said. ``The initial indications are that some paid as much as $1,500 to get here.'' Some aliens were allowed to pay back the smugglers by selling ice cream and frozen fruit bars known as paletas from push carts, Moschorak said. Gus Mora, whose family owns Delicias de Michoacan, denied the firm was involved in smuggling aliens. He described the raid Friday as a ``witch hunt.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Mafia Fugitives Reportedly Hiding in New York
DOC.TEXT: Two top organized crime leaders who disappeared in May shortly before their indictment on racketeering charges are probably hiding in New York, according to a report published Sunday. The two fugitives, Vittorio ``Vic'' Amuso, who prosecutors say is the boss of the Lucchese crime family, and Anthony ``Gaspipe'' Casso, allegedly the Lucchese underboss, have eluded arrest for two months. Jules J. Bonavolonta, the head of the FBI's organized-crime branch in the city, told The New York Times that agents will intensify the search for Amuso and Casso. Both men are probably ``squirreled away'' in the New York City area and still issuing orders, he said. Amuso, Casso and 13 other reputed organized crime leaders were indicted by a federal grand jury on May 30. They were accused of conspiracy and extortion in rigging bids on $142 million in window contracts awarded by the Housing Authority from 1978 to last year. Casso was also indicted on June 21 on charges of being part of a separate conspiracy to control the bidding for painting contracts in the city. Amuso was named as an unindicted co-conspirator in that case.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher To Meet Bush to Discuss Kuwait Occupation
LaserPhotos ASPX3
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher scheduled a meeting with President Bush and then set the world's problems aside to discuss physics with some of the field's top researchers Saturday. Mrs. Thatcher, with her son, Mark, by her side, shared an afternoon tea with researchers at the Aspen Center for Physics and talked about developments in research ranging from neurobiology to cosmology to quasi-crystals, a new and much-debated form of matter. ``We were all impressed with how interested she was,'' said Dr. Jeremy Bernstein of the Stevens Institute of Technology. ``It was as if the world had evaporated and we were (alone) in the universe.'' The 1{-half hour meeting was ``magnificent,'' said Mrs. Thatcher, who was trained as a chemist. ``It was very exciting.'' Despite repeated questioning from reporters, Mrs. Thatcher declined to comment on developments in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, other than to say, ``I have a very good rule. First find the facts. It's worked well for me in over 31 years in Parliament.'' Earlier Saturday, the Defense Ministry in London said Iraqi troops took 35 British servicemen acting as advisers to Kuwaiti forces from their homes in Kuwait. It said they later were flown to Baghdad. The servicemen were among 66 British military advisers in Kuwait. The institute's symposium, which celebrates its 40th anniversary, has been overshadowed by the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait since it opened Thursday. Prior to giving the keynote address at the institute's session Thursday, President Bush met with Mrs. Thatcher privately. He then cut his trip short to return to Washington, D.C., to work on the Kuwaiti issues. Mrs. Thatcher, who arrived here Wednesday, originally was to have stayed 10 days, combining business with pleasure on her first trip to Colorado. But after speaking with White House officials, French President Francois Mitterrand and members of the Saudi Arabian government on Saturday, Mrs. Thatcher decided to leave Monday. She plans to meet with Bush in the afternoon and continue on to London, where she is expected to arrive early Tuesday. On Sunday, Mrs. Thatcher will give the closing address to the institute on a topic that is expected to have a strong European focus. She also will receive the institute's Statesman Award, which only has been given twice in the nonprofit organization's 40-year history. The other two recipients are Jean Monnet, the founder of European economic integration and former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. Founded in 1950, the institute was created to gather leaders in all fields to discuss ways to deal with the world's problems.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Defense Spending Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts grafs 8-9, ``Shortly before xxx to incorporate action on transportation and intelligence bills from elsewhere in report and note that Senate adjourned until Sept. 10
DOC.TEXT: The Senate approved a $289 billion defense bill Saturday that cuts $1 billion from President Bush's request for the Strategic Defense Initiative but leaves intact his fiscal 1991 proposal for two B-2 bombers. In a rush to finish before a summer recess, the Senate adopted, 79-16, a military budget that slashes $18 billion from Bush's request of $307 billion for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. ``We have developed a manageable and prudent and responsible reduction in defense expenditures related to the threat,'' Senate Armed Services Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., said shortly before the chamber approved one of the first military budgets in the post-Cold War era. The Senate package, adopted despite the threat of a presidential veto, calls for a military personnel reduction of 100,000 and elimination of $1.6 billion in procurement money for the MX rail-garrison missile program. The White House has said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney would recommend a presidential veto because of the SDI total and troop cuts. The objection comes even though the Senate bill is considered the high mark in Congress. The House, when it returns in September, will likely approve its committee's version of a $283 billion defense bill. Senators lingered as legislative loners in the Capitol as House members commenced their August recess in the early morning hours. During a marathon session, they passed campaign finance `reform' legislation, a bill containing assistance for areas hardest hit by AIDS cases and an environnmental protection measure arising from the Exxon Valdez oil spill off Alaska. Shortly before adjourning until Sept. 10, the Senate also passed a bill appropriating roughly $28 billion for transportation programs for the new year, including money for upgrading the nation's airports, mass transit systems and Amtrak. And sources said that an intelligence budget for 1991 passed by voice vote during the previous post-midnight session eliminates U.S. support for a covert war in Cambodia and sharply restricts money for rebels in Afghanistan. Many of the details in the bill are secret since it authorizes some of the nation's most sensitive covert operations. Passage of the defense bill came after the Senate voted to restructure the SDI program, commonly known as Star Wars, by delaying deployment of the ``Brilliant Pebbles'' concept. By a vote of 54-44, the Senate approved a restructuring amendment that leaves intact the chamber's approved total of $3.7 billion for SDI _ $1 billion less than Bush proposed. However, the measure scales back the administration's request for the Brilliant Pebbles concept from $329 million to $129 million. Nunn criticized the Pentagon for trying four different systems for the SDI program in the past three years while Congress hasn't received ``one clue from anybody in this administration'' on how to pay for the anti-missile shield. ``No one can tell you where the money's coming from and yet they're charging straight ahead,'' Nunn said, noting the likely annual cost of $10 billion for SDI. The amendment comes on the heels of a congressional report that found deploying the first phase of SDI in 1993 would be ``premature and fraught with high risk.'' The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said that the introduction of Brilliant Pebbles has drastically changed the SDI system's design, leaving it in a state of flux. The technology involves several thousand interceptors that would orbit the Earth to seek and destroy a target by smashing into it at high speeds. A key sponsor, Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., said the amendment would ``be rejecting early deployment of systems that would violate the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.'' The Senate later rebuffed two attempts to reduce the SDI budget even further, including one that would have cut the 1991 budget to about $3 billion. The defense bill deletes money for two SSN-21 Seawolf attack submarines, replacing the request with two SSN-688 Los Angeles-class attack submarines, and delays the C-17 transport aircraft program. The bill also provides $238 million in research money for the V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft _ a program Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has tried to kill for the past two years. During three days of lengthy sessions, the Senate adopted by a narrow margin, the president's request for $4.6 billion for two B-2 stealth bombers in fiscal 1991. Despite eroding support for the costliest aircraft in history at $865 million a copy, the Senate left intact Bush's budget proposal but required the program to pass critical tests before money could be spent. The Senate decision sets up a confrontation with the House Armed Services panel which agreed to halt the program at the 15 radar-evading planes in development. The bill also eliminated $1.6 billion in procurement money requested in fiscal 1991 for the program to put MX nuclear missiles on railroad cars. The Senate left intact the $548 million for research on the system as well as the $202 million for the Midgetman land-based nuclear missile. The House Armed Services Committee eliminated the administration's request for both missiles and, instead, set up a strategic pot of $610 million for the two weapons. The panel also called on Bush to decide which missile he wants. The legislation calls for a cut of 100,000 military personnel, including 50,000 from U.S. troop strength in Europe where the committee believes ``the threat of a large-scale Warsaw Pact attack against Western Europe has virtually been eliminated.'' The nation's troop strength currently totals 2.1 million, a number certain to decrease significantly in light of Bush's plan announced Thursday to reduce U.S. forces 25 percent over the next five years. Among the measures approved by the House and Senate late Friday and early Saturday were these: _A House Democratic leadership-backed version of a campaign finance package. Majority Democrats pushed aside proposals from both Republicans and from within their own party and prevailed, 255-155. The bill, which now has to be reconciled with a Senate version, would among other things limit House campaign spending to $715,000 per candidate. _A bill boosting the liability of shippers for the cost of cleaning up oil spills and requiring new tankers to have leak-resistant double hulls. _A measure providing more than $4 billion over five years to help communities hardest hit by AIDS. _Emergency legislation providing the Treasury Department with $72 billion in additional borrowing authority through Oct. 2. _An intelligence budget for 1991 that eliminates U.S. support for a covert war in Cambodia and sharply restricts money for rebels in Afghanistan, according to congressional sources.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Investigates Cheating on Nuclear Reactor Safety Tests
DOC.TEXT: The Navy, investigating allegations of cheating on nuclear reactor safety inspections aboard the USS Nimitz, has restricted four crew members aboard ship. ``No charges have been filed,'' Navy spokesman Lt. Donald Thomas said. ``This action is a standard precautionary measure taken to ensure the presence of individuals until an investigation is complete.'' Four Nimitz sailors approached local news media last week and said sailors aboard the Nimitz were cheating on inspections and were overworked and insufficiently trained to react to a nuclear accident. It wasn't known if the four restricted sailors were the same ones who had approached the news media. The Nimitz is completing a month-long maintenance run at the Puget Sound Naval Shipyard in Bremerton. Thomas' comment came in written response to questions submitted by KIRO-TV. The station aired a segment Thursday night in which the sailors alleged crew members had cheated on reactor inspections, that some nuclear operators had to work up to 100 hours a week in port, and that many crew were not trained sufficiently to react to a nuclear accident. The crew members, whose faces and voices were masked, also alleged that some had considered disabling the reactor to ease their heavy work schedule. One of the sailors later told The Associated Press that the comment was not meant as a direct threat, but that overworked crew members might resort to minor acts of sabotage to put their commanding officers in a bad light. The sailor said the Nimitz was leaving Monday for a training mission, which would last about a month. The Navy declined to comment on the ship's movements. The Navy, in a response forwarded by Senior Chief Journalist Gene Romano at Sand Point Naval Station in Seattle, acknowledged that ``the upkeep period has been a demanding time with significant effort required of the crew. ``Pressure to accomplish the work safely and on schedule is naturally present but is no different from what a crew must routinely contend with, whether in port or in combat training at sea,'' it said. ``Under these circumstances, a lot is asked of _ and given by _ these dedicated individuals, and it is understandable that they sometimes look for outlets to let off steam.'' The Navy said the ``reported allegations are vague and there are few specifics on which to base a response. However, performance standards on Nimitz are very high, and a continuing program of crew training, testing and qualification is conducted with extensive oversight. Widespread cheating is not possible.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested After Crashing Car Into Capitol Barrier
DOC.TEXT: A 27-year-old man was arrested as he ran screaming toward the Capitol on Friday after he crashed his small car into a large concrete flower pot barrier near the building, police said. Norman Lober Jr. of Farifax, Va., was charged with one count of injury to government property. The charge is punishable by a maximum $500 fine and six months in jail. He drove his car over the curb at and rammed into the flower pot-shaped barrier near the Senate side of the Capitol, said Capitol Police spokesman Dan Nichols.

DOC.HEAD: New York Firm Considers Attempt at Greyhound Takeover
DOC.TEXT: The Blackstone Group, a New York firm that invests in corporate takeovers, is considering trying to buy Greyhound Lines Inc. in a deal to end the six-month drivers' strike, a partner in the firm said Friday. ``We are exploring the possibility,'' said partner Richard Ravitch. Greyhound, America's only nationwide bus line, has been operating under the protection of federal bankruptcy laws since June. Any deal to take over the bus line would have to include the return of the 6,300 union drivers who have been on strike since March 2, Ravitch said. ``I think that it's fair to say the only viable deal is one in which the union is a participant,'' Ravitch said. Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said he had never heard of the firm and noted that under federal bankruptcy laws, the bus line has until early October to file a reorganization plan and then another 60 days to prove the reorganization will work. The company has no plans to voluntarily sell the bus line, Gravley said. ``We are building cash balances. We're having a good summer. Things are going pretty well. Business as usual has been our theme song,'' Gravley said. Ravitch said the investment banking group was approached about the deal by Greyhound's creditors. The bus line suffered a loss of more than $50 million in the first three months of 1990 sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection June 4. Ravitch declined to elaborate on details of any deal, saying only that the investment firm was ``trying to get data concerning the company. We've had a discussion with the union and we're proceeding.'' An official with the Amalgamated Transit Union who asked to go unnamed said the union is still interested in some type of employee buyout. Blackstone considers the union's participation crucial, the ATU official said, because union drivers are experienced and also because returning them to work would alleviate millions of dollars in porivers strike, which entered its sixth month on Thursday, was marred by shootings, bomb threats and other violent incidents in its first few months. The two sides have not set down to try and negotiate a settlement since early May.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Authorities Free Student Leader
DOC.TEXT: Authorities freed a student leader jailed six weeks ago for his role in an anti-government protest, and they indicated Friday that Marian Munteanu's arrested colleagues may also be released. Munteanu called a news conference and pressed the government to let them go. Prosecutor-General Gheorghe Robu told state-run radio that Nica Leon, Dumitru Dinca and other leaders of the 53-day demonstration ``may also be released.'' But he said investigation of their activities was continuing. Like Munteanu, their detention began in mid-June, when police violently dispersed the protest in University Square in the center of Bucharest. The crackdown set off attacks on government buildings by angry crowds, and President Ion Iliescu called in miners to come to the aid of the government. The miners terrorized the city in a two-day rampage against people they saw as government opponents. Six people were killed, according to the official count. Robu said Munteanu was released late Thursday because conditions had changed there no longer was reason to fear he would disturb the peace. Late Friday night, about 100 demonstrators gathered briefly in University Square for the fourth time this week, chanting ``Down with Communism!'' and ``Down with Iliescu!'' Munteanu, president of the Bucharest University student league, said he now believes ``justice will be done ... and the others will be released.'' Describing his imprisonment, Munteanu said Friday: ``It was a nightmare. ... The food, the people around me, everything. These six weeks of detention have aged me many years. I am physically weak; I feel 80 years old.'' The 28-year-old student leader was badly beaten by the miners and hospitalized last June. He was arrested days later. Munteanu said the 53-day rally was not anti-government, but pro-democracy. The protesters said former Communists play too large a role in Romania's government and that former Communist Iliescu should quit. Iliescu won in elections last May, following Romania's December revolution in which Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown and executed. The state news agency Rompres reported Friday that former Communist official Nicolae Giosan died of cardiac arrest this week in prison. Giosan was on trial with 23 other Ceausescu aides for complicity in genocide. The charges relate to security force efforts to quell the revolution. Col. Gen. Iulian Vlad, head of Ceausescu's feared Securitate secret police, was arraigned Friday before a military court on charges of complicity in genocide, Rompres said. His trial begins Sept. 10. Conviction could mean life imprisonment.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Unrest Brings Instant Price Hikes At The Pump
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The invasion of Kuwait by Iraq produced a rapid rise in prices at the gas pumps for many Americans. Here is a brief look at some of the increases: _A survey of 1,400 retail gasoline stations by the American Automobile Association showed self-serve unleaded gasoline prices had gone up 4 cents in two days, to an average of $1.115 a gallon. At some stations, the price of a gallon increased as much as 14 cents. _Increases at the pump followed wholesale price hikes by the major oil companies. Mobil Oil Corp. raised its prices an average of 3.5 cents a gallon; Chevron Corp. hiked its price 5 cents; BP America Inc. had a 4-to-5-cent rise; Texaco raised its prices as much as 7 cents a gallon; and other firms also posted increases. _Wholesale unleaded gasoline for September delivery soared 4.11 cents to 72.18 cents a gallon, on top of a 3.80-cent rise Thursday. _The September contract for home heating oil picked up 1.89 cents to close at 66.58 cents a gallon after a 3.50-cent gain Thursday. Natural gas for September delivery rose to $1.510 per 1,000 cubic feet from Thursday's $1.432.

DOC.HEAD: White House Taps Roberts, Ex-Senate Aide, For SEC Vacancy
DOC.TEXT: President Bush nominated Washington attorney Richard Y. Roberts on Friday to fill a vacancy on the Securities and Exchange Commission. Roberts, a former chief of staff to Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala., would fill the seat of Joseph Grundfest, who left the five-member commission in January. The nomination is subject to confirmation by the Senate. No date for confirmation hearings was set. The SEC regulates the stocks and bonds, the exchanges that trade in them and other financial markets such as mutual funds. The chairman and four commissioners, all appointed by the president, serve five-year terms. Roberts, 39, a native of Birmingham, Ala., served 4{ years as Shelby's legislative aide in the House of Representatives and from January 1987 to April 1990 after Shelby was elected to the Senate. Roberts graduated in 1973 from Auburn University with an engineering degree. He received law degrees from the University of Alabama School of Law in 1976 and George Washington University in 1981. He left Shelby's staff in April to join the law firm of Miller, Hamilton, Snider, Odom and Bridgeman.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Announces Nominations
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate former New Hampshire attorney general Thomas D. Rath to the board of directors of the Legal Services Corp., the White House announced Friday. Rath, a Republican now in private practice in Concord, N.H., is a close friend and former deputy to David H. Souter, Bush's Supreme Court nominee. Rath would succeed former Illinois GOP congressman John N. Erlenborn on the board that oversees the Legal Services Corp., which provides legal aid for the poor. It has long been a lightning rod for criticism from conservatives. Conservatives have sought to abolish the agency since the outset of the Reagan administration. They object in particular to Legal Services lawyers' helping poor people file class action lawsuits against the government over welfare benefits and other programs. Bush also announced plans to nominate seven people who have been serving on the Legal Services board as recess appointees since Jan. 22. They now will face Senate confirmation. They are: former Rep. Guy Molinari, now borough president of Staten Island, N.Y.; Jo Betts Love of Mississippi; Jeanine E. Wolbeck of Minnesota; Howard H. Dana Jr. of Portland, Maine; Luis Guinot Jr. of Puerto Rico; Penny L. Pullen, Republican leader of the Illinois House, and George W. Wittgraf of Cherokee, Iowa. Also on Friday, Bush nominated a career diplomat, Arlene Render, to be ambassador to Gambia. She is a former deputy chief of mission in Accra, Ghana. The White House also announced Bush will nominate: _Richard Y. Roberts, a Washington lawyer, to the Securities and Exchange Commission. _Paula J. Dobriansky, a deputy assistant secretary of state for human rights, to be the U.S. Information Agency's associate director for programs. _Juliette Clagett McLennan, of Washington, D.C., for the rank of ambassador while serving as U.S. representative to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women. _Jean C. Hamilton, a Missouri Court of Appeals judge from St. Louis, to be a U.S. District Judge for the eastern district of Missouri. _Gary L. Taylor, a Superior Court judge in Orange County, Calif., to be a U.S. District Judge for the central district of California. He is from Villa Park, Calif. _James Ware, a Superior Court judge in Santa Clara County, Calif., to be a U.S. District judge for the northern district of California. He is from Mountain View, Calif. _William B. Shubb, a lawyer from Sacramento, to be U.S. District Judge for the eastern district of California. He is a former U.S. attorney. _Antonio C. Amador, of Sacramento, Calif., to the Merit Systems Protection Board. He is deputy director of the program review branch with the state employment department. _Howard E. Simmons, a vice president for research at the Dupont Co. in Wilmington, Del., to the National Science Board of the National Science Foundation. _Cheryl Feldman Halpern of Livingston, N.J., and Karl C. Rove, of Austin, Texas, to the Board for International Broadcasting. _Carol K. DiPrete of Bristol, R.I., and J. Michael Farrell of Washington, D.C., to the National Commission on Libraries and Information Science. _Fitzhugh Green and Tom C. Korologos, of Washington, D.C., to the U.S. Advisory Commission on Public Diplomacy. Green is the author of a Bush biography. Korologos is a former Reagan White House official.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Find More Bodies After Trinidad Hostage Siege
LaserPhoto POS1
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Soldiers removed seven more bodies Friday from a bombed police station, the Parliament and a TV building, raising to at least 38 the death toll from a failed coup attempt and subsequent looting. Moslem extremists held hostages for six days before surrendering Wednesday. Army spokesman Maj. Dave Williams said seven additional bodies were recovered by noon from wrecked buildings. Authorities also said that a fire of undetermined origin destroyed a storage area and an apartment Thursday night at the Jamaat al-Muslimeen commune's compound on the outskirts of Port-of-Spain, the capital of this Caribbean island. Abu Bakr, the commune's leader, and 112 of his followers were being held at army headquarters after giving up on Wednesday and releasing their remaining 46 hostages. Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson and several of his Cabinet ministers were among the total of 55 hostages held by the rebels. Government spokesman Gregory Shaw has said the militants could face a variety of charges, including murder, kidnapping and treason, which carries the death penalty. Shaw said Jazeni Omowale, a 21-year-old student from Howard University in Washington, D.C., had been killed Wednesday in a gunfight involving police and soldiers in the capital's Champs Fleurs suburb. He was believed to be Bakr's stepson. The circumstances of the gunfight were unknown. For the first time since the siege began on July 27, soldiers entered the Parliament building. Williams said the bodies of three civilians and one rebel were removed from the building, along with homemade grenades and about 40 handguns.
