He said two other bodies were pulled from the rubble of the police station. The building was demolished by a car bomb and fire during the siege. A seventh body, that of a rebel, was discovered at the government's television station, where 29 employees were held captive. Police sealed off the television station to search for any explosives left by rebels. Shaw said earlier at least 30 people were killed in the initial assault by Bakr and his men and in subsequent looting. The discovery of the bodies Friday and the killing of the American student brought the total to 38. Lennox Williams, administrator of Port-of-Spain General Hospital, said autopsies found at least 14 people died of gunshot wounds. He said most were killed by security forces during looting. A state of emergency remained in effect Friday and soldiers and police patrolled the capital. An 18-hour curfew was reduced to 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., however, and Shaw said banks would open Sunday to help residents resume normal business as soon as possible. A 150-member regional force was dispatched to this island nation of more than 1.2 million to guard installations and relieve the local forces for patrols. Food and medical supplies were being flown in from the United States, Canada and nearby Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Peasants Take Over Ranch, Strike Threat in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista peasants with machetes seized a private ranch and Sandinista workers warned of a general strike, working in unison to threaten anew on Friday the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. About 60 campesinos took over the Santa Julia Ranch in Juigalpa, 120 miles southeast of Managua on Thursday night. Hours earlier, the 150,000-member National Workers Front threatened its third and largest labor action since the United National Opposition coalition of Mrs. Chamorro took office on April 25. Ranch invasion leader Leopoldo Siles Blanco said the peasants acted in retaliation for takeovers in recent weeks of Sandinista cooperative farms. ``We are prepared to invade other private ranches,'' he said in an interview. About 150 Sandinista peasants occupied Agriculture Minister Roberto Rondon's ranch on Wednesday. Lucio Jimenez, leader of the National Workers Front, told a news conference his federation plans a walkout of all Sandinista unions because more than 1,000 government employees were fired despite promises nobody would be laid off. Jimenez complained that currency devaluations over the last three months have reduced the purchasing power of the 150,000 government workers by 90 percent despite pay raises. ``People can't pay for water (and) electricity'' because the government has eliminated subsidies for public services in its attempt to reduce its large financial deficit, he said. Jimenez also complained that despite an accord in which the government promised not to privatize state-owned lands, large farms, with machinery and silos, have been rented to ``large landowners close to the government.'' Six people were killed and about 100 injured in clashes between Sandinista supporters and opponents in the last Sandinista-led strike in July. The strikers erected barricades, paralyzing Managua and disrupting the rest of the nation. Edgardo Garcia, chief of the Sandinista Farmworkers Association, said the government has not lived up to agreements that ended the July strike, including limits on the amount of land distributed by Sandinistas that could be returned to former owners. Police spokesman Miguel Centeno said police lines were set up at the private ranch owned by Chester Noguera, leader of the Nicaraguan Farmers and Ranchers Federation, that was taken over Thursday. Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party United National Opposition defeated the Sandinistas in elections last February and took power in April in this Central American nation of about 3.5 million people. Inflation and low farm production, caused by massive land reform, are the two biggest problem she inherited from the anti-U.S. Sandinistas, who ruled Nicaragua for a decade after overthrowing dictator Anastasio Somoza. Thursday, the government devalued the cordoba by 7.7 percent, the 27th devaluation since it took office as part of a belt-tightening effort to keep the economy afloat. That brought the cordoba down to 560,000 to the dollar at the official rate of exchange, and up to 670,000 on the black market. Mrs. Chamorro has been trying to return Nicaragua to a free market economy, but strikes and strike threats have undermined her efforts. Her government managed to eliminate government subsidies and price controls. But this sent prices for staples skyrocketing.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern's Union Pilots Authorize Strike
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines remaining unionized pilots have authorized their leadership to strike the airline if a contract can't be reached by Aug. 11, the pilots' union said Friday. A spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association acknowledged a strike would not pose much of an immediate threat to the carrier's operations because there are few union pilots flying Eastern planes. Instead, the planes are being flown by pilots who crossed picket lines that were up when Eastern pilots joined striking machinists in a sympathy walkout last year. Still, ALPA spokesman John Mazor said a strike would be significant because ``as much as anything else, a strike focuses the attention of the public ... It creates a lot pressure on the company.'' Eastern pilots overwhelmingly authorized the strike through a ballot taken at local council meetings Thursday night, ALPA said. Contract talks are set to resume next week, the union said. On Thursday, a federal judge in Miami ruled that pilots who struck Eastern and later offered to return to work are entitled to replace the strike-breakers who were hired. They are also entitled to back pay, the judge ruled. Eastern, which is still in the midst of bankruptcy proceedings, said it would appeal the ruling.

DOC.HEAD: One Issue Disposed of By Conference Committee
DOC.TEXT: Senate and House negotiators on clean air legislation reached agreement Friday on a schedule for ending, by the close of the decade, use of chemicals that damage the ozone layer. But leaders acknowledged the most difficult issues of the legislation have yet to be discussed. Among other provisions, the negotiators agreed to forbid states and local governments from restricting or banning the chemicals for two years. The conference committee is not scheduled to meet again until after the August congressional recess. House and Senate staffers were directed to work through the month to draft possible compromises on various parts of the two bills. ``We don't have much time ahead of us,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., the conference chairman, noting there are only 23 legislative days remaining until Congress is scheduled to adjourn in early October. Negotiators said they hoped the agreement on ozone-destroying chemicals would help break the deadlock. That agreement calls for phasing out such chemicals, including chlorofluorocarbons, halons and carbon tetrachloride, widely used as coolants, solvents and foam blowing agents, by the end of the decade. Some substitute chemicals that are less harmful to the environment such as HCFCs _ chlorofluorocarbons that contain one or more hydrogen atoms _ would be phased out over the next 40 years. The measure also calls for recylcing of these chemicals by 1992, and the installation of precautions to prevent routine release into the air. The ban on local action will affect at least 17 states and communities that have acted on their own in various ways to restrict the use of ozone-depleting chemicals. The compromise substantially mirrors requirements in the Montreal Protocol, the international treaty on ozone-depleting chemicals. The House and Senate conferees have been struggling for nearly a month in an attempt to reconcile different bills approved by the House and Senate that would impose tougher air pollution controls on automobiles, industry and electric utilities. But so far the two sides have not even discussed specific compromises on the most controversial areas of the bills, including what smog-reducing controls to impose on automobiles and how industry must cut toxic chemical emissions. At Friday's session, the House and Senate members had trouble even agreeing what issues staff members should discuss during the August recess. The ozone layer 25 miles or so above the earth protects living organisms from the harmful ultraviolet rays of the sun, which can cause skin cancer. The normally inert chemicals in question last so long in the atmosphere that they eventually rise to to ozone layer, where ultraviolet light breaks them down and liberates chlorine that destroys ozone.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lanka Troops Kill About 30 Tamil Rebels
DOC.TEXT: A navy patrol boat bombarded a bunker of Tamil Tigers on the rebel-held Jaffna Peninsula, killing at least 10 people, military officials said Friday. The deaths were among 32 reported in north and east Sri Lanka in the previous 24 hours, the officials said on condition of anonymity. It was the first time since the civil war resumed on June 11 in this Indian Ocean island nation, just off India, that the navy attacked rebel positions. Sailors from the boat launched a surprise ground attack Thursday on the shores of Karainagar in the peninsula, 185 miles north of Colombo. The Tamil Tigers have been fighting since 1983 to set up an independent nation in Sri Lanka. Separatists complain of discrimination in jobs and education by the majority Sinhalese. Communications with the rebels have been cut since fighting broke out, and government accounts can rarely be independently confirmed. In northeastern Trincomalee district, soldiers killed nine insurgents after an abortive Tiger attempt to blow up a bridge at Palanpattu village. Police commandos also killed eight rebels trying to escape across a lagoon in Batticaloa on the east coast. Three other rebels were killed elsewhere in government attacks, and rebels shot and killed two civilians at Majidpuran village in eastern Ampara district, the officials said. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. The Sinhalese, who dominate the government and the military, account for 75 percent. More than 14,000 people have been killed in the 7-year-old Tamil revolt.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Bakes in Record Temperatures
DOC.TEXT: The highest temperature in Britain's history was recorded Friday when the mercury hit 99 degrees, the Meteorological Office said. Weather stations in Cheltenham, 80 miles west of London, and in Nailstone, 95 miles northwest of London, both registered the record high. The highest temperature previously recorded was 98 on Aug. 9, 1911, at both Epsom, 15 miles southwest of London and Canterbury, 55 miles east of London. Police walking the beat in Cheltenham were allowed to patrol without neckties. Brenda Wren, manager of the Bayshill Inn, said, ``I've done nothing but guzzle all day. You need to keep drinking almost non-stop to prevent yourself dehydrating.'' At Peter's Bar, the pub across the road, manager Chris Giles said: ``It's been so hot that I've had great difficulty persuading the customers to keep their clothes on. They all want to strip off!'' In Nailstone, the weather was the chief topic of conversation in the sleepy village's one shop and two pubs. ``It's just ever so hot,'' said a store owner, Joy Lawrence. London's high on Friday was a steamy 95, bringing complaints about the heat and air pollution from residents more accustomed to cool mist and fog. The hot weather has brought a huge Caribbean turtle to the English Channel. The 6-foot-by-7-foot turtle was spotted off Dorset feeding on jellyfish. Marine specialists said other sea-borne migrants, such as the thresher shark and sun fish, have been drawn off course by the unusually warm weather. Airliners headed for the northern runway of London's Heathrow Airport had to change course three days this week after high temperatures caused the newly laid tarmac to buckle. Walkers in the picturesque Lake District in northwest England were ``dropping like flies,'' said Stuart Hulse, of the Langdale and Ambleside mountain rescue team. Operators of Wookey Hole Caves in southwest England reported record business for tours. The caves never vary from a 55 degrees.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Collaborator Killed in West Bank
DOC.TEXT: The bludgeoned body of a Palestinian man suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities was found early Friday, hours after masked Arabs kidnapped him from his West Bank home. The death of 43-year-old Majid Darwish in the Tulkarem refugee camp in the Israeli-occupied West Bank came amid efforts by Palestinian leaders to try to reduce such killings. Darwish's death raised to at least 244 the number of Palestinians slain by fellow Arabs during the 31-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied territories. Most of the victims have been accused of collaboration. Another 725 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the rebellion, and 45 Israelis have died. Arab reports said Darwish was taken from his home by masked activists identified as members of the ``Black Tigers'' gang. The masked men later marched through the camp with loudspeakers announcing that Darwish had been killed for collaboration, residents said. His body was found with extensive beating and stabbing wounds, they said. The army command confirmed the death and said police were investigating. Palestinian leaders, alarmed at the rise in killings of suspected collaborators, have tried to intervene. A leaflet issued earlier this week by the PLO-linked underground leadership of the uprising said a committee was being formed ``to establish legal procedures ... including those which pertain to interrogations.'' The leaflet condemned torture in interrogations of suspected collaborators and called for ``correct methods'' to be used. Past statements by leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization have sought to limit such killings, but they have never been banned outright.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Reports Big Increase in AIDS Cases
DOC.TEXT: More than 7,000 new cases of AIDS were reported to the World Health Organization in July, increasing the global total to 273,425 since records began. An AIDS update, published Friday, showed 741 cases registered in Romania at the end of June, up from 74 cases recorded in February. Of these, 687 were children under the age of 13. Figures showed 18 of the young victims picked up the disease from their mothers and the rest were infected by contaminated needles and blood in hospitals and orphanages. The United States notified WHO of 3,496 new cases in July, raising the registered number of U.S. victims to 137,385 since reporting began in 1981. The number of reported cases underestimates the true extent of the disease, especially in Africa, WHO officials said. They believe the actual total is two to three times higher. The WHO report covers only victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome and not people infected with the Human Immunodeficiency Virus, HIV, which precedes full-blown AIDS. The United Nations on Wednesday said an estimated 8 million to 10 million people may already carry the HIV virus, spread by sexual contact, infected syringes, contaminated blood and by pregnant women to their babies. The latest figure is 2 million higher than previous estimates. WHO said the increase was because of the unexpectedly swift spread of the disease in sub-Saharan Africa and Asia. The report warned that existing predictions of 15 million to 20 million HIV infections by the year 2000 may also be too low. AIDS is a disease in which a virus attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to a wide variety of infections and cancers.

DOC.HEAD: `Tickemania' Roils Wall Street As Numbers Follow the News
DOC.TEXT: At a Manhattan brokerage firm, the grins and groans of a dozen men watching the tickertape Friday told the story of the ``tickemania'' that characterized the roller coaster ride of stocks following events in the Persian Gulf. As the market plunged Friday, Angelo Falco made light of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's decision to invade Kuwait and a prediction by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze that Iraq would quickly back out. ``I wouldn't be surprised if guys like Hussein, Shevardnadze were playing the market this week,'' he said, evoking some nervous laughter among other investors gathered inside Charles Schwab & Co. Inc. at the World Trade Center. Another man, frowning one moment, was smiling the next as he speculated that the prediction by Shevardnadze had caused the market to rebound 35 points in five minutes. He couldn't believe how quickly the numbers were changing. He pointed at one stock, noting that it stood at $6 a share just moments after it had been $11 per share. ``Eleven, now it's only six. Half price. Half price, unbelievable!'' he shouted. The others focused on the numbers, like gamblers around a casino table. It's typical to hear ``a lot of gallows humor'' on a day like Friday, Falco said, when the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 54.95 points after falling 120 points. ``They're kidding and laughing knowing they're losing thousands of dollars an hour,'' he said. ``Most people are taking a good dunking today.'' Robert A. Burke, editor of an investment trade paper ``Eye On Wall Street,'' watched with detached amusement as a steady stream of men took their turns at the computers. ``I call these guys tickaholics. The disease is tickemania,'' he said. Most of them were the kind of investors who viewed stocks with the same enthusiasm of those bitten by ``Lotto fever,'' he said. ``Everybody in America wants to get rich quick,'' he said. ``These guys are gambling. Once in a while they'll get lucky. Years ago there used to be millions of these guys but the stock market crashed and they all got wiped out.'' Burke attributed the sudden downfall in the market to the announcement Thursday that unemployment had risen to 5.5 percent, its highest level in two years, as well as the Iraqi invasion and a revision of the Gross National Product last week.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Declares Victory, Notes California Still Warring
DOC.TEXT: Florida declared victory over the Mediterranean fruit fly Friday, and agricultural officials gloated that they had swiftly crushed the insects while California was fighting a protracted battle. On April 16, a fruit fly was found in a trap near Miami International Airport. Within a week, the state Agriculture Department launched an extensive trapping and spraying program to keep the infestation localized and then eradicate it. ``Our immediate reaction upon discovery of the Medfly and our all-out effort ... provides a vivid contrast between Florida's eradication program and what's happening in California,'' said Agriculture Commissioner Doyle Conner in a statement. Florida's effort took less than four months, cost less than $1.6 million and was confined to a 20-square-mile area, he said. In contrast, California's infestation has been going on for a year, has spread to more than 900 square miles and already has cost more than $38 million, Conner said. He noted Florida and California ``are both states with large production of fruits and vegetables so essential to our nation's health and are both very vulnerable with long coastlines, deep-water ports, international airports and traverlers. ``Yet we in Florida have been successful in Medfly eradication'' in a short period, he said. Unlike California, where aerial malathion spraying produced a continuing public outcry, the spraying in Virginia Gardens, Miami Springs and parts of Hialeah northwest of Miami went on with little fuss, although some resistance developed as the spraying continued. The aim of Florida's battle, which included eight aerial treatments in seven-day cycles, compared to 21-day cycles in California, was to wipe out the invasion as quickly as possible, Conner said. Medflies lay eggs in host fruit and vegetables, and their larvae feed on the pulp. It is considered the most destructive farm pest because it can attack 250 different varieties of fruit and vegetables.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Jury Misconduct Triggers Mistrial Request in Camarena Case
DOC.TEXT: A mistrial motion was filed Friday on behalf of a defendant in the Enrique Camarena murder case because a newspaper article allegedly found in the jury room may have influenced deliberations. Edward Medvene, the attorney for Ruben Zuno Arce, also claimed government officials may have influenced the jury by conducting ``some sort of formal monitoring system in order to allegedly ensure the jurors' safety.'' Medvene also alleged members of the U.S. Marshal's staff walked in and out of the jury deliberation room on a regular basis and that one of them asked the jurors when they were going to come back with a verdict. ``It is clear that any consideration by the jurors of information outside of the record and not in evidence is improper and may well have affected their deliberations and@or verdict regarding Zuno Arce,'' the motion said. Zuno, the brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria, was found guilty Tuesday of kidnapping, racketeering and aiding and abetting the escape of a fugitive. He was acquitted of murder. The jury is still considering charges against one defendant, Javier Vasquez Velasco, charged with the murder of two American tourists. There were hints of problems with the jury on Thursday when U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie summoned them individually into his chambers for questioning. Medvene said lawyers were not notified about the problems, which turned out to be the discovery of a newspaper article about Zuno. Under questioning, the lawyer said, one juror admitted that the panel ``did consider information outside the record during the course of their deliberations.'' Specifically, Medvene said the juror told of a discussion among panelists in the jury room about an article which appeared in the Los Angeles Times after last week's conviction of defendant Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros. The motion did not say what the discussion was about. The jury convicted Matta, a Honduran business tycoon and convicted drug kingpin, of racketeering, conspiracy and kidnapping, but acquitted him of the murder of Camarena, the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent slain in Mexico in 1985. The jury also convicted former Mexican policeman Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez of kidnapping, but found him innocent of murder.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Prime Minister Fires Deputy, Survives Confidence Vote
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh won a vote of confidence from his governing coalition Friday, ending a political crisis over his dismissal of Devi Lal, a powerful deputy prime minister. ``There was no dissent,'' said Ram Jethmalani, a senior leader of the Janata Dal party, after an hourlong meeting of Parliament members and other leaders of the governing National Front coalition. Singh fired Devi Lal on Wednesday, a move that could have split the Janata Dal and toppled the government. Fears eased Thursday after senior party leaders and Devi Lal said they supported Singh's action. Devi Lal, a popular rural politician who was No. 2 man in the government until his dismissal from the Cabinet, said he would return to power, but would not try to divide the Janata Dal. Singh ordered Devi Lal's dismissal for circulating an allegedly forged letter that accused a Cabinet rival of accepting kickbacks from multinational firms. He also criticized Devi Lal's interview with a weekly news magazine, in which Devi Lal called Singh ``spineless'' and described other Cabinet ministers as ``wimps and cheerleaders.''

DOC.HEAD: Forecasters Say Cesar Likely To Veer Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Cesar moved steadily over the open Atlantic Ocean on Friday and forecasters said it likely would veer to the northwest, diminishing the threat to the U.S. mainland. The tropical storm born in coastal African waters was about 1,100 miles west of the Cape Verde islands over open waters, moving toward the west-northwest at 12 mph with sustained winds near 46 miles per hour. Little change in strength was expected. ``It seems like it will continue to move over open waters,'' said hurricane specialist Lixion Avila at the National Hurricane Center. ``In the next 72 hours it should move more to the northwest. There is a very small probability that it will turn back to the west.'' At 10:30 p.m. EDT, Cesar's center was located near 19.9 latitude north and 41.7 longitude west, about 1,100 miles miles west of the Cape Verde Islands. The fourth tropical depression of the Atlantic hurricane season, Cesar grew from a tropical wave that formed Wednesday afternoon. Tropical depressions become named storms when their top sustained winds reach 39 mph. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Seeks Disaster Status for Chicago's Blackout Area
DOC.TEXT: Gov. James R. Thompson on Friday asked for federal disaster relief for businesses on Chicago's West Side that were hit by a three-day blackout last weekend. In a letter to the U.S. Small Business Administration, Thompson said it is ``crucial'' that the government help the 40,000 utility customers _ including 2,000 small businesses _ affected by the blackout. ``This area of the city is particularly depressed economically; a large portion of the residents are receiving public assistance,'' he wrote. ``Federal involvement in the form of subsidized loans is crucial.'' Mayor Richard M. Daley said losses from the blackout may amount to millions of dollars. Meanwhile, a spokesman for Commonwealth Edison Co. disputed a lawsuit filed by the city Thursday that charges the utility's was negligent in failing to properly maintain a transformer. Edison spokesman John Hogan said there was no evidence of negligence. ``They seem to be jumping to conclusions that no investigator has come to yet,'' Hogan said. ``In the absence of any proof of negligence, the courts have historically thrown these types of cases out.'' Alderman Jesus Garcia filed the action, asking for unspecified damages for the 38,000 residential customers and 2,000 businesses that lost power after a fire in utility equipment on Saturday. ``This is not an act of God,'' said James Fennerty, an attorney who filed the lawsuit. ``It could have been prevented. It should have been prevented. There must have been some negligence, even if we can't prove it.'' Garcia said if the plaintiffs are successful in court, restitution could range from $50 for residents to several thousand dollars for businesses that lost sales and perishable items.

In the superpowers' first joint sanctions against a war, the United States and Soviet Union have urged a world embargo of weapons sales to Iraq and demanded that the Baghdad government pull its troops out of Kuwait. ``We have been assured that very soon the Iraqis will pull out their troops,'' Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze told a Friday news conference with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III at his side. He said the Soviets received the assurances through contacts in Baghdad. Later Friday an Iraqi government spokesman said Iraqi troops will begin withdrawing from Kuwait on Sunday, Baghdad Radio announced. Iraq claimed the decision was not because of international pressure. It was a historic case of the superpowers acting together to try to end hostilities.

Iraq's invasion of Kuwait already is costing U.S. motorists more at the gas pump. Some elected officials, service-station owners and motorists are accusing oil companies of price gouging. A survey of 1,400 retail gasoline stations nationwide showed self-serve unleaded gasoline prices increased 4 cents in two days, to an average of $1.11 a gallon, the American Automobile Association said Friday. Spot checks by AAA clubs in Florida, Michigan, Missouri, North Carolina, South Carolina and the Washington, D.C., area Friday showed retail prices shot up 4 to 14 cents a gallon, the association said. In Wisconsin, ``prices are just jumping up like crazy,'' sometimes increasing every 12 hours, said Robert Park, director of trade practices in the Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection. Increases as high as 10 cents a gallon were reported and further hikes were expected today, he said. Major oil companies increased wholesale prices, blaming surging energy markets. Prices for crude oil, gasoline and home heating oil futures rose for a second day Friday because of uncertainty about future Mideast supplies.

The House passed major civil rights legislation opposed by President Bush and a Democratic-sponsored campaign finance overhaul before taking its summer recess early today. As lawmakers rushed for the doors, the House also sent to the president a long-awaited bill designed to cut down on offshore oil spills. The Senate, meanwhile, passed an emergency debt bill early this morning and planned today to finish a $289 billion defense plan for fiscal 1991, the last item standing in the way of its vacation. Despite the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq that began Thursday, the Senate also early today approved by voice vote and without debate the nomination of Edward W. Gnehm to be U.S. ambassador to Kuwait.

A new technique that allows diagnosis of inherited diseases in an unfertilized human egg before conception is being described as an important step toward the prevention of genetic diseases. On Friday, researchers reported that they had diagnosed cystic fibrosis in a human egg before conception. They said the technique could be used with many other inherited ailments, including muscular dystrophy, hemophilia and sickle cell anemia. The technique could satisfy some abortion opponents' objections to fetal diagnosis, said Yury Verlinsky, director of the Reproductive Genetics Institute at Illinois Masonic Medical Center in Chicago. These diseases can now be diagnosed in the fetus before birth. But such diagnosis often leaves the parents with no option but to terminate the pregnancy if the fetus carries the disease.

The resignation of the nation's highest-ranking black Roman Catholic clergyman because he was intimate with a woman has renewed debate over mandatory celibacy for priests and raised fears of a racial backlash. Atlanta Archbishop Eugene Marino resigned last month because of his two-year relationship with a lay minister, Vicki R. Long, church officials confirmed this week. They previously said he resigned for health reasons. Ms. Long, 27, has filed a monetary claim against the archdiocese for an undisclosed amount. Neither Marino nor Ms. Long have commented about their relationship. Bishop James P. Lyke, the acting administrator of the Atlanta Archdiocese, would not say whether the relationship was sexual, describing it only as ``intimate.'' Church officials and theologians say Marino's prominence will provoke debate over church law dating to the Middle Ages requiring Catholic clergy to abstain from sex. Pope John Paul II strongly supports the requirement.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners Likely To Return For Quarterly Auction, Economists Say
DOC.TEXT: Despite foreign investors' recent disinterest in U.S. Treasury securities, economists expect them to resume buying at the upcoming quarterly auction of new notes and bonds. Foreign investors sold more Treasury securities than they bought in the first quarter of 1990, the first time there were net sales since the third quarter of 1988, according to the Securities Industry Association. But Nicholas Sargen, an international economist at Solomon Brothers Inc., said, ``To the extent we've gotten (past) participation ... I wouldn't be surprised to see some buying'' at the auction. The U.S. Treasury is scheduled to sell a record $32.25 billion of three- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday to help refinance the federal deficit. This quarter's amount surpasses last quarter's record $30.5 billion Sargen said that while the trend has been toward less foreign buying in the U.S. Treasuries market, foreign investors, particularly Japanese, try to concentrate their buying on the refunding. As broker-dealers they are obligated to make a bid at the auction. Also, those seeking liquidity usually choose to buy the latest issue. Foreign investors' reasons for staying away from the U.S. market have been good _ yields on government bonds in other countries offer them better returns. For instance, this past week, West Germany's 10-year bond was yielding 8{ percent, about 0.16 percentage point more than the U.S. 10-year note. Also, the spread between the U.S. 10-year note and the comparable Japanese bond has been narrowing. Most notably Canada, Japan, the Netherlands, Singapore and Australia, sold $6.5 billion more U.S. Treasury securities than they bought in the first three months of the year, according to the SIA. But economists warn that foreign investors, who are spreading the word they might not do much buying during the auction, could be trying to push down the price so they can get bargains and higher yields. ``You never know until the actual event to what extent they actually participate,'' said Irwin Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Government reports of a soft economy could help domestic buying sentiment at the auction as investors seek the fixed interest-rate notes and bonds, predicting the Federal Reserve will bring down interest rates to prevent the nation from falling into a recession. Bad economic news might encourage enough domestic investors to buy the securities to make up for any shortage of foreign investors, said Marilyn Schaja, a money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. Last week, the Commerce Department reported the Index of Leading Economic Indicators was unchanged in June. Many economists had expected the index, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, would increase slightly. Also, the Labor Department said the unemployment rate jumped to 5.5 percent in July, the highest in two years and further evidence of a weakening economy.

DOC.BYLINE: World Economies Could Suffer From Sustained Oil Price Hike
DOC.TEXT: A sustained rise in oil prices due to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and speculation about further aggression threatens a global economic slowdown, higher inflation and rising interest rates, experts say. However, the industrial world is much less vulnerable to oil shocks than it was in the 1970s, when Arab oil embargoes rattled Western economies, they said. ``The situation will be different. Even in the worst case scenario, it is unlikely that oil prices will jump on a sustained basis as they did then,'' said Michael Hughes, an economist at the London investment firm Barclays de Zoete Wedd. But, Hughes added, ``The impact on the world economy could still be quite significant.'' At the very least, the developments will bring unwelcome uncertainty to the global economic outlook. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Thursday sent the spot price soaring for North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude. The oil traded at above $24 a barrel by late Friday in London. That was some 50 percent higher than the price of nearly $16 a barrel on July 12, when Iraqi President Saddam Hussein began threatening to take action against Kuwait. Iraq accused its much-smaller neighbor of stealing oil from border areas and of costing Iraq billions of dollars in lost revenue by overproducing crude and helping to depress world oil prices. The proximity of Iraqi troops to the border with Saudi Arabia late in the week raised further speculation of threats to supplies. Geoff Pyne, an oil analyst with UBS Phillips and Drew, said under the best-case scenario, based on current supplies, oil prices should settle at $21 to $22 a barrel. If supplies are seriously disrupted, prices could reach $30 a barrel, he said, levels crude reached in the mid-1980s before a sustained price drop pummeled oil producers. The most vulnerable country is Japan, which imports 99 percent of its oil, economists say. The Arab oil embargo after the 1973 Arab-Israeli war set back Japan's economic growth with skyrocketing oil prices, inflation and cutbacks in industrial production. If oil prices rise to at least $25 a barrel and maintain that level through next year, Japan's economic growth could fall to 3.6 percent instead of the expected 3.9 percent next year, and its annual inflation could rise to 2.8 percent instead of 2.1 percent, said Stephen King, international economist at the London investment firm James Capel and Co. In the United States _ where the economy already has shown signs of slipping into a recession _ economic growth could be 1.5 percent next year instead of the forecast 2 percent, King said. Inflation could be 5.2 percent instead of 4.75 percent. ``In the United States you can wonder whether an oil shock, if there is to be an oil shock, is the straw that breaks the camel back,'' King said. ``It does appear the chances of recession are increasing anyway.'' Germany should still have growth of 4 percent and inflation of 3.5 percent next year, King said. But interest rates could rise in Germany, as well as in Japan, he said. ``They have plenty of reasons already to tighten policy and the oil price could be an extra reason,'' King said. The United States will be torn between wanting to lower interest rates to spur growth and wanting to raise them to counter the inflationary pressures of higher oil prices, King said. The temptation will be to leave interest rates unchanged, which could slow growth enough to tip the United States into recession, he said. Joe Roseman, a British economist at UBS Phillips and Drew, said a sustained, $25 a barrel oil price could mean British economic growth of 1.7 percent instead of 1.9 percent next year and inflation of 6.5 percent instead of 5.5 percent. Also threatened are developing economies and eastern European countries which are attempting to turn themselves into market economies. But oil prices haven't risen proportionally anywhere near as much as in the 1970s oil shocks, King said. In the 1979 oil price shock prompted by the Iranian revolution, oil prices nearly tripled to an annual average of nearly $37 a barrel from $13. Pyne said. In the 1973 price rise, blamed on the Arab oil embargo, prices almost quadrupled from $2.80 a barrel to $10.40, he said. Currently there is a world oil glut, and a slowdown in economic growth in the past two years has eased demand for oil, the experts said. Furthermore, the 1970s energy crises prompted further development of alternate sources of oil and other forms of energy and conservation methods, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Cincinnati Utility Buys Two French Firms
DOC.TEXT: Cincinnati Bell Inc. announced Friday it has acquired majority ownership of two French telemarketing agencies for $39 million. Cincinnati Bell, a holding company, said it acquired Phone Marketing Services SA and Syscall S.A.R.L. through its MATRIXX Marketing Inc. subsidiary. Cincinnati Bell said the acquisitions fit into its strategic growth plans.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Supplier Buying Generic Drug House
DOC.TEXT: Ivax Corp., a medical supply company, said Friday it had agreed to acquire Harris Pharmaceuticals Ltd., a leading British manufacturer of generic drugs, in a stock swap valued at about $75 million. Ivax has agreed to exchange 6.25 million of its shares, representing a 25 percent stake in Ivax, for all of Harris' outstanding shares, which are privately held. The Ivax shares are worth about $75 million at recent prices. Harris, with facilities in London and Waterford, Ireland, had $64 million in sales with $3 million in net profits in the year ended March 31. Ivax Corp. is a Miami-based holding company for divisions that distribute generic drugs and produce diagnostic equipment, pharmaceuticals and dermatological supplies.

DOC.HEAD: Pump Prices Hold, But Station Operators Taking a Hit
DOC.TEXT: The convulsions in the Middle East stirred unhappy memories of price shocks of 1974 and 1979 _ the specter of $2-a-gallon gas, cars queued up around the block, ``NO GAS'' signs on pumps. Experts say that's highly unlikely. But for independent gas station owners like Bob Horick in Minnetonka, Minn., Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait this past week hit quickly. His customers haven't felt the impact yet, but he has. That's because wholesale prices for gasoline moved up nationwide after Iraq stormed through its OPEC neighbor Thursday, provoking fears of a world supply crunch. Analysts reported jumps of 5 cents to 12 cents a gallon or more for wholesale gasoline, even in places Minnesota, which gets most of its oil from Canada, and California, which is supplied from oil-rich Alaska. The increase in wholesale prices followed rises on spot oil markets worldwide. They occurred even though oil companies were selling existing inventories. Horick's supplier raised prices 5 cents a gallon at noon and another 2 cents at midnight. Horick dispatched a truck to a pipeline terminal in Roseville, Minn., to try to buy gasoline at old prices. But trucks were lined up for more than two miles. He made the purchase at an extra cost of $595 a load. So Horick just passed on the extra 6 cents a gallon cost to consumers, right? Wrong. He kept the retail price of unleaded gasoline at $1.099 a gallon at his stations in St. Paul and Hutchinson, Minn., 50 miles west of the Twin Cities. Major oil companies set the tone for small retailers. Competition dictates that only when the big companies raise prices can the little guy match them. If Horick ups his price first, he risks fewer customers and less secondary business in candy, soft drinks, cigarettes and road maps. ``There isn't a retailer in this country who wants to be the first to raise his price on the street,'' said Brian Ettesvold, executive director of the Minnesota Service Stations Association in St. Paul. But the effect of higher crude prices doesn't hit major oil companies for about three months, the time it takes them to refine existing crude. In the interim, they can absorb a hit at the pumps by raising wholesale prices. ``They can really hurt the independents at a time like this,'' Horick said. Kevin Lindemer, an energy analyst with Cambridge Research Associates in Cambridge, Mass., said the panicky atmosphere and increased demand during the summer driving season doesn't help. ``Now that there's a perception in the market that prices are going up everybody scrambles to fill their inventory,'' he said. ``There's also the fear factor that if I don't fill up now the price is going to be a lot higher tomorrow.'' To avoid a rapid depletion of stocks and discourage panic buying, some wholesalers quickly allocated supplies to ensure an even distribution while others have stopped making deliveries altogether. Service station groups say the average U.S. gas tank is half full. If every driver filled up at once, it would take 30 to 60 days to refine enough crude oil to replenish the nation's gasoline inventories, they say. Short of a nationwide panic, energy analysts said the world's oil production system today makes the likelihood of a repeat of the troubles of the 1970s unlikely. For one thing, there are no signs of a large cutoff in oil supplies because of the Iraqi invasion. In the first five months of 1990 the United States imported 610,000 barrels of oil a day from Iraq, less than 8 percent of total imports, and 120,000 barrels a day from Kuwait, less than one half of 1 percent. Domestic crude oil stocks are at their highest level in eight years. Lindemer said surplus production capacity in other countries could quickly make up for losses from Kuwait or Iraq, including 2 million barrels outside the Persian Gulf region. In 1979, the Iranian revolution cut off the country's 6 million barrels a day from world markets. In 1974, the United States embargoed oil imports from the Arab world. Production capacity elsewhere was thin, in contrast to today's market. And no one is anxious to repeat the recession that accompanied both '70s oil crises. ``Everybody is well aware what very high oil prices did to the consuming as well as producing economies,'' Lindemer said. ``Everybody is trying to head that off.'' In other business and economic news this past week: _Economic reports were gloomy, contributing to declines in the stock market. The government said its index of leading economic indicators was unchanged in June, construction spending held steady and the nation's unemployment rate jumped to 5.5 percent in July. A private study of purchasing managers' activity pointed to a sluggish manufacturing sector. _The ballooning cost of bailing out the nation's savings and loans ballooned even more. The Bush administration said the cleanup would require about $100 million in the next 12 months. Officials said junk bond losses alone from thrifts seized by the government would exceed $1 billion. Congress, meanwhile, approved legislation to increase prison terms for S&L cheats. _General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger Smith drove the secretive Saturn car off an assembly line in a closed ceremony, retiring after 41 years with GM. He was succeeded by Robert Stempel. Elsewhere, the auto industry continued on a grim course as Chrysler Corp. reported a 47 percent drop in second-quarter earnings.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Hits Iraqi Oil Slick
DOC.TEXT: Visions of a pair of old nemeses _ recession and energy crisis _ are back haunting the investment markets of Wall Street. The chill they created spread through world financial centers after Iraq invaded Kuwait this past week, driving oil prices sharply higher. Suddenly, Wall Street veterans were recounting tales of the 1970s, when stocks and bonds languished under the influence of a slumping domestic economy and a runaway rise in the price of oil. From American investors' point of view, there could scarcely be any good time for a new flareup of trouble in the Middle East. But Iraq's action struck many analysts as especially inopportune, coming as it did when evidence was starting to accumulate fast that the U.S. economy was turning weaker than almost anyone had thought just a few weeks ago. On Friday the Labor Department reported that nonfarm payroll employment fell by 219,000 in July, surprising analysts who had been looking for a modest increase. The civilian unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent. A sustained simultaneous rise in oil prices and unemployment would stand to compound the problems facing the Federal Reserve in setting its monetary policy. Increasing joblessness would seem to mandate moves to ease credit, and thus cushion the potential effects of a recession. But the inflationary impact of higher energy prices could stymie any effort by the Fed to lower long-term interest rates. In the midst of this crossfire would stand the banking system, already burdened by the strains of a retrenchment from the credit boom of the '80s. Twice in the past two weeks, the Dow Jones industrial average has suffered intraday declines of more than 100 points. But on the second occasion, on Friday, some analysts said the market was simply jumping around wildly in reaction to breaking news from the Middle East, rather than providing any reliable gauge of a lasting shift in investor sentiment. ``I don't think it was so much a panic as a desire to get to safety before the market closed for the weekend,'' said William LeFevre, an analyst at Advest Inc. ``We have a global market with instant communications. But diplomacy takes time.'' At the close on Friday Dow Jones's average of 30 blue chips stood at 2,809.65, down 88.86 points from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 4.50 to 188.82; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 25.11 to 417.46, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 8.86 at 346.63. Volume on the Big Board averaged 208.51 million shares a day, up from 171.72 million the week before. As events unfolded in the Middle East and the economy, some analysts declared that a recession was increasingly imminent or even under way. David A. Levy and S. Jay Levy, economists in Chappaqua, N.Y., rated recession a 60 percent probability even before the new conflict in the Middle East flared up. ``An economic storm is threatening,'' they asserted. ``The most visible black clouds are decreasing unit retail sales, the housing recession and stagnant employment.'' Other, more optimistic observers say the Fed will move swiftly to combat recession if the economic indicators keep worsening. That could set up a stern test of the central bank's powers over an economy driven by worldwide forces.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Airlines Announces Fuel Surcharge
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines, moving to counter rising jet fuel prices, said Friday it will add a flat one-way surcharge of $8 to the price of domestic tickets beginning Aug. 9. The surcharge stems directly from increases in jet fuel costs incurred by the carrier since Iraqi troops invaded oil-rich Kuwait, said Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons. ``This will give us a chance to see what happens in the next few days,'' Gibbons said. ``This is not intended to be a permanent increase, and it's certainly adjustable.'' Fuel prices have jumped 8 cents a gallon and are expected to rise even higher because of uncertainty in the Persian Gulf. Gibbons predicted other airlines would follow Northwest's lead as jet fuel costs continue to rise. ``The effect of the uncertainty in the Middle East is clear. It packs a pretty big wallop,'' he said. The surcharge will be reviewed periodically, and could jump even higher, said Gibbons. He said Northwest is also considering adding a similar surcharge to its international flights. Fuel surcharges do not require governmewnt approval for domestic flights. Fuel costs are a major contributor to the operating expenses of all airlines, said Jack Van Der Wege, senior director of fuel administration. Crude oil prices have jumped considerably since Wednesday and will be sharply higher in August than was previously anticipated. Fuel is Northwest's second-largest cost, accounting for about 17 percent of its operating expenses. In January, the Eagan-based carrier announced similar surcharges to offset rising jet fuel costs, but withdrew them additional before they went into effect.
